questions.text:
A 8-year-old child presented with the deformity shown in the image. Subsequent investigations revealed a mutation in the PHEX gene and increased levels of fibroblast growth factor-23 (FGF 23). Which of the following blood parameters is most likely to be seen in this patient ?

ALP - Alkaline phosphatase
questions.solution:
Low serum PO4  is the likely blood parameter seen in this patient.

The given clinical scenario with the image showing the wind-swept deformity (characteristic of rickets in a pediatric patient) and PHEX gene mutation is suggestive of a diagnosis of X-linked dominant hypophosphatemic rickets. 

X-linked dominant hypophosphatemic rickets is the most common genetic cause of rickets. But the overall most common cause of rickets remains to be nutritional vitamin D deficiency. PHEX gene (phosphate-regulating endopeptidase on X chromosome) products are responsible for the inactivation of phosphatonin. Mutation of this PHEX leads to increased phosphatonin (FGF 23) levels. This leads to impaired renal tubular reabsorption of phosphate and hence the excretion of phosphorous is increased. It also inhibits renal 1-alpha hydroxylase leading to reduced 1,25 dihydroxy vitamin D. 

The patient's laboratory reports will show low phosphate levels or increased urinary phosphate. All other parameters such as calcium, PTH(parathyroid hormone) and pH are normal with raised alkaline phosphatase(ALP) levels.

Clinical features of X-linked dominant hypophosphatemic(XLH) rickets include lower extremity abnormalities, short stature, poor growth, delayed dentition, and tooth abscesses. The wind-swept deformity is due to genu varus(leg going inward compared to the knee joint) on one side and genu valgus(leg going outward compared to the knee) on the contralateral side.

Mainstay treatment of hypophosphatemic rickets includes oral phosphorus and 1,25-D (calcitriol). Phosphorus supplementation is usually given in 1-3 g elemental phosphorus divided into 4–5 doses. Frequent dosing reduces diarrhoea, which is a complication of high-dose oral phosphorus. Calcitriol is administered 30–70 ng/kg/day divided into 2 doses.

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Rickets

Radiological features of rickets:

  • Loss of provisional zone of calcification: earliest radiological finding of rickets. 
  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis
  • Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth plate is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  • Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis
  • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
  • In healing rickets, zone of calcification becomes denser. 

The above features are prominent at the growth plates where growth is greatest:

  • Knee: distal femur, proximal tibia
  • Wrist: especially the ulna
  • Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary

questions.text: An epidemiologist is studying pattern of disease related to mansonia mosquitoes. Which of the following findings are likely to be found regarding the disease transmission and its breeding habit?

choices.text: It transmits rift valley fever and breeds in artificially collected water
It transmits brugian filariasis and breeds in roots of aquatic plants
It transmits river blindness and breeds in clean water
It transmits west nile fever and breeds in dirty water

questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the disease transmitted by mansonia species of mosquito is Brugian filariasis (caused by B.malayi) and it breeds in roots of aquatic plants.

Adult Mansonia mosquitos are big, black or brown mosquitoes with speckling on their wings and legs. They breed in ponds and lakes containing certain aquatic plants, especially the floating types like Pistia stratiotes and water hyacinth. Their breeding is not possible in absence of these plants. Thus, removing the aquatic vegetation and destroying the vegetation using herbicides can be done to control Brugian filariasis.

Option A: Rift Valley fever is transmitted by Aedes mosquito which breeds in the artificial collected water 

Option C: River blindness also called Onchocerca volvulus is transmitted by the black fly. The vector black fly (genus-Simulium) breeds in fast-flowing rivers. Therefore, the disease is most common along the course of rivers. Hence, the name ‘river blindness’.

Option D: West Nile fever is transmitted by Culex mosquito which breed in the dirty, polluted water.

questions.text: A surgeon applies a very tight plaster cast on patient’s leg and asks the patient to inform if he develops any numbness. The patient develops numbness but does not inform the doctor immediately. Next day, when the patient informs the doctor, the doctor says he is too busy to remove the cast. After a few days, the patient develops a permanent injury. The doctor is held guilty under:
questions.solution:
This is a case of last clear chance doctrine and the doctor is held guilty.

In this case:

  • The doctor showed negligence by applying tight plaster cast, however, gave proper instructions to the patient.
  • The patient has neglected by not informing the doctor immediately after he developed numbness.
  • When the patient informed the doctor the next day, the doctor still had a chance to remove the cast and prevent permanent injury. But the doctor again neglected and thus missed the last clear chance.

So, the doctor cannot plead for contributory negligence and will be held guilty under the last clear chance doctrine.

Other options:

Option D: Medical maloccurrence is a defence against negligence for doctors. In certain cases, despite proper medical skill, attention, and care, the patient may fail to respond or suffer from the adverse effects of drugs. 

Related Pearl: Contributory negligence

Contributory negligence occurs when a patient or his personal attendant shows unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care, which when combined with the negligence of the doctor, has contributed to the injury. In this case, the patient’s or attendant’s negligence should be the direct, proximate cause and without which the injury would not have occurred.

So, contributory negligence occurs when both the doctor and patient are negligent. The direct or proximate cause of the injury should be the patient’s negligence, which means that if the patient was not negligent, the injury could have been prevented.

Contributory negligence usually occurs when the doctor is negligent and the patient:

  • Fails to give an accurate medical history, and as a result, the doctor may misdiagnose or mistreat the patient.
  • Fails to follow the doctor’s instructions
  • Refuses to take the treatment
  • Leaves the hospital against doctor’s advice
  • Does not inform the doctor or seek further medical assistance if the symptoms persist or worsens.

Contributory negligence is a defence for doctor’s negligence in civil cases. However, from case to case, the liability of a doctor may vary from complete non-liability to substantial liability for the damages. Under the doctrine of comparative negligence, the court has the right to hold both parties liable for their negligent actions.

Limitations / Exceptions to contributory negligence:

A. The doctor will be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. The doctor failed to provide proper instructions to the patient

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and did not tell the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (no proper instruction). The patient develops numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

 2. Last clear chance doctrine: It is applicable when the doctor fails to take necessary action to prevent damage due to a negligent act of the patient, even after getting a clear chance to take such action.

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and told the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (gave proper instruction). The patient developed numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). Next day patient informed the doctor, but the doctor did not remove the cast and said he was busy (There was a clear last chance, but the doctor neglected again). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

B. The doctor/person will not be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. Avoidable consequences rule: It occurs when an injury is caused due to doctor’s negligence, and the patient has done a negligent act, which further aggravated the injury caused by the doctor, and the patient could have avoided the consequence by not doing such act. In such cases, the doctor need not pay anything, and the patient will be held guilty.

  • Ex: A patient had a lacerated wound. The doctor examined the patient and had not done any dressing or provided any antibiotics (the doctor is negligent). However, the doctor instructed the patient to avoid contamination and asked him to visit the clinic next week. When the patient went home, he applied cow dung on his wound every day thinking that the wound would heal faster and didn't visit the doctor after one week. The wound got infected and developed pus and aggravated the injury.
  • Here, despite the doctor being negligent in the first instance, the patient is responsible for his injury as he performed an unnecessary, avoidable act, which aggravated the injury. The doctor need not pay anything.

2. Good Samaritan doctrine: A person who assists another person who is in serious danger cannot be charged with contributory negligence. unless such assistance is reckless or rash.

  • Ex: A person was travelling on a road and saw a car accident, where the victim was unconscious and was stuck inside the car. He called the ambulance. The paramedical staff instructed him not to mobilize the victim until they arrived. Meanwhile, the car was caught in fire (serious danger), and the person tried to remove the victim carefully out of the car (assisted the victim and was not reckless). However, the victim already had a cervical bone fracture due to the accident, which got mobilized while he was being removed out of the car and as a result, suffered an injury to the spine that led to paralysis (victim’s injury was aggravated). In such a case, the good samaritan doctrine would apply and the person who tried to help, will not be charged under contributory negligence.

questions.text:
A 64-year-old male patient who is being treated for diabetic ketoacidosis suddenly becomes hypotensive. His pulse rate is thready and rapid with BP 88/54 mm Hg. An electrocardiogram is obtained, and laboratory tests are given below. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?

Blood glucose- 220 mg/dl
Sodium (Na+) - 137 mEq/L; Potassium (K+) - 2.5 mEq/L
Calcium (Ca2+) - 8.5 mg/L; Magnesium (Mg2+) -  1 mEq/L
questions.solution:
The given ECG depicts torsades de pointes which is a type of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia. The most appropriate management for this patient would be IV magnesium sulfate infusion. 

Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia is characterized by variable QRS morphologies, meaning each QRS complex looks different from another, as they arise from different ventricular sites. Torsades de pointes means “twisting of the points,” as it appears as though the QRS axis is twisting around the baseline. 

These patients usually present with palpitations, dizziness, or syncope. The laboratory results may reveal the underlying cause such as hypomagnesemia and hypokalemia.

QT interval prolongation (caused due to a delay in repolarization of the ventricles) is a predisposing factor for torsades de pointes. It can be caused due to:

Inherited QT prolongation syndromes:

  • Jervell and Lange Neilson syndrome
  • Ramano-Ward syndrome.

Acquired causes:

  • Drugs like quinidine, procainamide, disopyramide, and dofetilide
  • Bradycardia
  • Acute ischemia or infarction.

The drug of choice for the management of torsades de pointes is IV magnesium sulfate infusion. It acts by suppressing early after-depolarizations that are responsible for arrhythmia, by preventing the entry of calcium into the cell. Other measures include discontinuation of the offending drug, correction of underlying electrolyte abnormalities, pH, and hypoxia. Definitive treatment includes electrical pacing.

questions.text:
A 7-day-old term neonate presents with jaundice and on blood investigations, unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia is seen. The baby is otherwise healthy and exclusively breastfed. A diagnosis of breast milk jaundice is suspected. What is the pathogenesis of the condition?

MRP 2 - Multiple drug-resistant protein 2
questions.solution:
The pathogenesis of breast milk jaundice is increased ß-glucuronidase.

Breast milk jaundice is a type of neonatal jaundice that occurs in neonates due to breast milk feeding. It usually happens within the first week of life due to the abnormal accumulation of unconjugated bilirubin, leading to jaundice. The pathology of breast milk jaundice is attributed to the contents of breast milk whereas in breastfeeding jaundice there is inadequate breastfeeding.      

Breast milk contains inhibitors of UDP-glucuronyl transferase that prevents hepatic conjugation of unconjugated bilirubin. Another constituent of breast milk is ß-glucuronidase which is an enzyme that deconjugates bilirubin in the intestinal brush border, leading to increased serum reabsorption instead of excretion of bilirubin. Thus increases enterohepatic recirculation of unconjugated bilirubin. 

Infant factors contributing to breast milk jaundice include decreased gut flora that converts conjugated bilirubin into stercobilinogen and excreted in stools. As well as increased gut permeability in infants promotes the enterohepatic recirculation of bilirubin. 

Breast milk jaundice usually is self-limiting in the 2nd to 3rd week of life. Other causes should be ruled out in infants with severe or persistent jaundice. Rarely due to persistent elevated bilirubin levels, they may require changing from breast milk to infant formula for 24-48 hr and/or treatment with phototherapy without cessation of breastfeeding. 

Other options:

Option A: Breastfeeding jaundice occurs due to inadequate breastfeeding which typically reaches its peak between the third and fifth day after birth and is often accompanied by excessive weight loss. They also show increased unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

Option B: Dubin Johnson syndrome shows multi-drug-resistant protein 2(MRP- 2) mutation. It is an autosomal recessive hyperbilirubinemia syndrome characterised by conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and black-pigmented liver on biopsy due to an epinephrine metabolite. 

Option C: Crigler-Najjar syndrome type-I is due to the absence of UDP-glucoronyl transferase enzyme. It is an autosomal recessive hyperbilirubinemia syndrome characterized by severe unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia and usually presents with kernicterus. It is usually fatal in the neonatal period.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman has had a degenerative high axial myopia since childhood. Which of the following marked areas of the eyeball is likely to show an ectatic portion in a B-mode ultrasound scan?
questions.solution:
A degenerative high axial myopia is likely to be associated with a posterior staphyloma which is marked as point D in the above image.

Staphyloma refers to ectasia of the outer coats of the eye i.e. cornea or sclera or both, as a result of the weakening of the eyewall due to inflammation or degenerative diseases. The staphyloma is lined internally by uveal tissue and externally by weak cornea or sclera.

Depending on the site affected, a staphyloma can be classified into anterior, posterior, intercalary, ciliary and equatorial staphyloma.

Posterior staphyloma refers to ectasia of the posterior pole of the eye lined by the choroid and is detected by fundoscopy and B-scan ultrasonography. The most common cause is degenerative high axial myopia. Indirect ophthalmoscopy shows a posterior outward curvature of the globe seen as a crescentic shadow in the macular region. The retinal vessels dip down into the region. The staphylomatous area appears pale due to degeneration of the retina, pigment epithelium, and occasionally the choroid. 

Anterior staphyloma is characterised by ectasia of the pseudo-cornea, which occurs after the total sloughing of the cornea. It is internally lined by the iris and externally by the newly formed epithelium. The most common cause is a sloughing corneal ulcer.

Equatorial staphyloma (point C) occurs in the equatorial region up to 14 mm behind the limbus of the eye due to scleritis, degenerative myopia and chronic uncontrolled glaucoma.

Intercalary staphyloma (point A) is located at the limbus and is lined by the root of the iris and the anteriormost part of the ciliary body. It may occur due to perforating injuries and ulcers of the peripheral cornea, anterior scleritis, scleromalacia perforans and secondary glaucoma.
 
Ciliary staphyloma (point B) is characterised by ectasia of weak sclera lined by the ciliary body. This affects the ciliary zone, which includes the region up to 8 mm behind the limbus. It may occur due to developmental glaucoma, end-stage primary or secondary glaucoma, scleritis and ciliary trauma.

questions.text: A  veterinarian presented to the clinic with fever, malaise, and headache. On examination, a lesion is seen on his arm as shown in the below image. Later the patient developed sepsis. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the toxin produced by the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette showing black, central, necrotic eschar surrounded by edematous skin in a veterinarian is strongly suggestive of cutaneous anthrax caused by Bacillus anthracis where the toxin acts by the increase in cAMP.

Bacillus anthracis is a large, gram-positive bacillus. It is non-motile and capsulated with a characteristic polypeptide capsule made of poly-γ-d-glutamic acid. 

Bacillus anthracis may cause:

  • Cutaneous anthrax: It is caused by contact with infected animal/ animal products. It is seen in tanners and hide-porters. At the site of entry of organism or spores, a papule develops which further develops into a vesicle. It later breaks down into an ulcer with a black, central, necrotic eschar surrounded by edematous skin. The lesion is also called a 'malignant pustule'. A majority of the patients tend to recover spontaneously. However, some patients may succumb to septicemia or meningitis.
  • Pulmonary anthrax (Wool sorter’s disease): It is caused by inhaling spores. It is seen in wool sorters. The infection from the lung spreads to the mediastinal lymph nodes and causes hemorrhagic mediastinitis and sepsis. 
  • Gastrointestinal anthrax: It is caused rarely, by ingesting infected animals. 

Virulence factors of Bacillus anthracis include:

  • Polypeptide capsule which is anti-phagocytic.
  • Toxins that are made of three proteins-
    • Protective antigen (PA)- Binds to specific cell receptors and mediates entry of edema factor and lethal factor into the cell.
    • Edema factor (EF)- Is an adenylate cyclase, which is activated only inside the target cells, leading to intracellular accumulation of cyclic AMP and causing tissue edema.
    • Lethal factor (LF)- Causes tissue death.

Other options : 

Option A: Diptheria toxin and Pseudomonas acts by inhibition of elongation factor-2 (EF-2).

Option C: Shiga toxin inhibits protein synthesis by inhibition of 60S ribosomal subunit.

Option D: Some strains of Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) produce a heat-stable toxin that acts by an increase in cGMP.

questions.text: Choose the correct statement about hold-over time in a cold chain.

choices.text: It is the total number of days a vaccine can be held in PHC since its acquirement
It is the time an equipment takes to raise the temperature inside it to threshold limit during power loss
It is the time taken by the vaccine vial monitor to become the same colour as the inside square
It is the time until a vaccine vial can be reused after opening the seal

questions.solution:
Hold-over time is the time taken by a cold-chain equipment to raise the temperature inside it, during loss of power, to the maximum temperature limit in its recommended range. For example, in the case of an ice-lined refrigerator(ILR) the cabinet temperature is +4°C at the time of power-cut, then the time taken to reach +8°C from +4°C will be the hold-over time for that ILR.

For an ice-lined refrigerator(ILR), this time depends on:

  • Ambient temperature
  • Frequency of opening the equipment
  • Quantity of vaccines kept inside with spacing
  • Condition of ice-pack lining

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with fever, lower abdominal pain, and purulent vaginal discharge. There is an associated sharp pain in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. Examination reveals tenderness in the right hypochondrium. Identify the incorrect statement about her condition.

choices.text: It is caused by transperitoneal spread of infection
A chlamydial infection is the most likely etiology
It is characterized by inflammation of the liver parenchyma
Laparoscopy will reveal violin-string adhesions around the liver

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with fever, lower abdominal pain, and purulent vaginal discharge is suggestive of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). The features of sharp pain and tenderness in the right upper abdomen are because of the associated Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome. This is characterized by inflammation of the liver capsule and there is no involvement of the liver parenchyma. Hence, option C is incorrect.

Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome is a sequelae of PID. It is caused by transperitoneal or vascular dissemination of the primary pelvic infection (option A). Chlamydia trachomatis is the most common pathogen involved in this condition (option B). However, it can also be caused due to a gonococcal infection. 

It is characterized by the perihepatitis or inflammation of the liver capsule. This results in the formation of adhesions between the liver capsule and the anterior abdomen. On laparoscopy, this can be visualized as a "violin-string" adhesion around the liver (option D). 

The image given represents the laparoscopic finding of violin-string adhesions:

PID is the infection of the female upper genital tract involving the fallopian tubes (salpingitis), ovaries (oophoritis), and uterus (endometritis). The most common causes of PID in sexually active young females are gonococci and chlamydia. If untreated, complications include infertility, chronic pelvic pain, ectopic pregnancy, and hydrosalpinx.

questions.text:
Which of the following is an example of a type of exocrine gland shown below?

EAM - External auditory meatus

choices.text: Sweat glands in the axilla and pubis

questions.solution:
The illustration of an exocrine gland depicting the mechanism shown indicates that it is a holocrine gland. An example of this is the Meibomian glands (palpebral tarsal glands) in the eye which are modified sebaceous glands. 

In holocrine glands, the entire cell disintegrates while discharging its secretion, which is commonly poured into an adjacent hair follicle. It is typically seen in sebaceous glands. A few examples include: 

  • Montgomery's glands of nipples
  • Inner surface of prepuce, clitoris, and labia minora
  • Meibomian glands - palpebral tarsal glands


Exocrine glands can be classified into three subtypes, based on the manner in which their secretions are poured out of the cells:

  1. Apocrine
  2. Merocrine
  3. Holocrine

In apocrine glands, the apical parts of the cells are shed off to discharge the secretion. Examples of apocrine glands are :

  • Secretion of milk fat by mammary glands in the breast (Option A)
  • Ceruminous glands of the external auditory meatus are modified apocrine glands (Option B)
  • Atypical sweat glands in the axilla, perianal region, periumbilical skin, mons pubis (Option C)

Apocrine glands are large glands found in the dermis or subcutaneous fat. They are a type of sweat gland. It consists of a basal secretory coil followed by a straight duct that opens into the pilary canal above the duct of the sebaceous gland. In hairless skin, it directly opens onto the skin surface. 


In merocrine glands, the secretions are initially packed into membrane-bound vesicles, shifted to the cell surface, and poured out by exocytosis. The cell remains intact. The stimulus for secretion is predominantly by raised intracellular calcium. It is the most commonly seen mechanism of exocrine secretion.

An example of the merocrine gland is the simple/typical sweat glands of the skin. An illustration depicting this mechanism is given below:

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman, G2A1, presents with heavy vaginal bleeding with cramp-like abdominal pain at 18 weeks of gestation. On examination, the uterine size corresponds to the period of gestation and  active vaginal bleeding is noted with an open internal os. USG reveals absent fetal cardiac activity. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and examination findings of active vaginal bleeding and open internal os, with the uterine size corresponding to the period of gestation, is suggestive of inevitable abortion.

Inevitable abortion is a type of abortion where the abortive process has progressed to a state where continuation of pregnancy is impossible.

Clinical features:

  • Increased vaginal bleeding as compared to threatened abortion.
  • Aggravated lower abdominal colicky pain
  • Uterine size corresponds to or may be smaller than the period of gestation
  • On examination, dilated internal os through which the products of conception are visualized and felt but has not begun to expel out ( unlike incomplete abortion )
  • USG examination shows absent fetal cardiac activity.

Risk factors:

  • Preterm premature rupture of membranes 
  • Amniocentesis
  • Prior second-trimester delivery
  • Tobacco use
  • Fetal surgery.

Management:

  • IV Methergine is indicated if there is excessive bleeding when the cervix is dilated and uterine size is. <12 weeks.
  • Before 12 weeks:
    • Dilatation and evacuation followed by curettage
    • Alternatively, suction and evacuation.
  • After 12 weeks:
    • Oxytocin drip, 10 units in 500mL of NS at 40-60 drips per minute
    • The separated placenta is removed by ovum forceps and digital separation is indicated if the placenta is not separated.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man had multiple nodular skin lesions for the past 5 years. Previous investigations showed CD 4 T helper cells in these lesions. He has been using topical steroids for its management. He now presents with rapid onset diffuse erythema of the skin. Which of the following will be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Increased CD 8 T cells in the skin
Abnormal T cells with cerebriform nucleus in blood
Increased mast cells around dermal blood vessels

questions.solution:
The given scenario describes the development of Sezary syndrome in a patient with mycosis fungoides. This syndrome shows the presence of abnormal T cells with cerebriform nucleii (Sezary cells) in the blood.

Mycosis fungoides is cutaneous T cell lymphoma (CD4+ Helper T cells) which usually stays confined to the skin. It can disseminate into blood which is known as Sezary syndrome. It presents as diffuse erythema of the skin (erythroderma).

Mycoses fungoides presents as scaly red-brown patches, raised scaling plaques, and fungating nodules. It passes through 3 phases:

  • Inflammatory pre-mycotic phase- eczema like lesions
  • Plaque phase- raised plaques are seen
  • Tumor phase- multiple tumor nodules indicating systemic spread

The given image shows mycosis fungoides:

Sezary syndrome occurs when malignant T cells from mycoses fungoides are seeded into blood. This leads to diffuse erythema and scaling of the entire body surface. The skin lesions in case of Sezary syndrome rarely reach tumefaction phase.

The given image shows erythrodermic sezary syndrome:

questions.text: A 20-year-old college student came to the emergency with complaints of restlessness, flushing of face, and hallucinations. A brown-colored powder was found in his pocket. On examination, multiple injection marks were seen on the left arm. Which of the following is used for the treatment of withdrawal symptoms in this patient?
questions.solution:
Methadone is used to treat the withdrawal symptoms of heroin.

Methadone is a long-acting opioid agonist with pharmacological properties similar to morphine. It has been used as a replacement agent for heroin addiction (available in three varieties: white, brown and black tar). Once stabilized, the dose is gradually reduced and the drug is stopped slowly over days. Because of its long half-life and accumulation in tissues, discontinuing the drug still results in low concentrations of the drug in plasma, resulting in mild but protracted withdrawal symptoms.

Management of heroin addiction:

  • long-acting opioid agonist: a safer substitute like methadone is given in a supervised manner to treat withdrawal symptoms
  • partial agonist: buprenorphine, can also be used
  • Clonidine and lofexidine: alpha-2 agonists act as sympatholytics and reduce withdrawal symptoms
  • Naltrexone: opioid antagonist used in maintenance therapy to prevent relapses. To avoid precipitating withdrawal syndromes, patients should be free of opioids for a minimum of 5-10 days before beginning treatment with naltrexone. 

Other options:

Option B: Naloxone is a rapidly acting opioid antagonist that is used to reverse both central and peripheral opioid effects in the case of acute opioid poisoning or opioid overdose. It is the drug of choice in such cases.

Option D) Haloperidol is a first-generation anti-psychotic drug/typical antipsychotic that acts as a dopamine receptor antagonist used in schizophrenia and acute mania. It is associated with extra-pyramidal side effects and neuroleptic malignant syndrome.

Note: Methadone is the drug of choice used to treat opioid withdrawal symptoms, whereas naltrexone is mainly used to prevent relapses and treat opioid dependence.

questions.text: Which of the following depicts the combination that would form Ceramide?
questions.solution:
Ceramide consists of sphingosine and a fatty acid.

Ceramide can be a component of a phospholipid, but it itself is not a phospholipid. Ceramide is present as a component of:

  •  The phospholipid, sphingomyelin (Sphingomyelin = ceramide + phosphoric acid + choline).
  •  And non-phosphorylated compound lipids like cerebrosides, globosides, and gangliosides (fatty acids esterified with alcohol + contain other groups).

Compound lipids are subclassified based on extra groups as:

  1. Phospholipids (containing phosphoric acid) - Ex: plasmalogens, dipalmitoyl lecithin, cardiolipin, sphingomyelin etc
  2. Non-phosphorylated lipids - Ex: cerebrosides, globosides, gangliosides, sulpholipids etc

questions.text:
A 42-year-old female presents with flaccid bullous lesions involving the oral cavity and the skin. Acantholytic cells are noted on Tzank smear. On immunopathology, fishnet pattern of IgG on suprabasal keratinocytes is noted. Autoantibodies against Dsg3 and Dsg1 are positive. The condition occurs due to which of the following types of hypersensitivity reactions?

Dsg1: Desmoglein 1
Dsg3: Desmoglein 3
questions.solution:
The given clinical condition is pemphigus vulgaris, which is characterized by flaccid bullous lesions involving mucosal surfaces (oral cavity) and skin, acantholytic cells on Tzanck smear, fishnet pattern on immunopathology, and autoantibodies against Dsg1 and Dsg3. Pemphigus vulgaris occurs due to antibody-mediated type II hypersensitivity reaction.

Pemphigus vulgaris is a persistent immunobullous disorder marked by the presence of antibodies targeting desmosomal proteins, which are responsible for intraepidermal intercellular connections. The antibodies target desmoglein 1 and desmoglein 3, which belong to the cadherin family. The primary pathological process is acantholysis.

Acantholysis in the lower spinous cell layers is shown in the histology image below:

Clinically, patients exhibit poorly defined, slow-healing oral lesions and erosions. Fluid-filled blisters, often on an erythematous base, may appear on normal skin. The rupture of these blisters results in painful erosions that heal without scarring. 

Direct immunofluorescence is the most reliable confirmatory test for this condition. It reveals the deposition of IgG and C3 between cells on the surface of keratinocytes across the entire epidermis, presenting a distinctive fishnet/ chickenwire appearance, as depicted below:

Related Pearl: Types of Type II Antibody-Mediated Hypersentivity

There are 3 mechanisms involved in type 2 hypersensitivity reactions- 

  1. Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction- antibodies react with antigens present on cell surfaces or in the extracellular matrix cause disease by destroying these cells, triggering inflammation, or interfering with normal functions
    1. Myasthenia gravis (against acetylcholine receptor)
    2. Graves’ disease (against TSH receptor)
    3. Pemphigus Vulgaris (against epidermal cadherin)
    4. Pernicious anemia (against intrinsic factor)
    5. Insulin resistant diabetes (against insulin receptor
  2. Antibody-mediated opsonization and phagocytosis -antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement and Recruiting Phagocytes
    1. Transfusion reactions
    2. Erythroblastosis fetalis
    3. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
    4. Autoimmune thrombocytopenic purpura
  3. Complement and Fc receptor-mediated inflammation- antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement
    1. Goodpasture syndrome
    2. Vasculitis due to ANCA
    3. Acute rheumatic fever
    4. Vascular rejection in organ graft

questions.text: Which fetal vessel obliterates to give rise to ligamentum teres hepatis?
questions.solution:
Ligamentum teres is a remnant of the Umbilical vein.

The vessels that are occluded soon after birth are in due course replaced by fibrous tissue and forms the following ligaments:

Fetal structure Adult structure
Foramen ovale Fossa ovalis
Umbilical vein Ligamentum teres
Ductus venosus Ligamentum venosum
Umbilicus arteries Medial umbilical ligaments
Ductus arteriosus Ligamentum arteriosum

Clinical correlation :  The umbilical vein is the preferred vessel for an isovolumetric and simultaneous double set up exchange transfusion. The obliterated remnant of the umbilical vein is the Ligamentum teres. Generally, a Cord blood bilirubin level of more than 4 mg/dL is an indication for exchange transfusion in a neonate. 

 Note :

The median umbilical ligament or Xander's ligament represents the remnant of the embryonic urachus.

The lateral umbilical ligaments are folds of the peritoneum over the inferior epigastric arteries.

Alternatively, the exchange may be performed through peripheral arterial (drawn out) and venous (infused in) lines.

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of fever and right upper quadrant pain, following consumption of certain aquatic plants. Blood test reveals eosinophilia and stool sample reveals the egg of a certain parasite, as shown in the image. Which of the following best describes the adult form of the microbe involved?

choices.text: Arise from the excystation of cercariae
Need two hosts for the completion of sexual phase
Reside in the vesical and pelvic plexus of veins
Have the potential to cause obstructive jaundice

questions.solution:
The history along with the given image suggests infection with Fasciola hepatica, which produces eggs that are ovoid, operculated and bile stained. Chronic infection with this parasite is known to cause obstructive jaundice.

Fasciola hepatica, also called the sheep liver fluke, is a trematode that passes its life cycle in one definitive host and two intermediate hosts :

  • Definitive host(for sexual phase): Sheep, goat, cattle, and man.
  • Intermediate hosts(for the asexual phase): Snails of the genus Lymnaea and Succinea, which are the first intermediate hosts.
    Encystment occurs on aquatic plants, which act as the second intermediate host.

Mode of infection - The definitive host, sheep and man get the infection by the ingestion of metacercariae encysted on the aquatic vegetation. The metacercariae excyst in the duodenum, pierce the gut wall and reach the liver and biliary passages, where they mature into adult worms. These worms lay eggs in the biliary passages, which are shed in the feces.

The clinical features include fever, tender hepatomegaly, right upper quadrant pain, obstructive jaundice and eosinophilia. Diagnosis is made by the detection of eggs in stool and aspirated bile. 

Oral triclabendazole (10 mg/kg once) is the treatment of choice.

questions.text: A newborn infant is diagnosed with a congenital urethral abnormality in which the urethral meatus opens on the ventral side of the penis. Which of the following statements regarding this condition is false?

choices.text: Circumcision is avoided in these patients
Dorsal aspect of the prepuce is poorly developed
Usually associated with a ventral deformity of the erect penis
Does not cause obstruction in the urinary tract

questions.solution:
The ventral aspect of the prepuce is poorly developed ("hooded prepuce") in hypospadias.

Hypospadias is the most common congenital abnormality of the urethra. It is characterized by the combination of a ventrally (underside of penis or perineum) placed urethral meatus, a hooded foreskin, and ventral chordee (bending of the penis).

Types of hypospadias (according to meatal location):

  • Anterior (Distal)
    • Glanular (most common)
    • Coronal
  • Middle
    • Middle penile shaft
    • Distal penile shaft
  • Posterior (Proximal)
    • Proximal penile shaft
    • Penoscrotal
    • Scrotal
    • Perineal

Note:

In hypospadias, ventral chordee is seen, whereas, in epispadias, dorsal chordee is seen.

Circumcision is contraindicated in hypospadias because the foreskin may be used later for reconstruction.

Hypospadias does not cause either obstruction or urinary tract infection.

questions.text: Which of the following glycogen storage disorders does not involve the muscle?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, von Gierke's disease does not have muscle involvement.

von Gierke's disease is caused by the absence or deficiency of the enzyme glucose-6-phosphatase in the liver, kidney, and intestinal mucosa. The clinical manifestations include:

  • Seizures
  • Doll-like facies (fat cheeks and relatively thin extremities)
  • Hepatomegaly
  • Growth retardation
  • Hypoglycemia 
  • Elevated blood uric acid levels 
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Elevated cholesterol and triglycerides
  • Neutropenia (specific to type Ib)

The management of the condition involves the maintenance of blood glucose levels by infusion of glucose or the use of uncooked cornstarch. Restriction of lactose, fructose, and sucrose is recommended. Supplementation and adequate intake of vitamins and minerals are ensured. Allopurinol is indicated for hyperuricemia if uncontrolled on dietary therapy.

Other options:

Option A: Pompe's disease is characterized by hypotonia (floppy infant), skeletal muscle weakness, hepatomegaly, cardiomyopathy, macroglossia, and cardiomegaly on chest X-ray. It occurs due to α-1,4-glucosidase (acid maltase) deficiency.

Option B: Andersen's disease is characterized by growth delay, hepatomegaly, and myopathy. There may be fasting intolerance and ketosis in the initial stages. Hypoglycemia usually appears late in the disease. It occurs due to a deficiency of glycogen branching enzyme.

Option C: McArdle's disease presents during late childhood or in the second decade of life. It is characterized by exercise intolerance associated with muscle cramps. Myoglobinuria secondary to rhabdomyolysis leads to the passage of burgundy-colored urine in some patients. It occurs due to a deficiency of muscle glycogen phosphorylase enzyme.

questions.text: An ophthalmological examination of a patient shows the following findings. This is likely to be the result of:

choices.text: Blunt trauma to the eye causing pigment deposition
Age-related lipid degeneration of the cornea

questions.solution:
The finding given in the image is that of a Vossius ring.

Vossius ring is a circular ring of faint or stippled opacity, seen on the anterior surface of the lens due to brown amorphous granules of pigment lying on the capsule of the lens. It is usually seen after blunt trauma to the eye and orbit.

It usually has about the same diameter as the contracted pupil. The force of the blow drives the cornea and iris backward and thus producing an impression of the iris on the lens. The resorption of the pigment results in discrete subcapsular opacities.

Corneal epithelial iron deposits are seen in keratoconus and are called Fleischer's ring. It is seen best with a cobalt blue filter. Slit-lamp examination reveals Fleischer's ring at the base of the cone formed.

Intraocular deposition of copper is seen in Wilson's disease and would result in a KF ring/ Kayser-Fleischer ring on the cornea. A brownish-yellow zone is seen in the peripheral Descemet membrane of the cornea. Anterior capsular cataract, also knowns as a sunflower cataract may be seen in some patients.

Age-related lipid degeneration of the cornea would result in Arcus lipoides/ Arcus senilis/ Gerontoxon. Arcus senilis (AS) is usually an age-related lipid degeneration of the peripheral cornea that forms a light grey or bluish ring. It is the most common peripheral corneal opacity and is usually found in the elderly where it is considered a benign condition.

When AS is found in patients less than 40 years old it is termed arcus juvenilis. It represents an increased risk for cardiovascular disease and warrants screening for an underlying lipid disorder. AS is caused by leakage of lipoproteins (phospholipids and cholesterol) from limbal capillaries into the corneal stroma.

  • Deposition begins at the superior and inferior aspects and progresses to encircle the entire peripheral cornea which is about 1 mm wide.
  • The peripheral border of this ring opacity is sharp while the central border is diffuse.
  • The exterior border of AS and the limbus is separated by a clear zone of the cornea called the interval of Vogt. (limbal sparing)

Noticing that the image shows the deposition within the area of the pupil, and hence indicated a likely deposition on the lens and not the cornea, would have helped rule out the other three options.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman presents to the OPD with complaints of on-and-off back pain and stiffness in the morning that improves with exercise. Lately, she has been having persistent back pain and restricted chest movements. A CT scan was performed and is shown below. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Earliest X-ray finding is bamboo spine appearance
There is a strong association with HLA B27
Young males are more commonly affected

questions.solution:
The clinical description and CT image showing bony ankylosis of the spine continuously involving the thoracolumbar vertebral bodies is suggestive of ankylosing spondylitis. Continuous ossification of the anterior longitudinal ligament is present. The earliest/cardinal sign is erosion and fuzziness of the sacroiliac joints.

Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic progressive inflammatory condition of the sacroiliac joints and the axial skeleton. It has a strong association with the HLAB27 genetic marker. It commonly involves young male adults.

Diagnostic criteria for ankylosing spondylitis:

  • Insidious onset
  • Morning stiffness 
  • Symptoms begin early at age <40 years
  • Improvement with exercise
  • Persistence for >3 months  

Examination findings:

  • Loss of lumbar lordosis
  • Increased thoracic kyphosis
  • Diminished spinal movements
  • Decreased chest expansion ( <7 cm)
  • Positive tests for sacroiliac joint involvement

Important X-ray features:

  • Sacro-iliac joints:
    • Cardinal sign/earliest sign– erosion and fuzziness of the sacroiliac joints
    • Later- peri-articular sclerosis and bony ankylosis of the joint
  • Vertebral changes:
    • Earliest- flattening of the normal anterior concavity of the vertebral body (‘squaring’)
    • Later- ossification of the ligaments around the intervertebral discs produces syndesmophytes (bridges) between adjacent vertebrae
    • Bamboo spine appearance- due to bridging at several vertebral levels

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is inhibited by a sweet pea (Lathyrus odoratus) toxin causing lathyrism?
questions.solution:
The enzyme lysyl oxidase is inhibited by the sweet pea(Lathyrus odoratus)toxin causing lathyrism.

Lysyl oxidase is a copper-containing enzyme that is involved in the formation of cross-links in collagen synthesis. Inhibition of the enzyme by the sweat pea toxin leads to defective collagen formation and leads to lathyrism.  

Lathyrism is a paralyzing disease of humans and animals. It is due to the consumption of Khesari dal/Lathyrus sativus or its variants such as sweet pea(Lathyrus odoratus). It is mostly consumed by agricultural labourers of poor economic status because it is relatively cheap. 

It can present as skeletal, vascular or neural manifestations. Beta-oxalyl-amino-alanine (BOAA) is the toxic compound causing lathyrism.

The water-soluble property of the toxin is used in removing it from the pulses by soaking it in hot water and rejecting the soaked water. Vitamin C in doses of 500-1000 mg can be used for the prevention and treatment of lathyrism. 

 Note - Cytochrome c oxidase, superoxide dismutase and tyrosinase are other examples of copper-containing enzymes.

questions.text:

questions.solution:
The given mammogram of a patient portrays oval masses with coarse calcifications which is a popcorn calcification of stroma and is a common finding in Fibroadenoma of the breast. As per the ANDI classification of benign breast disorders, Fibroadenoma is considered a disorder of the early reproductive years ( 15-25 y ). 

Fibroadenoma arises from hyperplasia of a single lobule and presents as a well-circumscribed, smooth, firm, non-tender, solitary, freely mobile mass (mouse in the breast). They are surrounded by a well-marked capsule and can thus be enucleated through a cosmetically appropriate incision.

questions.text: A middle aged female presents with persistent redness and photophobia of the eye despite conservative management. An image of a characteristic lesion of her eye is shown below. Identify the true statement regarding this condition.

choices.text: It is an immune-complex reaction in the eye
Topical steroids can worsen the condition
S. aureus is a common organism implicated

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario with persistent redness and photophobia of the eye and characteristic lesion "phlycten" suggests phlyctenular keratoconjunctivitis. S. aureus is commonly implicated in this condition.

Phlycten is a white-pinkish nodule surrounded by hyperemia on the bulbar conjunctiva near the limbus seen in phlyctenular conjunctivitis.

Phlyctenular keratoconjunctivitis is a nodular affection and a delayed hypersensitivity (type 4) (Option A) reaction due to endogenous allergens like proteins of Staphylococcus aureus (most common), Mycobacterium tuberculosis (common in India) and proteins of Moraxella axenfield.

It is a unilateral disease (Option D) common in undernourished young girls living in overcrowded and unhygienic conditions in developing countries.

It is characterized by the following:

  • Phlycten that may eventually form ring ulcers
  • Shallow marginal ulcer due to the breakdown of limbal phlycten known as scrofulous ulcer
  • Fascicular ulcer with a prominent parallel leash of blood vessels that heals leaving a band-shaped opacity

It is a self-limiting disease and phlycten can disappear in 8-10 days with no scarring but it has a high chance of recurrence.

Treatment: Topical steroids (dexamethasone or betamethasone) (Option B); atropine if the cornea is involved and antibiotic drops to avoid secondary bacterial infection. Associated systemic tuberculous disease, septic foci (tonsilitis or adenoiditis), and parasitic infections should be ruled out.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male patient came with complaints of pain over the heel that is most severe while taking the first step in the morning. On examination, localized tenderness was present over the medial aspect beneath the heel. A radiograph of his foot is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of pain and tenderness over the heel which worsens on standing or walking after rest and an X-ray showing a calcaneal spur is suggestive of plantar fasciitis. 

Plantar fasciitis is a painful condition of the sole of the foot that limits normal functions. The plantar fascia or aponeurosis is seen to be thickened, stiff, and may have micro-tears. Typically, the pain worsens while patients stand or walk from a resting position, often when waking up in the morning.

They have a localized tenderness at the medial aspect beneath the heel. An X-ray often shows a calcaneal spur which is associated with plantar fasciitis.

It is managed with proper rest and NSAIDs. Night splints can be used for the prevention of stiffening of the plantar fascia.

Other options:

Option A: Achilles tendinitis is a condition with pain and swelling around the Achilles tendon due to local irritation. It's often seen in athletes and hikers. 

Option C: Traction apophysitis is a traction injury. It is also known as Sever's disease. It is predominantly seen in boys of age around 10 years. They mostly present with pain and tenderness at the Achilles tendon insertion. X-ray shows increased density and fragmentation of the apophysis. 

Option D: Tarsal tunnel syndrome is a condition with pain and sensory disturbance occurring in the medial part of the forefoot, unrelated to weight-bearing. This is due to compression of the posterior tibial nerve behind and below the medial malleolus. Typically the pain worsens at night and gets relieved on walking or stamping the foot.

questions.text: An elderly female patient presented with signs and symptoms of essential tremor caused due to progressive degeneration of the cells that form the output of the cerebellar cortex. Which of the following cells are affected?
questions.solution:
Purkinje cells are the affected cells in this patient as they form the only output neurons of the cerebellar cortex.

The only output from the cerebellar cortex is inhibitory from the purkinje cells to the deep cerebellar nuclei(Fastigial, Globose, Emboliform, and Dentate).

The Purkinje layer is the middle layer of the cerebellar cortex. It contains flask-shaped cell bodies of Purkinje cells. Their dendrites pass into the molecular layer. The axons of the purkinje cells passes through the granular layer into the white matter and synapses with the deep cerebellar nuclei.

The output from the  whole cerebellum is from deep cerebellar nuclei

  • Globose, emboliform, and dentate nuclei give output via superior cerebellar peduncle
  • Fastigial nuclei give output via inferior cerebellar peduncle

Related Pearl: Layers of the cerebellar cortex

The cerebellar cortex is divided into 3 layers. They are:

  • Molecular layer - It is the outermost layer. It contains stellate cells and basket cells. They receive excitatory input from the parallel fibers and form inhibitory synapses on the Purkinje cells. It contains many myelinated and unmyelinated nerve fibers giving it a pale appearance in H and E staining.
  • Purkinje layer - It is the middle layer. It contain flask-shaped cell bodies of Purkinje cells. Their dendrites pass into the molecular layer. The axons of the Purkinje cells passes through the granular layer into the white matter and synapses with the cerebellar nuclei.
  • Granular layer - It is the innermost layer. It contains the cell bodies of the granule cells as well as Golgi cells. It receives excitatory input from the mossy fibers. They end on the dendrites of the granule cells and these complexes are called glomeruli. The axon from the granule cells travels to the molecular layer and bifurcates in a T-shape. These branches form the T and are called parallel fibers. These parallel fibers form excitatory synapses with the Purkinje cells. The granule cells form the only excitatory neurons in the cerebellar cortex. Golgi cells receive input from parallel fibers and mossy fibers. They send inhibitory output to the granule cells.

Neurotransmitters released:

  • Stellate, basket, Golgi and Purkinje cells- GABA
  • Granule cells - Glutamate

The only output from the cerebellar cortex is inhibitory from the Purkinje cells to the deep cerebellar nuclei.

Related Pearl: Cerebellar Circuitry

Cerebellar circuitry includes:

Afferents- Climbing and mossy fibers

  • Climbing fibers -
    • Origin - contralateral inferior olivary nucleus in the medulla oblongata
    • Terminates on - Purkinje cell
  • Mossy fibers -
    • Origin - multiple sources in the spinal cord and brainstem
    • Terminates on - Granule cell

Intrinsic components

  • Granule cell backward inhibition - done by Golgi cells- prevent transmission from mossy fibers to the granule cells
  • Purkinje cells forward inhibition- done by stellate and basket cells

Efferents -

  • The output from the cerebellar cortex - from Purkinje cells inhibitory output to the deep cerebellar nuclei
  • The output from the cerebellum - from deep cerebellar nuclei
    • Globose, emboliform, and dentate - via superior cerebellar peduncle
    • Fastigial - via inferior cerebellar peduncle

questions.text: Which of the following is involved in eliciting tickle and itch sensations?
questions.solution:
Itch and tickle sensations are elicited by the stimulation of free nerve endings of unmyelinated type C nerve fibers.

The free nerve ends are rapidly adapting mechanoreceptors and are present only in the superficial layers of the skin. After these fibers synapse in the spinal cord, the sensations are carried in the contralateral anterolateral spinothalamic tract.

The same type-C fibers are also involved in carrying sensations of slow pain. The itch sensation calls attention to mild surface stimuli such as a flea crawling on the skin or a fly about to bite. These signals later activate the scratch reflex. This way by scratching one gets relieved of the itch. Sometimes, this scratching action can be strong enough to elicit pain. These pain signals suppress the itch signals in the cord by lateral inhibition. 

Related Pearl: Sensory Receptors

questions.text: A 58-year-old female presents with a gradually enlarging, erythematous, and eczematous lesion involving the nipple and areola of her left breast. Biopsy shows the following finding. A triple assessment reveals no underlying malignancy. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?

choices.text: Central core excision followed by radiotherapy
Central core excision followed by chemotherapy

questions.solution:
The given scenario is of Paget's disease of the breast, characterized by a red eczematous nipple lesion and biopsy findings of large, pale, intraepithelial cells with round/oval nuclei and large nucleoli called Paget cells. In cases of Paget's disease of the breast without underlying malignancy, central core excision of the nipple-areolar complex followed by radiotherapy is often the preferred treatment.

Paget's disease is a type of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) arising in the nipple. It is an uncommon presentation of breast carcinoma affecting women between 50 and 60 years of age. Patients may initially have pain, burning, and pruritus of the nipple. On examination, a crusted lesion with irregular borders or a scaly, raw, vesicular, or ulcerated lesion that begins over the nipple and spreads to the surrounding areola is seen. This may be accompanied by a bloody discharge.

Although Paget's disease is usually unilateral, a bilateral breast examination should be done. A full-thickness wedge or punch biopsy of the nipple shows the presence of Paget cells. They are often large cells with pale cytoplasm and high-grade nuclei with prominent nucleoli. Paget cells migrate through the lactiferous ducts into the nipple epidermis. It may spread outward from the nipple onto the areola and the surrounding skin. Paget cells do not invade the dermal basement membrane and are hence categorized as carcinoma-in-situ.

Triple assessment is done to exclude underlying malignancy. Cases with no underlying malignancy are managed by central core excision, removing a cone of major milk ducts, nipple, and areola. It is followed by radiotherapy. 

Cases with underlying malignancy are treated with mastectomy and assessment of axillary lymph node status (Options C and D).

questions.text: The given image shows the synthesis and release of GABA at the nerve terminal. Identify the antiepileptic that mainly acts at site A.
questions.solution:
The structure marked as A is a GABA transporter. The drug that acts on GABA transporter is tiagabine. It inhibits the neuronal uptake of GABA and prolongs its time in the synaptic cleft, where the GABA molecules can activate GABA receptors.

  • Activation of GABA B receptors - Baclofen

questions.text: The carnitine shuttle is essential for the transport of fatty acids across the mitochondrial membrane. Which of the following biochemical findings do you expect to find in a patient with carnitine deficiency?
questions.solution:
Carnitine deficiency is characterized by hypoketotic hypoglycemia with associated hyperammonemia. Hence, a patient with this disorder will have low blood glucose and low blood ketones (option D). 

The carnitine shuttle plays a very important role in the transport of long-chain fatty acids (LCFAs) across the mitochondrial membrane for the beta-oxidation of the LCFAs. LCFAs are converted in the cytosol to long-chain fatty acyl-CoAs. These compounds diffuse through the outer mitochondrial membrane where they are converted to acylcarnitine by the enzyme carnitine palmitoyltransferase-1. The acylcarnitine so formed can penetrate the inner mitochondrial membrane. This is how fatty acids reach the mitochondrial matrix. The acyl group is transferred back to CoA, restoring acyl-CoA and liberating carnitine, which is moved back to the intermembrane space.

Carnitine deficiency results in impaired transport of LCFAs into mitochondria and impaired beta-oxidation, in the face of depletion of glucose stores in the body. This results in reduced energy production from fatty acids and reduced ketone formation, resulting in the characteristic hypoketotic hypoglycemia.The associated hyperammonemia results from the decreased expression of enzymes in the urea cycle.

The role of carnitine in the metabolism of fatty acids is demonstrated in the image below:

Clinical features of carnitine deficiency begin in childhood and include poor feeding, lethargy, liver dysfunction and hepatomegaly, hypotonia, and dilated cardiomyopathy. Treatment involves oral supplementation of carnitine.

questions.text: A patient presents with chronic diarrhea, weight loss, and right lower quadrant pain. Colonoscopy shows the presence of skip lesions. Biopsy findings are shown below. Which of the following antibodies is likely to be positive in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with chronic diarrhea, weight loss, right lower quadrant pain, colonoscopy showing skip lesions, and biopsy findings of characteristic non-caseating granulomas is suggestive of Crohn's disease (CD). Patients with this condition show increased titers of anti–Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibody (ASCA). 

CD is characterized by acute or chronic inflammation of the bowel. The most commonly involved site is the terminal ileum because of which patients present with diarrhea and right lower quadrant pain. Extensive inflammation can result in malabsorption and steatorrhea. 

Blood investigations may reveal anemia, elevated ESR and CRP. Fecal calprotectin and lactoferrin levels are used to rule out irritable bowel syndrome and as a marker of ileo-colonic inflammation. A colonoscopy is done as part of the evaluation. It shows characteristic skip lesions and a cobblestone appearance. Biopsy shows transmural inflammation with non-caseating granulomas. 

Serological markers that are usually positive in patients with CD include the anti–Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibody (ASCA). Other positive markers (however, with low sensitivity) include antibodies to bacterial proteins (OmpC and I2), flagellin, and bacterial carbohydrates.

Other options:

Options A and D: Anti-endomysial antibodies and anti-gliadin antibodies are positive in patients with celiac disease. Patients can present with chronic diarrhea and abdominal pain. However, a small intestinal biopsy in this condition shows villous atrophy and lymphocytic infiltration. 

Option C: Anti-parietal cell antibody is positive in patients with pernicious anemia. The resultant vitamin B12 deficiency causes anemia and neurological manifestations such as peripheral neuropathy and subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord.

questions.text: Following a road traffic accident, a patient presents to the emergency department with complaints of pain and swelling over his right shoulder. On examination, there is no neurovascular deficit. X-ray confirms fracture of the right clavicle. Which of the following is true with respect to this condition?

choices.text: The fracture is likely to be at the junction of inner and middle third of clavicle
The outer fragment is displaced upwards by the pull of sternocleidomastoid muscle
The most common complication is non union
Conservative management is followed in majority of the cases

questions.solution:
Conservative management is followed in majority of the cases of fracture clavicle. 

The fracture of the clavicle is a common fracture in all age groups. It usually results from a fall on the shoulder or sometimes on an outstretched hand. The junction of the middle and outer third of the clavicle is the commonest site.

The outer fragment displaces medially and downwards because of the gravity and pull by the pectoralis major muscle. The inner fragment displaces upwards because of the pull by the sternocleidomastoid muscle. 

Treatment :

Fractures of the clavicle unite readily even if displaced, hence reduction of the fragment is not essential. A triangular sling is sufficient in cases with minimum displacement. A figure-of-8 bandage may be applied to a young adult with a displaced fracture. Open reduction and internal fixation is required, either when the fracture is associated with neurovascular deficit, or in some severely displaced fractures, where it may be more of a cosmetic concern. In such cases, the fracture is fixed internally with a plate or a nail. 

Complications :

The fractured fragment may injure the subclavian vessels or brachial plexus. 

Malunion is very common due to difficulty in holding the fracture fragments in position because of the distracting forces already explained. It causes only a cosmetic problem and does not usually impair function. Hence, no treatment is required.

Non-union is a very rare complication.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man presents to the emergency after falling down some steps at his home. He admits to having a few drinks which made him lose balance. Physical examination reveals some bruises over the left face and left arm. There are no neurological deficits. According to the NEXUS criteria, which of the following is an indication for cervical spine imaging in this patient?

NEXUS - National Emergency X-Radiography Utilization Study
questions.solution:
According to the NEXUS criteria, this patient needs to have a cervical spine imaging because of his history of alcohol intoxication.

The NEXUS criteria is a clinical screening and decision-making tool used for evaluating the need for imaging in a patient with a suspected cervical spine injury. It consists of the following:

  • Neurological deficits
  • Ethanol (alcohol) intoxication
  • eXtreme distracting injuries
  • Unable to provide history
  • midline Spinal tenderness

The presence of any one of the above criteria is an indication for cervical spine imaging.

Patients are considered intoxicated if they have either of the following:

  • a recent history of alcohol ingestion (like in this patient which contributed to the fall)
  • evidence of intoxication on examination. This may include alcohol odor in breath or cerebellar findings consistent with intoxication

Extreme distracting injuries include long bone fractures, crush injuries, large lacerations, burns, or any other injury causing gross functional impairment. These are conditions that produce a lot of pain and can cause the patient to be "distracted" from a spine injury or neck pain. This patient's examination findings of bruises over the left face and left arm are not considered distracting injuries (option D). 

If the criteria is met, the imaging of choice is CT cervical spine. Alternatively, AP and lateral X-rays of the cervical spine can also be used for evaluation. 

The age of the patient (option A) and the nature or mechanism of injury (option B) are not a part of the criteria.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old primigravida with a previous history of infertility who conceived by in-vitro fertilization came to ANC at 28 weeks. On examination, the fundal height is more than the period of gestation with two separate fetal heart sounds heard. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the diagnosis?

USG - Ultrasound
questions.solution:
The clinical history of in-vitro fertilization and examination findings of fundal height more than the period of gestation with  2 separate fetal heart sounds heard is suggestive of multifetal pregnancy.

α-fetoprotein, Maternal serum gonadotropin, and unconjugated estriol are approximately double that of singleton pregnancy.

Maternal complications of multifetal pregnancy: 

  • Nausea, vomiting
  • Anemia
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Polyhydramnios / oligohydramnios
  • Preterm labor
  • Malpresentation
  • Antepartum hemorrhage
  • Mechanical distress (dyspnea, palpitations)
  • Prolonged labor

Fetal complications of multifetal pregnancy:

  • Abortion
  • Vanishing twin/ fetal papyraceous
  • Preterm birth
  • Low birth weight babies
  • Fetal anomalies
  • Discordant growth
  • Intrauterine death of one fetus
  • Twin-twin transfusion syndrome 

Other options:

Option C: Preterm labor is a complication of multifetal pregnancy and the average gestation period for twins is 37 weeks 

Option D: Increased incidence of megaloblastic anemia. Anemia is more due to increased iron and folic acid requirements by two fetuses. A deficiency of folic acid leads to an increased incidence of megaloblastic anemia.

questions.text: You are a researcher studying the mechanism of action of statins which inhibit the enzyme HMG-CoA reductase by acting as a structural analog to its natural substrate. The Lineweaver Burk Plot for the interaction is given below. Which of the following is true about this type of inhibition?
questions.solution:
The given example of statin inhibiting cholesterol synthesis by acting on HMG-CoA reductase and the graph is a type of competitive inhibition. True about competitive inhibition is that the Km of the reaction increases.

Important parameters in a reaction include:

  • The affinity of the enzyme for its substrate is given by the Michaelis constant or Km. A low Km reflects a high affinity of the enzyme for substrate and vice versa. The value of Km is given by the substrate concentration at which the reaction velocity is equal to one-half Vmax. It does not change with changes in enzyme concentration. 
  • The rate of the reaction is directly proportional to the enzyme concentration.

Competitive inhibition is when the inhibitor binds reversibly to the substrate-binding site and competes with the substrate for the active enzyme binding site.

This effect of competitive inhibition can be overcome by increasing the substrate concentration by which maximum velocity can still be achieved. Therefore, Vmax is unaltered in this type of inhibition. However, the concentration of the substrate required to achieve half of the maximum velocity is increased. Therefore, Km is increased in this condition.

Noncompetitive inhibition is by binding of inhibitors to enzymes in locations remote from the active site. Increasing the concentration of the substrate does not overcome non-competitive inhibition. Thus, noncompetitive inhibitors decrease the Vmax of the reaction. They do not interfere with the binding of the substrate to the enzyme. Thus, the enzyme shows the same Km in the presence or absence of noncompetitive inhibitors.

Graph showing the changes in Vmax and Km in competitive and noncompetitive inhibition.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man was admitted to the hospital with difficulty in breathing. He had puffiness around the eyes, pitting edema of the lower limbs, and ascites. His 24-hour urine protein shows a protein level of 4 g/24h. CT chest shows a saddle embolus. What is the cause of this patient's CT findings?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of a diagnosis of nephrotic syndrome complicated by pulmonary embolism. Thrombo-embolic complications in nephrotic syndrome are due to the loss of endogenous anticoagulants such as antithrombin III in the urine.

Nephrotic syndrome is a condition that occurs due to damage in the glomerular capillary walls thereby leading to increased capillary permeability to plasma proteins.

The manifestations and the mechanisms of nephrotic syndrome are:

  • Massive proteinuria (>3.5 grams) as a result of leakage in the barrier formed by glomerular basement membrane, endothelium, and visceral epithelial cells.
  • Hypoalbuminemia (albumin <3g/dL) occurs as a consequence of proteinuria. Also, increased catabolism of the kidney contributes to hypoalbuminemia. 
  • Generalized edema is seen. The edema is soft and pitting seen in periorbital and dependent portions of the body. It occurs as a result of decreased intravascular colloid osmotic pressure and other factors like sodium and water retention lead to edema. 
  • Hyperlipidemia occurs following the increased synthesis of lipoproteins, lipid particles, and decreased catabolism of lipids.
  • Lipiduria is due to leakage of lipids through the glomerular capillary wall.

Increased susceptibility to infections is another complication. It is due to the loss of immunoglobulins in the urine.

The CT image below depicts a large pulmonary embolism at the pulmonary artery bifurcation (saddle embolism).

questions.text: An elderly male with advanced prostatic carcinoma suffers from compression of the nerve that passes through the obturator foramen. Which of the following functions would be affected?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of compression of the obturator nerve which affects the adduction of the thigh and also the medial rotation of the thigh  

The obturator nerve, which is a branch of the lumbar plexus, is the primary nerve responsible for the medial compartment of the thigh. Its compression affects the medial compartment actions including adduction and medial rotation of the thigh. The ventral divisions of the anterior primary rami of spinal nerves L2,3,4 form the obturator nerve. The proximal part of the nerve is located in the pelvis, and it enters the thigh via the obturator canal. 

In these cases, the pain from the thigh is due to the compression of the anterior or geniculate branch of the obturator nerve. This is also known as the Howship-Romberg sign. The pain in the anteromedial aspect of the thigh is relieved by thigh flexion. 

It provides motor innervation to the Adductor longus, adductor brevis, gracilis, obturator externus and ischiocondylar part of adductor magnus muscle, and sensory supply to the skin of the proximal part of the medial thigh, hip joint, and knee joint.

Clinical significance:

  • In certain cases of spastic paraplegia that are hard to manage, spasms of the adductors of the thigh can be relieved by surgically dividing the obturator nerve. 
  • A hip joint pathology can cause referred pain in the knee, as well as on the medial side of the thigh. This occurs because both areas share a common nerve supply provided by the obturator nerve.

questions.text: There is a structure that is related to the area marked "A" in the diagram. The same structure passes through the diaphragm.  At what vertebral level does it pass through the diaphragm?
questions.solution:
The diagram shown is of the right lung identified by the presence of hyparterial and eparterial bronchus at the hilum and the area marked A is where the azygos vein arches over the hilum of the right lung. It passes through the diaphragm at the T12 level (through the aortic hiatus).

The right lung hilar structures from superior to inferior:

  • Superior lobar bronchus
  • Pulmonary artery
  • Principal bronchus
  • Inferior pulmonary vein  

The medial surface of the lung is connected to the heart and trachea by a group of structures that enter or leave the hilum. It is called the pulmonary root. It is anteriorly related to the phrenic nerve, pericardiacophrenic vessels, and anterior pulmonary plexus. The vagus nerve and posterior pulmonary plexus form the posterior relation and the pulmonary ligament the inferior relation. 

The superior vena cava and right atrium are seen in front of the right root and terminal part of the azygos vein superiorly.

The diaphragm is a domed musculofibrous sheet that separates the thoracic and abdominopelvic cavities. It is supplied by the phrenic nerve whose root values are C3, C4, and C5.
