questions.text: You are conducting a survey to investigate the prevalence of hypertension in a community. The data collected from individuals shows an association between obesity, decreased physical activity, and hypertension. Which of the following best describes this type of study?
questions.solution:
The study design shown here to investigate the prevalence of hypertension and its associations in a community at one point in time best describes a cross-sectional study.

A cross-sectional study is the simplest observational study which involves the examination of a population at a particular point in time. It can be used to determine the prevalence of a disease and the prevalence of associated variables of interest. Thus, it is also known as a "prevalence study."

Cross-sectional studies are particularly useful in determining the prevalence of chronic diseases like hypertension. It helps us determine associations (eg. obesity and decreased physical activity in this case) and for planning how to address the prevention of the disease. However, we cannot determine causality from a cross-sectional study. Observational studies only help us determine associations which can then be tested for causality by analytical studies.

Other options:

Option A: An ecological study assesses an entire population as a whole. The study is done at the population level using population-based data. The study described here uses data at an individual level.

Option B: Case series is a compilation of similar cases of a particular disease. It is mostly used in hospital-based studies or healthcare surveys. 

Option D: A cohort study, which can be either prospective or retrospective, is done for a group of individuals who have been or haven't been exposed to a particular risk factor. It is done over a period of time to determine causality. It also tells us about the incidence of diseases. 

Related Pearl: Descriptive Epidemiology

Descriptive Epidemiology

  • Descriptive studies are used to describe a disease of unknown etiology.
  • Steps
    • Defining the population to be studied
    • Defining the disease to be studied
    • Describing the disease by time, place, and person
      • Measurement of the disease by cross sectional or longitudinal study
      • Comparing with known indices
      • Formulation of an etiological hypothesis
  • Uses
    • Provides data of magnitude of disease load in community
    • Provides clues to disease etiology
    • Provides background data for health planning
    • Contributes to research by describing the disease

questions.text:
The given reaction is a component of the free radical scavenging systems in the human body. Defective enzyme in this pathway is associated with which of the following conditions?

O2.   + O2.  + 2H+ ------> H2O2 + O2
questions.solution:
The defective enzyme in the given pathway of free radical scavenging system is superoxide dismutase, which is seen in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.

The human body has several pathways to detoxify free radicals. Superoxide dismutase (SOD) is an enzyme that converts superoxides to hydrogen peroxide and oxygen. A defect in the SOD gene causes misfolding and accumulation of protein aggregates (gain-of-function phenotype), leading to amyotrophic lateral sclerosis(ALS), which is characterized by neuronal injury, especially in the anterior horn cells of the spinal cord.

Clinical manifestations of ALS include -

  • Initially, it presents as asymmetrical weakness in the distal part of the upper limb characterised by wasting, atrophy and absent motor reflex. Later other limbs are affected and extensors are involved more than flexors in the hand.
  • Progresses to bulbar/pseudobulbar involvement leading to dysphagia, dysarthria, chewing and movements of the face and tongue. Rarely, early involvement of the muscles of respiration may lead to death before the disease is far advanced. Pseudobulbar involvement is characterised by emotional incontinence.
  • Upper motor neuron features such as brisk reflexes, and loss of dexterity can be seen leading to inability to perform complex activities.

Importantly sensory, bowel and bladder dysfunction and cognitive dysfunction are unaffected. Also, ocular motility is spared until very late stages of the illness. Familial ALS is sometimes associated with frontotemporal dementia.

Tofersen is an antisense oligonucleotide indicated for treating Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) in adults with a mutation in the superoxide dismutase 1 (SOD1) gene. It acts by causing degradation of SOD1 mRNA after binding to it, which results in a reduction of SOD1 protein synthesis. Riluzole and edaravone are other drugs used in the management of ALS.

Other options -

Option A - In the next step of the above reaction, hydrogen peroxide is removed by glutathione peroxidase. The reduced form of glutathione is regenerated with the help of NADPH produced in the HMP shunt pathway, by the enzyme glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase. Deficiency of this enzyme causes hemolytic anemia in the presence of oxidizing agents, like certain drugs.

Option B - Chronic granulomatous disease is caused by a deficiency in NADPH oxidase, which converts molecular oxygen to superoxide, which is bactericidal. The disease is characterized by recurrent pneumonia, subcutaneous abscesses, and granulomas at multiple sites, caused by catalase-positive organisms.

Option C - Wilson disease is caused by a defect in the gene ATP7B on chromosome 13, which results in decreased biliary copper excretion and its accumulation in the liver. It is known to cause hepatolenticular degeneration. Serum ceruloplasmin levels are decreased.

questions.text: The clinical examination of a child with cerebral palsy is demonstrated below. What neuropathological finding is most likely associated with this condition?

choices.text: Focal infarct of the cerebral cortex

questions.solution:
The given image shows the scissoring posture of the lower extremities which is characteristically seen in the spastic diplegia type of cerebral palsy. The most common neuropathological finding associated with spastic diplegia is periventricular leukomalacia.

Cerebral palsy is classified into several types based on its clinical features.

Spastic diplegia is commonly seen in premature infants with a history of birth asphyxia. It is 2nd most common type of cerebral palsy in India after spastic quadriplegia. Both the lower limbs are involved, with spasticity in the hip adductors. This leads to a characteristic commando crawling in infants and a scissoring gait in older children. Brain MRI shows scarring and shrinkage in the periventricular white matter with compensatory enlargement of the cerebral ventricles, called periventricular leukomalacia. IQ of these children is usually normal and has a good prognosis. 

Spastic hemiplegia affects one-half of the body. It is seen due to a vascular insult leading to a perinatal stroke event. Early hand preference is seen (before 1 year), where one side of the body is always preferred as the other side is weak. MRI shows focal changes and porencephalic cysts due to infarcts.

Spastic quadriplegia is the most common subtype seen in India. It is often caused by perinatal asphyxia and neonatal illness where all four limbs are affected. MRI would reveal multicystic encephalomalacia. It is associated with a poor outcome.

Dyskinetic/ Extrapyramidal CP is associated with birth asphyxia and kernicterus in the early neonatal period. Unlike spastic diplegia, the upper limbs are affected more than the lower limb. Brain MRI reveals lesions in the basal ganglia and thalamus.

questions.text: A patient has been diagnosed with keratosis obturans in the right ear. Which of the following tuning fork test results is seen in the patient?

choices.text: Rinne’s positive in the right ear
Weber’s lateralised to the right ear
Absolute bone conduction test reduced in the right ear
Weber’s lateralised to the left ear

questions.solution:
The tuning fork test present in this patient is Weber’s lateralised to the right ear (affected ear). 

Keratosis obturans is the accumulation of a large plug of desquamated keratin in the external auditory meatus. It presents with conductive type of hearing loss in the affected ear.

In conductive hearing loss - 

  • Rinne’s test is negative in the affected ear (bone conduction > air conduction)
  • Absolute bone conduction test (ABC) normal in the affected ear.
  • Schwabach test is lengthened in the affected ear.

Keratosis obturans is usually seen between the ages of 5-20 years and is commonly unilateral. Clinical features include severe otalgia and difficulty in hearing. It is associated with systemic conditions like bronchiectasis and chronic sinusitis. 

On otoscopic examination, there is a thickening of the tympanic membrane and a keratin plug appearing like a pearly white mass occluding the canal. There is also hyperemia of canal skin, sometimes with ulcerations and granulations. 

Facial nerve palsy is a common complication. Treatment involves the removal of the plug by syringing or instrumentation. Any recurrence can be prevented with the use of keratolytic agents such as 2% salicylic acid.

Note - Widening of the ear canal is associated with keratosis obturans, not narrowing.

questions.text: A 3-day-old neonate born to a diabetic mother presents with progressively deepening cyanosis and tachypnea since birth. Which of the following X-ray finding is characteristic of the most specific congenital heart disease associated with a baby born to a diabetic mother?
questions.solution:
The most specific congenital heart disease associated with a baby born to a diabetic mother is the transposition of great arteries (TGA). The characteristic X-ray finding of this condition is an egg-on-string appearance.

Egg-on-a-string appearance/ egg-on-side appearance refers to a globular-shaped heart due to an abnormal convexity of the right atrial border and left atrial enlargement, and therefore appears like an egg. Other chest X-ray features include mild cardiomegaly and a narrow mediastinum with normal to increased pulmonary blood flow.

 

ECHO is diagnostic. The size of the interatrial communication and the ductus arteriosus, the degree of mixing assessed, any associated ventricular outflow tract obstruction, or a septal defect, can be assessed by a color Doppler examination. 

Pathology of TGA:

 Transposition of great arteries (TGA) is characterized by the aorta arising from the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery from the left ventricle. Because of this, the pulmonary and systemic circulations remain separate. The right side of the heart has deoxygenated blood and the left side of the heart has oxygenated blood. The pulmonary artery saturation is always higher than the aortic saturation.

The deoxygenated blood returning from the body goes inappropriately out the aorta and back to the body again, while oxygenated pulmonary venous blood is returned directly to the lungs. Survival in the immediate neonatal period is due to the mixture of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood provided by the foramen ovale and the ductus arteriosus. 50% of patients also have a ventricular septal defect (VSD).

Infants with transposition of the great arteries (TGA) are usually born at term, with cyanosis apparent within hours of birth.

 

Other options:

Option A: Box-shaped heart is seen in Ebstein's anomaly. There is severe right-sided cardiomegaly due to an elongated and enlarged right atrium which leads to an elevated apex. 

Option B: Snowman heart is seen in total anomalous pulmonary venous return. It refers to the configuration of the heart and the superior mediastinal borders resembling a snowman. It is also referred to as the figure of 8 sign.

Option C: Gooseneck sign: Seen on left lateral angiograms in endocardial cushion defects.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male smoker with claudication pain in the lower limbs presents with the following arteriography findings. Choose the correct statement regarding his diagnosis.

choices.text: Surgery is the mainstay treatment of the disease
It majorly affects medium and large sizeds vessels
Chronic disease may result in recanalisation of the vessels
Elderly smokers are the most commonly affected

questions.solution:
The given angiographic image of a young male smoker with extensive corkscrew collaterals point towards the diagnosis of thromboangitis obliterans. Pathologically, chronic disease may result in recanalisation of the vessels in majority of the cases.

Thromboangiitis obliterans (Buerger’s disease) is a progressive segmental inflammatory occlusive vascular disorder involving small and medium-sized arteries, veins and nerves in the distal upper and lower extremities. 

It is most commonly identified in young ( 20-50 years ) male smokers and symptoms begin before 40 years of age. Claudication remains the initial complaint. Progressive calf claudication ends in rest pain and ulceration on toes, feet and fingers and digital gangrene.

The clinical features include a triad of:

  • Claudication of the affected extremity
  • Raynaud’s phenomenon
  • Migratory superficial vein thrombophlebitis

Four-limb angiography is the investigation of choice. Angiographic findings show distal involvement of vessels, skip lesions and extensive collateralisation called "cork-screw collaterals".

 In the acute stage, small and medium-sized arteries undergo thrombosis. There is a dense polymorphonuclear leucocyte aggregation around the affected regions. Microabcess and giant cell aggregation are also present.

The chronic stage shows a characteristic decrease in hypercellularity and recanalisation of vessel lumen.

End-stage lesions demonstrate organized thrombus and blood vessel fibrosis. 

The treatment majorly revolves around smoking cessation. The role of surgical intervention is minimal. Amputation is the end result for disease progression in patients who refuse to discontinue smoking.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presents to the emergency room with severe, upper abdominal pain that radiates to the back. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol. Lab investigations reveal gross elevations in triglycerides and of the component shown in the image below. He gives a family history of abnormal lipid profiles. Which of the following is the likely defect in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a case of acute pancreatitis. This patient's serum triglycerides are grossly elevated, and the image shows a schematic representation of a chylomicron which is elevated in familial chylomicronemia (type 1 dyslipidemia). This is caused due to lipoprotein lipase (LPL) deficiency, abnormal LPL, or apo C-II deficiency.

Lipoprotein lipase is required for the degradation of triglycerides in chylomicrons and VLDLs. Familial chylomicronemia follows an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance. These patients show slow clearance of chylomicrons and VLDL (rather than increased production), and low levels of LDL and HDL. It is usually not associated with premature atherosclerosis. Patients usually present due to acute pancreatitis. Other clinical features include hepatosplenomegaly and eruptive/ pruritic xanthomas. 

Chylomicrons transport dietary lipids from the intestine to the peripheral tissues. They are synthesized in the intestine by assembling apo B-48 with lipids (mainly triacylglycerol). This is called a nascent chylomicron, which upon receiving apo C-II and apo E from HDL is remodeled into a mature chylomicron. Apo C-II activates lipoprotein lipase present on the endothelium. Lipoprotein lipase hydrolyzes the triacylglycerols into fatty acids and glycerol which are either used for storage or energy. Therefore, patients who are deficient in lipoprotein lipase or apo C-II (type I hyperlipoproteinemia) show increased levels of chylomicrons in the plasma after a fatty meal.

questions.text: A teacher complains that a 7-year-old girl with falling grades is inattentive in class and has unresponsive episodes with staring. On hyperventilation, her symptoms increase and her EEG findings show a 3Hz spike and wave discharge. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical vignette and EEG features is typical absence seizures.

Absence seizures are a form of generalized seizures marked by unresponsiveness, staring, and eye flutter which usually last for a few seconds. GABAB receptors, T-type Ca2+ channels, and K+ channels situated within the thalamus are involved in the pathophysiology of absence seizures.

It is of two types:

  • Typical absence seizures  
  • Atypical absence seizures  

Typical absence seizures are associated with 3-Hz spike and slow wave discharges on EEG. It usually starts by the age of 5-8 years and can occur up to a hundred times per day. Hyperventilation can precipitate seizures and EEG changes. They last only for a few seconds and do not have an aura. It can be accompanied by eyelid flutter or upward rolling of the eyes. Simple automatisms such as lip smacking or picking at clothing can also be seen. There is no postictal period and the child usually resumes whatever activity he/she was engaged in prior to the episode. 

Atypical absence seizures are associated with 1-2-Hz spike-and-slow-wave discharges. Head atonia and myoclonus can also be seen during the seizures. It is precipitated by drowsiness and is generally more difficult to treat. 

Juvenile absence seizures occur at a later stage and are similar to typical absences. It is marked by 4-to-6 Hz spike-and-slow-wave and polyspike-and-slow-wave discharges. It is associated with juvenile myoclonic epilepsy.

EEG is the diagnostic test for absence seizures. An MRI would appear normal and so is not useful. Ethosuximide is the drug of choice for typical absence seizures. Its mechanism of action is inhibition of T-type calcium channels. Phenytoin, carbamazepine, and oxcarbazepine have all been associated with aggravation of absence seizures and even absence status epilepticus in children with absence epilepsy.

The following epilepsy syndromes are associated with absence seizures:

  • Childhood absence epilepsy
  • Juvenile absence epilepsy
  • Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy
  • Myoclonic absence epilepsy
  • Lennox-gestaut syndrome

Other options:

Option A: Myoclonic seizures can be focal, multifocal, or generalized. It is marked by the rapidity of jerks (<50 mseconds). EEG changes depend on the type of myoclonic seizure.

Option B: Myoclonus is very brief, abrupt, and involuntary jerky contractions of a single muscle or muscle group. Some causes of myoclonus in children include hiccups (physiologic), meningitis, and electrolyte disturbances.  

Option D: Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy also known as Janz syndrome is a type of generalized epilepsy seen in young adults. It presents as myoclonic jerks in the morning and generalized tonic-clonic or clonic-tonic-clonic seizures upon awakening. Sleep deprivation and photic stimulation can precipitate the episodes. 4-5 Hz polyspike-and-slow-wave discharges can be seen on EEG.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman in puerperium presents with headache, 1 episode of generalized seizures, and confusion. On examination, she is found to have papilledema. The contrast-enhanced CT of the head is shown below. What is the drug of choice for the acute management of her condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the CECT image showing the empty delta sign are characteristic of cerebral venous thrombosis. IV heparin is the drug of choice in cerebral venous thrombosis.

Cerebral venous thrombosis is the occlusion of the lateral sagittal sinuses (central venous sinus thrombosis) or small cortical veins (cortical venous thrombosis). Symptoms and signs include the following:

  • Headache: most common, with or without vomiting
  • Seizures
  • Intracranial hypertension and papilledema
  • Focal neurological deficits
  • Altered mental status
  • Coma

It is commonly seen in hypercoagulable states. Risk factors include the following:

  • Oral contraceptive pill use
  • Pregnancy and puerperium
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Dehydration
  • Intracranial infections
  • Thrombophilias like antiphospholipid syndrome, polycythemia, sickle cell anemia, protein C, S deficiency, factor V Leiden mutation, antithrombin III deficiency

MRI Brain with MR venography is the most sensitive investigation. Alternatively, CECT brain can also be done. The empty delta sign is a sign of dural venous sinus thrombosis of the superior sagittal sinus, where contrast outlines a triangular filling defect (clot). It is seen with a CECT scan or MRI.

CECT image showing the empty delta sign in the superior sagittal sinus posteriorly, with a large infarct in the left hemisphere causing a midline shift to the right:


Treatment of CVT includes

  • Acute treatment is with IV Heparin or low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH). IV heparin is the drug of choice in cerebral venous thrombosis. It prevents further thrombosis and reduces venous hypertension and ischemia.
  • Maintenance therapy:
    • Anticoagulation is often continued indefinitely if thrombophilia is diagnosed.
    • If there is no underlying hypercoagulable state, treatment with vitamin K antagonists like warfarin for 3–6 months may be initiated and then converted to aspirin, depending on the degree of resolution of the venous sinus thrombus. 
    • In pregnant women:
      • Anticoagulation with LMWH throughout pregnancy and till 8 weeks postpartum.

questions.text: A premature infant born at 34 weeks is admitted to the NICU for monitoring. You notice a pattern of breathing characterized by regular breathing interrupted by short pauses lasting for 5-10 seconds, followed by a burst of rapid respiration lasting for 10-15 seconds, before resuming normal breathing. These pauses are not associated with change in colour or heart rate. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The observed breathing pattern characterized by regular breathing interrupted with short pauses lasting 5-10 seconds, followed by a burst of rapid breathing lasting for 10-15 seconds, before resuming normal breathing, without changes in color or heart rate, is consistent with periodic breathing.

Periodic breathing is a common phenomenon seen in premature infants due to immature respiratory control centers in the brainstem. These episodes typically consist of cycles of regular respiration followed by brief pauses in breathing, lasting for about 5-10 seconds, before resuming normal breathing. Periodic breathing is also seen in term infants in the first few months of life.

Apneic episodes of up to 20 seconds are considered acceptable if they are not associated with changes in color or heart rate.

Other options: 

Option A: Apnea of prematurity refers to prolonged episodes of apnea lasting longer than 20 seconds in premature infants. Unlike periodic breathing, apnea of prematurity episodes is typically associated with changes in appearance and heart rate, such as cyanosis or bradycardia. 

Option C: Transient tachypnea of the newborn is a condition characterized by rapid breathing shortly after birth due to delayed clearance of lung fluid. It does not present with the cyclic pattern of respirations and pauses seen in periodic breathing.

Option D: Breath-holding spells typically occur in older infants and children and are characterized by a voluntary cessation of breathing, often in response to emotional stress or frustration.

questions.text: A diabetic patient is undergoing management of a chronic ulcer with hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HBOT). All of the following statements are correct about this treatment modality, except:

choices.text: It stimulates angiogenesis in chronic, non-healing wounds
It is associated with an increased ischemia–reperfusion injury
In diabetic ulcers, HBOT reduces the risk of proximal amputation
Middle ear barotrauma is a common adverse effect of HBOT chamber

questions.solution:
Hyperbaric oxygen therapy produces controlled oxidative stress which is associated with reduced occurrence of ischemia–reperfusion injury. Hence, option B is incorrect.

Chronic, non-healing wounds are usually associated with a decreased blood supply. Oxygen therapy in such cases results in improved angiogenesis (option A) and the production of reactive oxygen species prevents the growth of bacteria in the wounds. Hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HBOT) using pressurized oxygen is the most commonly used modality. 

HBOT chambers provide 100% oxygen at higher than atmospheric pressure. There is a significant increase in partial pressure of oxygen in the tissues which results in the production of a controlled oxidative stress. This produces improved leukocyte function, neovascularization in the wound bed, and increased local growth factors that improve wound healing. The controlled oxidative stress is associated with blunting of ischemia-reperfusion injury. 

HBOT chambers can be either single-person chambers or multiple-person chambers. The image below shows a single-person HBOT chamber:


HBOT is indicated for the management of the following wounds and ulcers:

  • Clostridial myonecrosis and necrotizing soft tissue infections
  • Diabetic ulcers
  • Radiation-induced tissue or bone necrosis
  • Refractory osteomyelitis
  • Thermal burns

In cases where it was employed for the management of diabetic foot ulcers, HBOT significantly improved wound healing and was associated with a reduced risk of proximal amputation (option C). 

Complications of HBOT are mostly related to the adverse effects of increased pressure inside HBOT chambers. The most common complications are middle ear barotrauma (option D) and sinus barotrauma. Other complications include dental barotrauma, pulmonary barotrauma, and seizures from CNS oxygen toxicity.

questions.text: During ward rounds, the neonatologist tries to pick up the newborn. You observe the sign as shown in the image given below. The presence of this sign is considered abnormal after ________.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a pull-to-sit maneuver being performed and there is a complete head lag on picking up the child. The presence of this sign is abnormal if it persists beyond 20 weeks.

In the newborn, the head completely lags and the back is rounded. The head lag disappears once neck control is achieved and the child starts to flex his head when trying to pick up from the supine position.

The head control first begins to develop at 6 weeks, and there is a slight lag at 12 weeks. Complete neck control is attained by 20 weeks, after which, the infant lifts the head from the supine position when about to be pulled.

questions.text: An obese male diagnosed with hypertension is on statin therapy. However, his recent cholesterol levels are elevated and an additional drug that increases bile acid excretion in the stools is initiated. Which of the following drugs is likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
The drug that is likely prescribed to this patient which acts by increasing bile acid excretion in the stools is colestipol. It is a bile acid sequestrant that decreases reabsorption of bile acids in the intestine which are thus excreted in stools. 

Loss of bile acids in stools leads to increased hepatic bile acid synthesis. Therefore, hepatic cholesterol content decreases, stimulating the production of LDL receptors, an effect similar to that of statins. The increase in hepatic LDL receptors increases LDL clearance and lowers LDL-cholesterol (LDL-C) levels.

But this effect is partially offset by the enhanced cholesterol synthesis caused by upregulation of HMG-CoA reductase. Therefore, concurrent statin therapy substantially increases the effectiveness of bile acid sequestrants. 

Another effect of increased hepatic bile acid synthesis is that it also causes an increase in hepatic triglyceride synthesis, which is of consequence in patients with significant hypertriglyceridemia. Therefore, initial monitoring of fasting triglyceride levels every 1-2 weeks is important while starting on these drugs.

Other options 

Option A) - Ezetimibe inhibits Niemann-Pick C1-like 1 (NPC1L1) transport protein which is a cholesterol transporter in the jejunal enterocytes and thereby decreases cholesterol absorption in the diet.

Option C) - Gemfibrozil belongs to the fibrate group of drugs that binds to peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors (PPARα) which stimulate fatty acid oxidation and thereby reduce triglyceride levels mainly.

Option D) - Bempedoic acid acts by competitively inhibiting ATP-citrate lyase(ACL), a cytoplasmic enzyme that converts citrate to oxaloacetate and acetyl-CoA. Thereby reducing acetyl-CoA levels which is the starting substrate in the de novo synthesis of cholesterol. 

Note - Ezetimibe , colestipol, bempedoic acid and PCSK-9 inhibitors like alirocumab have been proven to reduce atherosclerosis risk when added to statins whereas fibrate group of drugs and niacin show no significant effect in addition to statins.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman comes to the clinic with a history of ulcers on her fingertips for the last one year. She says that her fingertips change color when exposed to cold . Examination findings are shown below. Auscultation reveals a loud second (P2)heart sound. Laboratory investigations reveal normal renal function. Which of the following antibodies is likely to be positive in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical image shows calcinosis cutis, a feature commonly seen in patients with longstanding limited systemic sclerosis or CREST syndrome. The anticentromere antibody is positive in these patients.

CREST stands for calcinosis cutis, Raynaud’s phenomenon (color change in fingers on exposure to cold), esophageal dysmotility, sclerodactyly, and telangiectasias. The condition can be associated with ulcers on the fingertips and isolated pulmonary hypertension (loud P2), which can be asymptomatic or present with reduced exercise capacity.

Calcinosis cutis is dystrophic calcification in the skin, subcutaneous tissues, and soft tissues. The serum calcium and phosphate levels are generally normal. 

Systemic sclerosis (SSc)  is a complex heterogeneous disorder that can potentially involve every organ system. There is significant variability in the patterns of skin involvement, organ complications, and rates of disease progression that gives rise to two major subtypes of the disease - diffuse cutaneous SSc and limited cutaneous SSc.

The antibodies tested in systemic sclerosis include:

  • Antinuclear antibody (ANA) - positive in most cases of systemic sclerosis. The absence of this antibody suggests considering an alternate diagnosis.
  • Anticentromere antibody (ACA) - usually positive in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis or CREST
  • Antitopoisomerase I (anti-Scl-70) antibody - usually positive with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis (option A)
  • Anti-RNA polymerase III antibody - usually positive with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis.

Other options:

Option C: Anti-Ro antibodies are used to diagnose Sjogren’s syndrome, which is an autoimmune disorder characterized by the involvement of the exocrine glands which results in impairment of salivary and lacrimal gland function. Although patients with Sjogren’s syndrome may have arthralgias, Raynaud’s phenomenon and cough, calcinosis cutis is not a feature of this disease.

Option D: Anti Mi-2 antibodies are highly specific for dermatomyositis which may have cutaneous manifestations such as Gottron's papules on the dorsum of the hands. This disease is characterized by proximal muscle weakness and is usually associated with an underlying malignancy.

An image of Gottron's papules in dermatomyositis is shown below:

questions.text: A police officer travelling to a malaria-endemic area for a monthly posting came to you regarding chemoprophylaxis. Choose the best-suited regimen that can be prescribed to the officer.

choices.text: T. Doxycycline 100 mg OD- 1 week before arrival upto 2 weeks after leaving the endemic area
T. Chloroquine 300 mg OD- 1 week before arrival upto 4 weeks after leaving the endemic area
T. Doxycycline 100 mg OD- 2 days before arrival upto 4 weeks after leaving the endemic area
T. Mefloquine 250 mg OD- one day before arrival upto 2 weeks after leaving the endemic area

questions.solution:
The most suitable regimen for the police officer traveling for a monthly posting is the short-term (less than 6 weeks) chemoprophylaxis consisting of T. Doxycycline 100mg OD starting 2 days before arrival up to 4 weeks after leaving the endemic area.

Chemoprophylaxis is recommended for travelers from non-endemic areas and as a preventive measure for soldiers, police, and labor forces serving in highly endemic areas. It should be complemented by personal protection and methods of vector control.

The recommended chemoprophylaxis as per the NVBDCP guidelines:

Prophylaxis Drug Dose Recommendation 
Short term 
(<6 weeks)		 Doxycycline Adults- 100 mg OD
Children- 1.5 mg/kg OD		 2 days before arrival, continued up to 4 weeks after leaving 
Long term
(>6 weeks)		 Mefloquine Adults- 250 mg weekly 2 weeks before arrival, continued up to 4 weeks after leaving 


All prophylactic courses should be taken with un-failing regularity for the duration of stay and 4 weeks after the last possible exposure to infection since parasites may still emerge from the liver during this period.

Doxycycline chemoprophylaxis is not recommended for pregnant women and children less than 8 years of age. Mefloquine is contraindicated in individuals with a history of convulsions, neuropsychiatric problems, and cardiac conditions.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman presents with complaints of myalgia and fatigue. Her BP is 88/54 and examination reveals hyperpigmentation of the palmar creases and dorsal foot. She has a history of treated pulmonary tuberculosis. Serum electrolyte values are given below. Which of the following will be used for managing this patient?

Sodium - 125 mmol/ L
Potassium - 6 mmol/ L
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with myalgia and fatigue, examination showing hypotension and hyperpigmentation of extremities, and electrolytes showing hyponatremia (Na < 135 mmol/L) and hyperkalemia (K > 5.2 mmol/L) is suggestive of primary adrenal insufficiency. Management involves glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid replacement with hydrocortisone + fludrocortisone.

The most common cause of primary adrenal insufficiency or Addison’s disease is autoimmune adrenalitis. However, tuberculous adrenalitis is also an important cause in developing countries. This patient's history of pulmonary tuberculosis makes the latter more likely. 

Patients usually present with complaints of fatigue, myalgias, weight loss, and joint pain. Mineralocorticoid deficiency manifests as salt craving, dizziness due to hypotension, and abdominal pain. Excess ACTH stimulation results in hyperpigmentation of exposed areas of the skin such as palmar creases and dorsal foot. Hyponatremia is a characteristic feature and is often associated with hyperkalemia. 

Diagnosis is established with decreased morning cortisol levels and elevated ACTH. A cosyntropin test is used to confirm the diagnosis.

The image below shows hyperpigmentation associated with Addison's disease:


Management of primary adrenal insufficiency involves supplementation of glucocorticoids and mineralocorticoids. Hydrocortisone is used for glucocorticoid supplementation in two or three divided doses. The doses are timed to mimic the physiological cortisol secretion. Long-acting glucocorticoids like prednisolone are not preferred because of their inability to mimic the physiological cycle.

Mineralocorticoid replacement is done with fludrocortisone at an initial dose of 100–150 μg. The dose is adjusted according to the patient's response and the blood pressure, serum sodium, potassium, and renin levels are monitored. 

Other options:

Option B: As mentioned, prednisolone is a long-acting glucocorticoid which is not preferred. Indomethacin is used for the management of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. This drug combination is not indicated for this patient. 

Option C: Demeclocycline + tolvaptan can be used in the management of the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH). This condition can present with muscle weakness and lethargy due to hyponatremia. However, it is not associated with hyperpigmentation or hyperkalemia. 

Option D: Hydrochlorothiazide + amiloride can be used for the management of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (DI). Amiloride is used for the management of lithium-induced nephrogenic DI. DI presents with hypernatremia and is not associated with hyperpigmentation.

  • Autoimmune (Addison's disease)

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with a dermatophytic infection. A scraping from the lesion was observed under the potassium hydroxide (KOH) mount. It revealed the macroconidia of the dermatophyte as shown in the image below. The species of this genera usually infects:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing spindle-shaped macroconidia point toward a diagnosis of Microsporum infection. The species of this genera usually infect skin and hair.

Dermatophytes involve only the superficial keratinized layer of skin, sparing the dermis. It should be differentiated from dermatomycosis which is the cutaneous involvement of systemic fungi.

Dermatophytes are classified into 3 types:

  • Trichophyton infects skin, hair, and nails. The species include T. rubrum, T. mentagrophytes, T. tonsurans, T. schoenleinii, T. violaceum, etc. Microconidia > Macroconidia
  • Microsporum infects only hair and skin but, not the nails. The species include M. gypseum, M. canis, and M. nanum. Macroconidia> Microconidia.
  • Epidermophyton infects only skin and nails, not hair. Floccosum is the only species in this genus. Only Macroconidia.

Clinical features of infection by Microsporum include:

  • Skin lesions in the skin tend to be circular, dry, erythematous, scaly, and itchy.
  • Hair lesions include kerion, scarring, and alopecia.

Diagnosis is established by clinical features, use of Wood's lamp, and laboratory investigations such as microscopic examination and culture characteristics.

Microscopic examination of material teased out from the fungal colony (culture mount) or material taken on cellotape (cellotape mount) is observed for identification of the species. It is observed for the presence and type of hyphae and conidia. Conidia (asexual spores) are of two types: small unicellular microconidia and larger septate macroconidia.

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

questions.text: A 47-year-old female patient presents with slow progressive hearing loss and pulsatile tinnitus for the last few years. Otoscopy reveals the following findings. What is the embryological origin of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a middle-aged woman with progressive hearing loss, pulsatile tinnitus and a red mass behind an intact tympanic membrane is suggestive of an intratympanic glomus tumour. The embryological origin of an intratympanic glomus tumour is neural crest cells.

Glomus tumours are the most common benign tumours of the middle ear. The tumors comprise paraganglionic cells and arise from glomus bodies which resemble carotid bodies. Glomus bodies are present in the dome of the jugular bulb and on the promontory along the course of the tympanic branch of the IXth cranial nerve. 

Signs seen in intratympanic glomus tumour are -

  • Rising sun sign when tumor arises from the floor of the middle ear
  • Pulsation or Brown sign: when the ear canal pressure is raised with Siegel's speculum the tumour pulsates and blanches, this reverses when pressure is released.

Other presentations of glomus tumour include- bleeding polyp if the tympanic membrane is breached and pressure symptoms causing cranial nerve palsies. These are -

  • Dysphagia and hoarseness with unilateral paralysis of the soft palate, due to IX and X nerve
  • Vocal cord paralysis due to X nerve
  • Weakness of the trapezius and sternomastoid muscles - XI nerve
  • Atrophy of half of the tongue - XII nerve

They are diagnosed by CT scan, MRI and four-vessel angiography mainly. It is treated by surgery, radiation, embolization, or a combination of them. 

Note - Glomus tumors are highly vascular tumors hence biopsy is never done and their origin is not from angioblasts.

questions.text: A patient is set to undergo the orthopedic surgery shown in the image below, for the correction of a deformity. Which of the following statements is likely to be true regarding the deformity?

choices.text: Presents with an increase in the carrying angle
Preserved range of motion at the elbow joint
Commonly associated with tardive ulnar nerve palsy
Occurs due to non union of fracture shaft of humerus

questions.solution:
The given image represents lateral closed-wedge osteotomy, which is performed for the correction of cubitus varus deformity. This deformity is characterized by a preserved range of motion at the elbow joint.

Cubitus varus, also called the gunstock deformity, is characterized by a decreased carrying angle at the elbow joint. It is the most common complication of malunited supracondylar fracture. The malunited fracture results in medial tilt and internal rotation displacement of the distal fragment. 

Cubitus varus is only a cosmetic disability with no functional impairment of the elbow, as supracondylar fracture is an extra articular fracture.         

The treatment of choice is corrective osteotomy and is deferred until skeletal maturity. These are : 

  • Lateral closed-wedge osteotomy(French/modified French osteotomy) - A wedge of bone is removed from the lateral cortex and the gap is closed
  • Medial open-wedge osteotomy (King’s osteotomy) - a wedge of bone is resected on the medial aspect and the deformity is corrected. 

Other options:

Option A -  An increase in the carrying angle is a feature of cubitus valgus.

Option C - Cubitus valgus deformity is commonly associated with tardive ulnar nerve palsy due to stretching of the ulnar nerve and not cubitus varus.

Option D - Cubitus varus is a result of malunion of supracondylar fracture of the humerus and not due to nonunion of fracture shaft of humerus.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old child is brought to the clinic with a daily fever for the last 2 months. She has not been playful during the daytime but appears to get better in the evening. The girl also complains of wrist and knee pain for the last two months which worsens with movements. There is a faint salmon-pink rash on the trunk. Below is the lab report. What is the most appropriate diagnosis?

TLC - 15,000 cells/cu.mm 

ESR - 40 mm/hr
questions.solution:
A young child with pain in the joints, daily fever spike that reduces spontaneously, salmon-pink rash on the trunks, and elevated ESR and WBC count is likely suggestive of systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA).

Systemic JIA - Arthritis in ≥1 joint + fever of at least 2 weeks in duration that is documented to be daily (quotidian fever) for at least 3 days and accompanied by ≥1 of the following:

  • Evanescent (nonfixed) maculopapular truncal rash
  • Generalized lymph node enlargement
  • Hepatomegaly or splenomegaly or both
  • Serositis

JIA is defined as arthritis in ≥1 joint with onset <16 years of age and persisting for at least 6 weeks. It can be classified as systemic, oligoarthritis, polyarthritis with rheumatoid factor (RF) positive or negative, psoriatic arthritis, and enthesitis-related arthritis.

  • Chronic arthritis ≥6 weeks and age of onset ≤16 years is essential for the diagnosis of JIA
  • Oligoarthritis JIA - ≤4 joints involved
  • Polyarthritis JIA -  ≥5 joints involved
    • RF positive - Symmetric involvement is seen in >8 years of age 
    • RF negative - Asymmetric involvement is seen in <8 years of age
  • Psoriatic JIA - Features of psoriasis and any 2 of the following
    • Dactylitis
    • Pitting of nails
    • 1st degree relative with psoriasis
  • Enthesitis-related JIA - Arthritis + Enthesitis
    • HLA-B27 positive

Treatment options include NSAIDs (non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs) for symptomatic management and disease-modifying anti-rheumatic drugs (DMARDs) such as methotrexate. DMARDs should be started in all children with polyarthritis. Systemic glucocorticoids are usually reserved for children with severe unremitting arthritis, systemic manifestations (serositis, vasculitis), and rapidly progressive disease.

questions.solution:

questions.text: Which of the following findings suggests that the baby was live-born in a case of infanticide?

choices.text: Gelatinous tissue in the middle ear
Weight of lung 1/35th of body weight

questions.solution:
The baby will be considered live-born if the weight of the lung is 1/35th of the body weight.

Autopsy findings to differentiate before and after respiration:

Autopsy findings Before respiration After respiration
1. Shape of chest Flat; chest circumference is 1–2 cm less than the abdominal circumference Dome or arch-shaped
2. Position of the diaphragm At or above the 4th/5th rib At or below the 6th/7th rib
3. Lung margins Sharp Rounded
4. Lung consistency Dense, firm, non-crepitant Soft, spongy, elastic, crepitant
5. Lung weight 1/70th of body weight 1/35th of body weight
6. Lung color Uniformly reddish-brown or bluish-red Mottled or marbled appearance
7. Hydrostatic test Specific gravity is 1040–1050 Specific gravity is 940
8. Stomach Contains only mucin and sinks in water Contains mucin and air and floats in water
9. Middle ear Contains gelatinous embryonic connective tissue Air replaces the embryonic tissue

 

Other tests for live birth:

  • Breslau’s first life test (also known as Hydrostatic test/Raygat’s test) - The organ tested is the lung. It is based on the ability of the lung to sink or float in water.
  • Breslau's second life test: It is based on the air entering stomach and intestine during respiration in a live-born fetus. The stomach and intestine are removed by tying double ligatures at each end and placed in water to check if they float or sink.
  • Wreden’s test – This test is based on changes in the middle ear after birth
  • Fodere’s test – This test is based on the increase in the weight of the lungs due to increased blood flow after birth. The weight of the unrespired lung is 30–40 g, whereas the weight of respired lung is 60–66 g.
  • Ploucquet’s test – This is based on the ratio of the weight of the lung to the weight of the body in unrespired and respired lungs.
    • Unrespired lungs - 1/70
    • Respired lungs - 1/35

Related Pearl: Hydrostatic Test/Floatation Test/Raygat's Test

It is based on the lung changes in a fetus after respiration.

Principle: Respired air remains in the lungs as residual air which cannot be removed after death. Hence lung floats in water.

False-negative test in:

  • Atelectasis
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Pneumonia
  • Congenital syphilis
  • Air absorbed from air passages if circulation continued for long time after cessation of respiration
  • More air exhaled from the lungs compared to air entering during inspiration
  • Obstruction by alveolar duct membrane

False-positive test in:

  • Putrefied foetus
  • Artificial inflation

Hydrostatic test is not required when:

  • Fetus is monstrous
  • Fetus is macerated or mummified
  • Fetus is born before 180 days of gestation
  • Stomach contains milk
  • Umbilical cord has separated and scar has been formed

questions.text:
While studying sleep physiology, a student learns that one of the stages reduces as we age and is associated with pontogeniculo-occipital (PGO) spikes. What is the stage of sleep referred to?

NREM - Non - Rapid eye movement
REM - Rapid eye movement
questions.solution:
The stage of the sleep cycle referred to here is the REM stage. 

The REM stage occupies 80% of total sleep time in premature infants and 50% in full-term neonates. Thereafter, the proportion of REM sleep falls rapidly and plateaus at about 25% until it falls to about 20% in the elderly. 

Pontogeniculo-occipital (PGO) spikes are characteristic of REM sleep. These are large phasic potentials that originate in the cholinergic neurons in the pons and pass rapidly to the lateral geniculate body and from there to the occipital cortex. A combination of PET scans and EEG are used to identify these spikes or waves.

Positron emission tomography (PET) scans in REM sleep show increased activity in the pontine area, amygdala, and anterior cingulate gyrus, but decreased activity in the prefrontal and parietal cortex. 

Note - REM stage shows increased activity in cholinergic neurons of the pons that are part of the reticular activating system and decreased norepinephrine and serotonin-containing neurons in the locus ceruleus and raphé nuclei respectively.

The opposite activity of decreased cholinergic activity in the pons and increased norepinephrine and serotonin-containing neurons in the locus ceruleus and raphé nuclei respectively occurs during waking up from sleep.

  • Changes to the beta rhythm in response to internal or external stimuli.

  • Fatigued and tired
  • The head droops, momentary lapses of attention
  • Sleepy but not asleep

NREM 1 (N1) (5%)
  • Light sleep-easily aroused by moderate stimuli or even by muscle jerks
  • Continuous lack of awareness
  • Mixed frequency waves  (predominantly 2-7 Hz).
  • Gap in alpha rhythm is filled with theta (4–8 Hz) and delta (slower than 4 Hz) activity
  • Vertex waves

  • Predominant theta activity (4-7 Hz)
  • K-complex and sleep spindles occur periodically

  • Deep sleep
  • Arousal only with vigorous stimuli
  • Sleep-arousal most difficult

  • 50–90 min after sleep onset, episodes repeated every 60–90 min, each episode lasting about 10 min
  • Dreaming occurs, rapid eye movements, increase in brain O2 consumption
  • EEG resembles that of alert awake state.
  • Saw tooth waves

Note: According to the new classification, stage 3 and 4 of NREM are grouped together as N3. So as per recent staging NREM has 3 stages (N1, N2, N3)

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl complains of low-grade fever and mild discomfort in her throat. On examination, a membrane is seen over the tonsil that can be removed easily. After removal of the membrane, an irregular ulcer is seen on the surface of the tonsil. A smear from the lesion shows a fusiform bacilli and another bacterium. What is the other bacterium?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Vincent's angina. It is caused by the fusiform bacillus and Borrelia vincentii.

Vincent's angina, also known as acute necrotizing ulcerative gingivitis or trench mouth, is a form of gingivitis characterized by painful, inflamed gingiva with ulcerations of the interdental papillae that bleed easily.

Patients usually present with low-grade fever, halitosis, malaise, lymphadenopathy, sore throat & a membrane over the tonsil. This membrane is easily removed to reveal irregular ulcers over the tonsil.

A throat swab will show both the organisms typical of the disease, namely fusiform bacilli and spirochetes, namely Borrelia vincentii. 

Treatment consists of debridement and oral administration of penicillin plus metronidazole, with clindamycin or doxycycline alone as an alternative.

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl is brought for medical examination by her parents, with complaints of being sexually assaulted by her neighbor. What would be the likely hymenal finding in this child?

choices.text: Ruptured since it is superficially situated
Ruptured since it is very thin
Unruptured since it is deeply situated
Unruptured since it is highly elastic

questions.solution:
In this child, the hymen is likely to be unruptured since it is deeply situated and usually intact after intercourse.

 As the vagina is very small, it is impossible for the penetration of the adult organ to take place. In children, there are few or no signs of general   violence, as the child is unaware of the assault and incapable of resisting.

 The penis is usually placed within the vulva and between the thighs. Forceful penetration may cause the penis to be pushed backward by the   symphysis pubis, and the hymen may be torn posteriorly.

 A few indicators for routine enquiry are pain on urination and/or defecation, abdominal pain, inability to sleep, sudden withdrawal from peers/adults,   feelings of anxiety, nervousness, helplessness, weight loss, and feelings of ending one’s life.

 On examination, blood may be oozing from the injured parts or blood clots may be found. An attempt to separate the thighs may cause pain. The child    may walk with difficulty due to the pain. The labia majora may be contused, abraded, or lacerated. Circumferential tears may be seen in children        up  to six years.

questions.text: A patient comes to the casualty with a history of fall on the left hand. An X-ray image of the patient is given below. What is the true statement regarding the injury/fracture sustained?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the x-ray image suggest a Smith’s fracture and the true statement is reduction of the fracture involves dorsiflexion of the wrist.

Smith’s fracture is an extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement. It is also called a reverse Colles fracture.

The patient presents with a fall on the back of the wrist injury with a garden-spade deformity.

These fractures are reduced by traction, supination and extension/dorsiflexion of the wrist, and the forearm is immobilised in a cast for 6 weeks. Check x-rays are taken every 7-10 days to assess for displacement. If fracture realignment is difficult or not satisfactory, surgical management with a volar plate to buttress the distal fragment is preferred.

Other options:

Options A and D: Dinner fork deformity and dorsal angulation are seen in a Colles fracture.

Option B: Smith’s fracture is an extra-articular fracture of the wrist. Intra-articular fractures of the wrist include Barton’s fracture.

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.

questions.text: A 52-year-old female presents with a complaint of progressive hair loss over the past 6 months. On examination, she has areas of scarring alopecia with perifollicular erythema. She also has pruritic, polygonal, flat-topped, violaceous papules and plaques with Wickham's striae on her wrists and forearms. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This is a clinical scenario of lichen planopilaris, characterized by scarring alopecia and the presence of typical lichen planus lesions characterized by pruritic, polygonal, flat-topped, violaceous papules and plaques with Wickham's striae.

Lichen planopilaris causes scarring alopecia. Scarring/ cicatricial alopecia is characterized by permanent destruction of hair follicles and irreversible hair loss.

Lichen planopilaris (LPP) is a type of follicular lichen planus. There are 3 types of follicular lichen planus, out of which LPP is the most common.

It is most commonly confined to the scalp and produces progressive cicatricial/ scarring alopecia. The proposed mechanism behind it is reduced expression of peroxisome proliferator‐activated receptor γ (PPAR‐γ) in hair follicles, causing their destruction and ultimately, scarring.

It can occur in isolation or in the presence of typical lichen planus lesions in other parts of the body.

Related Pearl: Causes of scarring and non-scarring alopecia- Mnemonic

Alopecia or hair loss can be classified as :

  1. Non-Scarring/Non-Cicatricial alopecia
  2. Scarring/Cicatricial alopecia 

Mnemonic for causes of non-scarring alopecia: THATS STD!

  • Tinea capitis(Non-Inflammatory Type  - grey patch and black dot types )
  • Hormonal - Hypothyroidism, Androgenetic alopecia
  • Anagen effluvium, Alopecia areata
  • Trichotillomania
  • Secondary syphilis (moth-eaten alopecia)
  • SLE(predominantly causes non-scarring alopecia but also can cause scarring alopecia)
  • Telogen effluvium
  • Deficiency of Zinc, Iron 

Mnemonic for causes of scarring alopecia: SF2L3

  • Scleroderma - Linear scalp morphea (en coup de sabre)
  • Favus and Kerion (Inflammatory Type of Tinea capitis)
  • Folliculitis decalvans
  • Lichen planopilaris
  • Lupus vulgaris
  • Lupus erythematosis - discoid (DLE)
  • Pseudopelade of Brocq

questions.text: A senior resident who is in charge of the labor ward asks you to perform cardiotocography(CTG) in a patient suspected of fetal head compression. Presence of which of the following features on CTG is suggestive of this diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Fetal head compression may show early deceleration on cardiotocography.

Deceleration refers to a transient decrease in fetal heart rate below the baseline by 15 bpm or more and lasting for ≥15 seconds.

Types of decelerations:

  • Early decelerations (Type I Dips): Onset, nadir(lowest point), and recovery of deceleration coincide with the beginning, peak, and ending of uterine contraction respectively. It suggests fetal head compression resulting in vagal nerve activation.
  • Late decelerations (Type II Dips): These begin after the onset of the uterine contraction. Usually, the onset, nadir, and recovery of the deceleration occur after the start, peak, and end of the uterine contraction respectively. The peak occurs 20 seconds after the peak of the contraction and FHR returns to normal after the contraction is over.
    It suggests uteroplacental insufficiency and fetal hypoxia.
  • Variable deceleration: It is associated with umbilical cord compression and may disappear with the change in position of the patient. It has an acceleration at the beginning and also at the end of the deceleration. These accelerations are described as the shoulders of the deceleration. It is the most common type of deceleration. 
  • Prolonged deceleration is the abrupt decrease in FHR to levels below the baseline and it lasts > 2 min but < 10 min.
  • Sinusoidal pattern: It has a stable baseline FHR with fixed or absent baseline variability lasting > 20 min, thus resembling a sine wave. Accelerations are absent. It is often associated with fetal anemia, fetomaternal hemorrhage, and fetal hypoxia (acidosis). It may occur when narcotics are given to the mother.

Acceleration: Transient increase in FHR by 15 bpm or more lasting for at least 15 seconds. It indicates a healthy fetus due to an intact neurohormonal and cardiovascular activity.

Prolonged acceleration is the abrupt increase in FHR to levels above the baseline and it lasts > 2 min but < 10 min. 

Related Pearl: Deceleration patterns on cardiotocography (CTG)

Early deceleration: seen in head compression

 

Late deceleration: Seen in uteroplacental insufficiency, foetal hypoxia

 

Variable deceleration: Seen in umbilical cord compression

questions.text: An elderly patient came to you with lower abdominal pain and was unable to pass urine since the previous night. His wife says that he was prescribed a new medication for his depression which he has been taking for one week. Which of the following drug can be the one which caused the above symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given symptoms point to urinary retention. Among the given drugs, this is most likely due to imipramine which is a tricyclic antidepressant. 

Tricyclic antidepressants have anticholinergic (antimuscarinic) effects like urinary retention (especially in elderly males with an enlarged prostate), epigastric distress, dry mouth, constipation, blurred vision, and confusion. 

Tricyclic antidepressants are mainly used in depressive patients who are unresponsive to commonly used antidepressent such as selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRI) and serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRI).

Other options:

Option A- Trazodone is an atypical antidepressant with no antimuscarinic effects. It is known to cause priapsim.

Option B- Sertraline is an SSRI with no antimuscarinic effects. 

Option C- Venlafaxine is an SNRI with no antimuscarinic effects.

questions.text: What percentage of children are expected to manifest cystic fibrosis if the father and mother, both are carriers for the disease?
questions.solution:
Cystic fibrosis follows autosomal recessive inheritance. Hence, the disease is likely to be manifested in 25% of children. 

If parents are unaffected (both are carriers/heterozygotes):

  • 25% of the children have normal genotype
  • 50% are carriers
  • 25% are homozygous and hence the disease is manifested

In autosomal recessive disorders, the disease manifests itself when the offspring has a homozygous state. Multiple affected members are seen in the same generation. Other generations are not affected. The following pedigree chart depicts an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance.

Cystic fibrosis results due to a defective mutation in the gene encoding for cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR gene). It plays an important role in mucociliary transport along the respiratory mucosa. It also helps regulate the amount of exocrine gland secretion.

The defect in the ion channel results in the production of hyper viscous, adherent secretions which can obstruct the airways. Organisms such as Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Staphylococcus aureus can grow in the sputum. The exocrine pancreas can undergo fibrotic scarring, cyst formation, and acinar tissue loss. The viscid secretions can lead to pancreatic duct obstruction. The flow of digestive enzymes to the duodenum is hence impaired.

Symptoms include sinusitis, steatorrhea, and abdominal pain. Distal intestinal obstruction is a complication due to difficulty in excreting intestinal contents. In neonates, it can present as meconium ileus. 

Detection of high levels of trypsinogen is used in newborn screening. Chloride levels >60mEq/L in the sweat of affected patients are diagnostic. Hyponatremic hypochloremic alkalosis and hypokalemia may also be seen.

Postural drainage, short-term antibiotics, and inhaled bronchodilators can be used for medical management. The definitive treatment is lung transplantation.

questions.text: In a microbiology lab, 50% of employees received the prophylactic pneumococcal pneumonia vaccine while the remaining 50% did not. Which of the following statistical tests can be used to see whether the vaccination program made any difference in the health outcomes of the employees?
questions.solution:
The Chi-square test is the statistical test that can be used to determine whether the vaccination program made any difference in the health outcomes of the employees. This is because it can test for differences in two or more categories when all the variables are qualitative or nominal (variables having two or more categories and a natural ranking or ordering). The variables in this case are qualitative.

The Chi-square test is a non-parametric test of significance employed for two proportions using qualitative variables. It has the advantage of being of use when more than two groups are to be compared. It also offers information on the significance of any observed differences.

Other options:

Option A: Paired t-test compares paired data or pre-intervention and post-intervention data of the same group. This doesn't apply here as the groups are not paired.

Option B: The student’s t-test is used for quantitative data. Here the data is qualitative, hence it can't be used.

Option C: Medical record linkage is the assembly and maintenance of a file for each individual in a population using important records relating to his health. It is a suitable method of studying associations between diseases.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: Identify the zone of liver most susceptible to injury in case of acetaminophen toxicity?
questions.solution:
The zone of liver most susceptible to injury due to acetaminophen toxicity is the centrilobular zone surrounding the central vein. This is Zone 3 in the image. 

Acetaminophen or paracetamol is considered safe at therapeutic doses ( 0.5g ), at toxic doses( 10- 25g ), acetaminophen produces a centrilobular hepatic necrosis that may progress to liver failure and prove fatal due to accumulation of unconjugated N-acetyl-p-benzoquinoneimine (NAPQI).

questions.text: Which of the following cellular and extracellular matrix interactions are correctly paired?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, hemidesmosomes and integrins are correctly paired.

Hemidesmosomes are anchoring junctions that mechanically attach cells to the extracellular matrix (ECM). Transmembrane connector proteins called integrins are present on hemidesmosomes, which attach to intermediate filaments and links the cytoskeleton to the ECM.
