questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient suffers blunt abdominal trauma due to an RTA. He presents with severe abdominal pain and distension. On examination, the abdomen is tense, distended, and tender. He has decreased urine output and hypotension. Bladder pressure monitoring is found to be 36 cm H20. What is the next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain contrast enhanced CT of the abdomen

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario described is suggestive of abdominal compartment syndrome (ACS), characterized by elevated abdominal pressure, abdominal pain, distention, oliguria, and hypotension following blunt abdominal trauma. Intra-abdominal pressure (IAP) is 36 mmHg, which belongs to grade IV intra-abdominal hypertension and should be managed by emergent bedside laparotomy for decompression.

Any acute process in the abdomen such as trauma, intestinal perforation, peritonitis, or acute pancreatitis can increase the intra-abdominal pressure. Increased abdominal pressure can diminish the blood flow to the abdominal organs and decrease the venous return to the heart. This manifests as oliguria and hypotension.

Normally, IAP is < 8 mm Hg. Intra-abdominal hypertension (IAH) is defined as a sustained elevation in IAP > 12 mmHg. Whereas, ACS is characterized by a sustained increase in IAP ≥ 20 mmHg leading to end-organ dysfunction. Measurement of bladder (intravesical) pressure is the standard method to screen for IAH and ACS.

The degree of organ dysfunction increases with the grade of IAH. Most patients with grade III IAH and all patients with grade IV IAH require abdominal decompression. Hence, emergent bedside laparotomy is the most appropriate next step in management to relieve the elevated intra-abdominal pressure and prevent further organ damage. 

Other options:

Option A: Fluid resuscitation is a standard initial approach in managing hypovolemic shock, especially after trauma. However, in the context of ACS, excessive fluids without adequate decompression can worsen the condition.

Option B: Obtaining a CECT scanning may not be feasible in an unstable patient as ACS is a clinical diagnosis, and a delay for imaging could be detrimental. Immediate intervention is required in suspected ACS to prevent organ damage and improve outcomes.

Option D: Antibiotics can be considered based on clinical suspicion or culture results but are not the primary intervention for ACS.

Related Pearl: Physiological Consequences of Increased Intra-abdominal Pressure

Decreased :

  • Cardiac output
  • Venous return
  • Visceral blood ﬂow
  • Renal blood ﬂow
  • Glomerular filtration

Increased :

  • Cardiac rate
  • Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure
  • Peak inspiratory pressure
  • Central venous pressure
  • Intrapleural pressure
  • Systemic vascular resistance

questions.text: On assessing a patient in psychiatry OPD, you ask him "What is your name?". He replies " game, frame, some shame, lame, blame.." and continues telling such rhyming words which are unrelated to each other. This thought disorder falls under which of the following category?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario in which a patient speaks continuous irrelevant rhyming words is suggestive of clang association which is a disorder of stream of thought, as per Fish's classification of thought disorders.

Clang associations are thoughts in which the logical connection may be missing and the words are related only by the sound of words like rhyming or assonance than by their meaning. Such type of thought disorder is seen in disorders like schizophrenia and mania. 

Related Pearl: Classification of disorders of thought

Related Pearl: Disorders of thought and perception

DISORDERS OF THOUGHT

DISORDER OF STREAM OF THOUGHT

(A) Disorder of tempo

(i) Flight of Ideas

Continuous flow of rapid speech that jumps from topic to topic

  • "I like mangoes, the weather is nice, India is great"

(ii) Retardation of thinking

Slow speed of speech and a prolonged latent period before a response

  • "I went to the market (pause)......... the shop was closed"

(iii) Circumstantialities

Inclusion of irrelevant details and going on in a roundabout manner, but their thought ultimately reaches the answer

  • Doctor: "How did you get that bruise?"

  • Patient: "I woke up and had a cup of coffee, read the newspaper and went for a walk. It was a wonderful day in the park. I returned home and watched the TV. I took a nap in the afternoon after lunch. I slipped and fell in the bathroom. The fall gave me this bruise."

(iv) Clang associations

Jumping from one word to another irrelevant rhyming word

  • I am Sam...I like jam...I travel in a tram"

(B) Disorder of continuity

(i) Perseveration

Repetition of out of context words, phrases, or ideas beyond the point of relevance.

  • Q1. What's your name?: "Rahul"

  • Q2. Where are you from?: "Rahul"

  • Q3. How old are you?: "Rahul"

(ii) Thought blocking

A sudden disruption of thought or a break in the flow of ideas

  • "I went to the market (extreme silence)...................."

DISORDER OF FORM OF THOUGHT

(i) Tangentiality

In response to a question, the patient gives a reply that is appropriate to the general topic but does not answer the question exactly. The speech moves away from the actual answer.

  • Doctor: "Have you had any trouble sleeping lately?"
  • Patient: "I usually sleep in my bed, but now I'm sleeping on the sofa"

(ii) Derailment

A breakdown in both the logical connection between ideas and the overall sense of goal-directedness. The words make sentences, but the sentences do not make sense.

  • "Some people just don't understand why I had breakfast in America during the first world war"

(iii) Neologisms

Bringing in new words that do not exist.

  • The world is not 'gooder' for people like me"

(iv) Desultory thoughts

Speech is grammatically correct, however, sudden unrelated ideas force their way in from time to time.

  • My actual problem is that the people never understand me and my stomach feels like an empty bucket"

(v) Word salad

Using a mixture of unintelligible meaningless words and sentences

  • Tree bus rain food home car tiger"

DISORDER OF POSSESSION OF THOUGHT
A. Thought alienation

(i) Thought insertion

Thoughts are being inserted into the patient's mind and they recognize them as being foreign and coming from without any stimulus

  • "I have repeated thoughts of killing my neighbors and I believe aliens are putting these ideas into my head at night"

(ii) Thought withdrawal

Delusion that someone or something is removing from one's mind and the patient has no power over this.

  • "Lately, I am losing all my memories and I believe that the 'government agents' are stealing them when I go to sleep"

(iii) Thought broadcasting

Belief that one's thoughts are quietly escaping from one's mind and that other people might be able to access them and hear or see them.

  • "I believe my exact thoughts appear on the TV and the internet and I think I can broadcast them globally" 

(iv) Thought echo

Patient hears the 'echo' of his own thoughts in the form of a voice after he has made the thought.

  • "I thought of making a sandwich in the morning and surprisingly a voice, from nowhere, told me to make a sandwich out loud" 

 B. Obsessions and Compulsions

1. Obsessions

Recurrent and persistent thoughts, impulses. or images that cause distress to oneself.

  • Fear of dirt or contamination
  • Fear of becoming ill
  • Constant thoughts of a certain number
  • Need for symmetry or exactness
  • Worry about whether something has been done "right"
  • Forbidden sexual or religious thoughts

2. Compulsions

Repetitive behaviors or actions that the person feels driven to perform in response to an obsession

  • Washing hands
  • Blinking eyes
  • Counting items, such as currency
  • Checking to see if doors are locked
  • Arranging items in a certain way
  • Requiring constant approval from people around them

 
 DISORDER OF CONTENT OF THOUGHT

(i) Phobias

Persistent fear of an object or situation, typically disproportional to the actual danger posed, in which the sufferer goes to great lengths in avoiding it

  • Arachnophobia - fear of spider
  • Barophobia - fear of gravity
  • Cynophobia - fear of dogs
  • Hemophobia - fear of blood
  • Nosocomephobia - fear of hospitals

(ii) Religious preoccupations

Thoughts involving religious themes or subject matter.

  • "I get instructions from God on how to make my country great"

(iii) Ideas of hopelessness

Thoughts of complete despair where the patient strongly believes that the circumstances will never get better for him.

  • "I am never going to pass my final exams, no matter how hard I study"

(iv) Antisocial urges

Thoughts of indulging in some behaviors or actions that harm or lack consideration for the well being of others.

  • "I have these urges to go rob a bank or blackmail my neighbors for their money"

(v) Delusions

False beliefs that are strongly held and unchangeable in the face of refuting evidence and that are not consistent with the person's educational, social and cultural background.

The three main criteria for a belief to be considered a delusion are:

  • Certainty (held with complete confidence)
  • Incorrigibility (not changeable by proof to the contrary)
  • Impossibility or falsity of content (implausible, bizarre or patently untrue)
 DISORDERS OF PERCEPTIONS

  • Illusion: Misinterpretation of real external stimuli.

  • Hallucination: False sensory perception, externally.

  • Pseudohallucination: False sensory perception from within and having an insight.

  • Depersonalization: Feeling as if one is disconnected from reality, feeling detached from one's own thoughts and one's own physical body.

    "I sometimes drift into a dream-like state where I lose contact with my own self"

  • Derealization: Alteration in the perception or experience of the external world so that it seems unreal.

    "The world and everything around is nothing but just a dream"

questions.text: A patient who is posted for renal transplant in 5 hours is started on an interleukin- 2 receptor antagonist to prevent acute transplant rejection. Which of the following drugs would have likely been given?
questions.solution:
Basiliximab is the interleukin-2 receptor antagonist that would have been likely given.

It is otherwise known as the anti-CD25 antibody and is a murine-human chimeric monoclonal antibody that acts by inhibiting T-cell activation and proliferation, but does not induce cell lysis. It is used prophylactically to prevent acute solid-organ rejection. 

Basiliximab is used with a maintenance regimen consisting of cyclosporine and prednisone. It is also effectively used in a maintenance regimen consisting of cyclosporine, Mycophenolate mofetil, and prednisone. Lymphoproliferative disorders and anaphylactic reactions may occur rarely as adverse effects.

Other options:

Option A: Sirolimus is an mTOR inhibitor and arrests the immune response at a later stage than cyclosporine. It can be used alone or in combination with cyclosporine or corticosteroid and mycophenolate mofetil. It is not recommended for a liver transplant. 

Option C: Cyclosporine is a calcineurin inhibitor and is highly effective in preventing graft rejection reactions. However, it is nephrotoxic.

Option D: Alemtuzumab is a humanized IgG1 that binds to CD52 found on normal and malignant B and T lymphocytes, NK cells, monocytes, macrophages, and a small population of granulocytes. It is used for the treatment of B-cell chronic lymphocytic leukemia, relapsing and remitting multiple sclerosis and as an off-label in kidney transplant.

questions.text:
The body of 70-year-old male was brought to the hospital for autopsy. The forensic experts decided to do a virtual autopsy before performing a normal autopsy. Which of the following modalities is not used for this?

CT: Computed tomography

MRI: Magnetic Resonance Imaging
questions.solution:
Ultrasonography is not used for virtual autopsy.

Virtual autopsy is a non-invasive method to investigate the cause of death of a person. It combines photogrammetry(option B), 3D optical measuring, and CT and MR imaging(option D). CT images provide details about abnormal anatomical findings, while MR images show soft tissue damage, organ trauma, and the condition of blood vessels, tissue, and bones. When determining injuries from firearms, explosions, charred bodies, decomposed bodies, child abuse, fractured bones, sex, and age, multi-slice compound tomography (MSCT)(option C), multi-planar reconstruction (MPR), and volume rendering technique (VRT) are used.

Photogrammetry is a technique used to obtain 3D information from two dimensional images or video footage. It involves taking multiple overlapping photographs of an object or scene from different angles and then using software to analyze the images and reconstruct the 3D geometry and textures. 

Advantages of a virtual autopsy:

  • Conditions like emphysema, air embolism, and pneumothorax can be better appreciated.
  • In injuries caused by weapons, a computer software can create a virtual model of the injury by using a simulation of a similar weapon.
  • In firearm injuries, entrance and exit wounds can be identified by the fracture pattern and bevelling of the bone.
  • It avoids destruction of some important evidence which maybe destroyed in a usual autopsy

questions.text: The given ocular finding is seen due to the accumulation of calcium in the cornea. Which of the following is not a cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The ocular finding depicted here is suggestive of band-shaped keratopathy and multiple sclerosis is not a cause of this condition. Multiple sclerosis causes optic neuritis.

Band-shaped keratopathy(BSK) is a corneal degenerative condition associated with the deposition of calcium salts in the deeper layers of corneal epithelium, Bowman's membrane and superficial part of the stroma.

Causes of band-shaped keratopathy are -

Local causes Systemic causes associated with hypercalcemia

Chronic keratitis
Chronic uveitis
Chronic glaucoma
Pthisis bulbi
Ocular trauma
Still's disease (Juvenile idiopathic arthritis)		 Hyperparathyroidism
Vitamin D toxicity
Hyperuricemia
Hyperphosphatemia
Chronic renal failure
Sarcoidosis

 

lt typically presents as a band-shaped opacity in the interpalpebral zone with a clear interval between the ends of the band and the limbus. The condition begins at the periphery and gradually progresses towards the centre. Surface of this opaque band is stippled due to holes in the calcium plaques in the area of nerve canals of Bowman's membrane.

Treatment includes initially scraping of corneal epithelium under local anesthesia followed by chelation therapy with EDTA. 0.01 molar solution of EDTA solution is applied to the cornea with the help of a cotton swab for 10 minutes. Eye padding and bandage are then applied for 2-3 days to allow the epithelium to regenerate. 

Other treatment options include phototherapeutic keratectomy(PTK)with excimer laser and keratoplasty for loss of vision.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old male patient came to the outpatient department with complaints of hematuria. Cystoscopic biopsy of the bladder shows non-invasive papillary cancer and a subsequent MRI reveals a 2x2 cm bladder mass with no evidence of muscle invasion. Which among the following is the ideal management?

TURBT: Transurethral resection of bladder tumor

choices.text: TURBT followed by Intravesical mitomycin C

questions.solution:
The pathological stage in this patient is pTa - non-muscle invasive papillary urothelial cancer of bladder for which the treatment is Transurethral resection of bladder tumor (TURBT) followed by intravesical mitomycin C.

Approximately 30% of patients with non muscle invasive bladder cancer (NMIBC) will experience early recurrence following initial TURBT and so an immediate post-TURBT dose of mitomycin C should be instilled into the bladder. This has been shown to reduce the risk of tumour recurrence.

Bladder cancer is the fourth most common non dermatological cancer in men, with cigarette smoking being the main aetiological factor. Other risk factors include exposure to aniline dyes and schistosomiasis. Patients present with painless gross hematuria and frequency and urgency of urine.

CT urogram is used to assess the upper urinary tract, lymph node metastasis and the presence of hydroureteronephrosis. MRI of the bladder is useful in assessing whether or not the muscle layer of the bladder is involved. 

pT stage: Pathological stage:

pT stage Extent of the tumor
Tx Primary tumor cannot be assessed
T0 No evidence of primary tumor

Tis Carcinoma in situ
T1 Tumor invades subepithelial connective tissue (lamina propria)
T2 Tumor invades detrusor muscle (muscularis propria)
T3 Tumor invades perivesical tissue 
T4 Tumor invades any of the following: Prostate, uterus, vagina, pelvic wall and abdominal wall 

Treatment of carcinoma bladder:

Non-muscle invasive tumors - 

For those with multifocal high-grade T1 tumors with CIS, an early radical cystectomy should be discussed as they are at high risk of tumor progression. An alternative is intravesical bacillus Calmette–Guérin (BCG) to reduce the risk of tumor progression. Those with solitary low-grade Ta tumors have the lowest risk of recurrence and progression and so the management of this group consists of regular cystoscopic surveillance alone. For intermediate-risk tumors, a 6-week course of intravesical mitomycin C can be considered to reduce the risk of recurrence.

Muscle-invasive tumors - The standard treatment for muscle-invasive tumors is radical cystectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy with urinary diversion. Systemic chemotherapy with M-VAC (Methotrexate, vinblastine, doxorubicin, and cisplatin) has been shown to be beneficial.

questions.text:
After being told that the maximum amount of solutes is reabsorbed in the PCT, a researcher plots the following curves. Which of the following would be indicative of the osmolarity of the tubular fluid along the length of the PCT?

PCT: Proximal convoluted tubule
questions.solution:
Curve B would be indicative of the osmolarity of the tubular fluid along the length of the PCT.

Nearly 60% of the filtered sodium and water is reabsorbed in the PCT. Solutes mainly absorbed in the proximal tubule are sodium, chloride, bicarbonate, phosphate, lactate, glucose, and amino acids. Although the amount of sodium in the tubular fluid decreases markedly along the proximal tubule, the concentration of sodium and the total osmolarity (or total solute concentration) remain relatively constant. This is because the proximal tubule is highly permeable to water and water reabsorption increases to keep pace with the sodium reabsorption. 

This is demonstrated in the figure below. A value of 1.0 would indicate that the concentration of the substance in the tubular fluid would be equal to that in the plasma. A value >1.0 would mean that the substance is secreted into the tubular fluid or reabsorbed relatively less than water, such as chloride, urea, and creatinine. A value <1.0 would mean that the substance is reabsorbed relatively more than water, such as bicarbonate, glucose, and amino acids.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl was brought to the clinic by her mother with complaints of frequent upper respiratory tract infections. Her mother said that the girl also had a tendency for easy bruising. After thorough investigations, a diagnosis of Chediak-Hegashi syndrome was made. What is the defect in this disorder?

choices.text: Defect in both T cells and B cells

questions.solution:
Chediak-Higashi syndrome involves a defect in the process of phagocytosis. 

Chediak-Higashi syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder due to defects in the lysosomal transport protein LYST —a protein required for the normal packaging and distribution of granules (encoded by CHS1 gene). This defect results in defective chemotaxis, phagolysosome fusion, degranulation of T-cells and NK cells, and ADP granule function in platelets. 

Clinically, patients with Chediak-Higashi syndrome may present with-

  • Persistent skin, respiratory and gastro-intestinal infections- Especially due to staphylococcus aureus.
  • Partial oculo-cutaneous albinism.
  • Platelet dysfunction- There is increased bleeding time leading to easy bruising and excessive bleeding, however, the platelet count is normal.
  • Neurological dysfunction- Progressive peripheral neuropathy, nystagmus, mental retardation.
  • Accelerated phase with lymphoma-like illness and hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis — a life-threatening condition that is characterized by high prolonged fever, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, and cytopenia and carries a very poor prognosis.

Diagnosis is done by detecting the presence of peroxidase-positive giant primary granules in neutrophils and other granule-bearing cells on Wright’s stain. Genetic detection may be confirmatory. 

Other options:

Option A: Disorders of complement system, such as  C1 inhibitor deficiency, results in hereditary angioedema.

Option B: Combined defect in both B cells and T cells result in severe combined immunodeficiency syndrome (SCID).

Option C: Disorders of T cells include conditions such as Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome and DiGeorge syndrome. Disorders of B cells include conditions such as hyper IgM syndrome and IgA deficiency. 

The image below shows a neutrophil in Chediak Higashi Syndrome showing polymorphonuclear leukocytes with abundant giant intracytoplasmic granules:

  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia

questions.text:
A 68-year-old male patient is brought by his daughter after claiming to have seen a snake on multiple occasions even though one was not present. He has had difficulty with performing daily activities for the past 8 months. Examination reveals bradykinesia and rigidity. No personality changes were observed. MMSE score is 20 with relative sparing of memory. What is the most likely diagnosis?

MMSE - mini-mental state examination
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a case of Lewy-body dementia.

Fluctuating cognition, visual hallucinations, and motor symptoms of Parkinson's like bradykinesia and rigidity are the core features that help in the diagnosis of this disease. Characteristically, dementia in this condition develops very early and usually within 1 year of the onset of motor symptoms. Memory is usually spared in this condition.  MMSE score of less than 24 out of 30 indicates impaired cognitive function. 

Dementia with Lewy bodies is a progressive neurodegenerative associated with dementia, psychosis, and features of Parkinsonism. It is characterized by the protein deposition of Lewy bodies in the substantia nigra, limbic system, and cerebral cortex, comprising α-synuclein and ubiquitin. It is the third most common type of dementia after Alzheimer's disease and vascular dementia.

The clinical features of dementia with Lewy bodies are characterized by visual hallucinations, features of Parkinsonism, neuroleptic sensitivity, REM (rapid eye movement) sleep disorder, and excessive daytime sleepiness. They can also present with delirium and orthostatic hypotension. Memory is usually preserved in patients with Lewy body dementia. If a typical antipsychotic is prescribed for hallucinations and mild cognitive deficits, it can result in profound extrapyramidal adverse effects due to the sensitivity to neuroleptic agents. The features of Parkinsonism would include bradykinesia, resting tremor, and cog-wheel rigidity.

Dementia or neuropsychiatric conditions emerge concurrently with parkinsonism features in dementia with Lewy bodies whereas Parkinson's disease dementia occurs in long-standing cases of Parkinson's disease. Recently it has been decided that if dementia or any cognitive disability occurs after 12 months of Parkinson's disease, then the disorder is most likely Parkinson's disease dementia.

The pharmacotherapy would include cholinesterase inhibitors like rivastigmine, galantamine, and donepezil to treat the cognitive impairments. Other medications include antidepressants, and low-potency atypical antipsychotics to treat depression and hallucinations respectively.

Other options:

Option A- No history of personality changes rules out frontotemporal dementia.

Option B- Alzheimer's disease is ruled out as the memory is intact in the patient.

Option C- Parkinson's disease dementia is dementia occurring in long-standing cases of Parkinson's disease. It causes impairment of memory, attention, visual perception, hallucinations, and depression. It is diagnosed along with a prior diagnosis of Parkinson's disease and the onset of dementia occurring after 12 months of motor dysfunction of Parkinson's disease.

Note - Hallucinations in Parkinson's disease dementia occur late in Parkinson's disease and is seen after medication use.

questions.text: A pregnant woman who was in preterm labor was infused with an oxytocin receptor antagonist. Which of the following drugs was she likely administered?
questions.solution:
The oxytocin receptor antagonist that would have likely been administered to her is the tocolytic atosiban.

Tocolytics are drugs that suppress uterine contractions of preterm labor. Atosiban acts as an oxytocin receptor antagonist and inhibits preterm labor at 24-33 weeks of gestation.

Tocolytics can be effective only if administered before cervical dilatation reaches 4 cm and the lower uterine segment is taken up minimally. Other tocolytics that are used to delay premature labor:

  • Beta-2 agonists - ritodrine, terbutaline, isoxsuprine
  • Calcium channel blockers - nifedipine
  • Magnesium sulfate - It is a tocolytic as well as a first-line drug that is used in pre-eclampsia and eclampsia. 
  • Indomethacin

questions.text: A postpartum woman developed a severe headache and lactational failure. MRI revealed enlarged pituitary with a hemorrhagic infarct. She does not have any visual disturbance, ophthalmoplegia, or impaired consciousness. What is the most-likely management in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and MRI findings is suggestive of pituitary apoplexy in a post-partum woman. Since there is no evidence of visual loss or impaired consciousness, the most likely management in this case would be high-dose glucocorticoids.

Pituitary apoplexy is damage to the pituitary gland and the surrounding structures as a result of acute intrapituitary hemorrhagic vascular events. It occurs spontaneously, as in pre-existing adenoma or in postpartum cases (Sheehan's syndrome) or in association with other systemic diseases like diabetes mellitus, systemic hypertension, sickle cell anemia, and acute shock. 

Postpartum apoplexy is due to the hyperplastic enlargement of the pituitary gland (occuring normally in pregnant woman), which poses an increased risk for haemorrhage. Clinical features include:

  • Headache with signs of meningeal irritation
  • Lactational failure
  • Bilateral visual changes
  • Ophthalmoplegia
  • Cardiovascular collapse (shock) 
  • Hypoglycemia or diabetes mellitus
  • Loss of consciousness

Investigation of choice: MRI or CT shows signs of intratumoral or sellar hemorrhage, with pituitary stalk deviation and compression of pituitary tissue.

Treatment :

  • No signs of visual disturbances or loss of consciousness - high dose glucocorticoids
  • Signs of progressive visual loss, cranial nerve palsy, or loss of consciousness present - urgent surgical decompression

Note: Hypopituitarism follows pituitary apoplexy.

questions.text: Which of the following complications is least likely to be associated with this placental variant?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the circumvallate placenta. It is a type of extrachorial placentation and is caused when the chorionic plate is smaller than the basal plate. It has raised placental membranes. 

If the blood vessels are present over the internal os in front of the presenting part, it is called vasa previa. Vasa previa is associated with the velamentous placenta in which the cord is attached to the membranes. 

Complications associated with circumvallate placenta:

  • Abortion
  • Antepartum hemorrhage
  • Hydrorrhea gravidarum
  • Intrauterine growth restriction
  • Preterm delivery
  • Retained placenta or membranes

Extrachorial placentation: the chorionic plate is smaller than the basal plate. There are two types of extrachorial placentation:

  • Circummarginate placenta - In this type, the space between the fetal membranes and the basal plate is filled up by fibrin and old hemorrhage with a smooth margin.
  • Circumvallate placenta - In this type, the peripheral chorion is thickened into a ridge composed of a double fold of chorion and amnion.

questions.text: A 53-year-old male patient was admitted to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. On examination, paradoxical respiration was seen. His chest X-ray is shown below. He was given analgesics and oxygen was administered via face mask but he developed respiratory failure. What is the best line of management of this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario alongwith the X-ray showing contiguous rib fractures on the right side suggest Flail chest.

Flail chest is characterized by contiguous rib fractures and paradoxical respiration following blunt trauma to the chest wall. Mechanical ventilation (like Intermittent Positive Pressure Ventilation) is the management of flail chest with respiratory failure.

Flail Chest :

  • A flail chest occurs when a segment of the chest wall does not have bony continuity with the rest of the thoracic cage.
  • This condition results from blunt trauma associated with multiple rib fractures, i.e. 2 adjacent ribs or 3 or more ribs fractured in two or more places.
  • The blunt force required to disrupt the integrity of the thoracic cage typically produces an underlying pulmonary contusion as well.

Clinical Features:

On inspiration, the loose segment of the chest wall is displaced inwards and less air, therefore, moves into the lungs. On expiration, the segment moves outwards(paradoxical respiration).

Diagnosis - To confirm the diagnosis the chest wall can be observed for the paradoxical motion of a chest wall segment for several respiratory cycles and during coughing. Voluntary splinting as a result of pain, mechanically impaired chest wall movement, and the associated lung contusion are all causes of hypoxia and respiratory failure.

The patient is also at high risk of developing a pneumothorax or hemothorax.

Treatment

  • Chest strapping or splinting should be avoided
  • Currently, treatment consists of oxygen administration, adequate analgesia (including opiates) or epidural analgesia and physiotherapy.
  • IPPV (Intermittent Positive Pressure Ventilation) is reserved for cases developing respiratory failure despite adequate analgesia and oxygen.

Other options:

Option A: Chest tube drainage can be done in traumatic pulmonary contusion associated with pneumothorax or hemothorax

Option B: Intrapleural local analgesia can be given if the patient has a chest tube inserted. Since the chest tube drainage is only done after stabilising the patient, intrapleural analgesia is not the best line of treatment at this stage.

Option D: Surgical fixation of the fracture is done only in patients with severe chest injury and pulmonary contusion. Also, surgery should be proceeded only after the patient's condition is stabilised.

questions.text: A neonate shortly after birth by normal vaginal delivery, develops petechiae and purpura. You suspect a bleeding disorder and on work-up, Bernard-Soulier syndrome is diagnosed. What is the etiology of this syndrome?
questions.solution:
The likely etiology of the given clinical condition is GpIb-IX deficiency seen in Bernard-Soulier syndrome.

Bernard–Soulier syndrome is an autosomal recessive functional/qualitative platelet disorder. It is characterized by the deficiency of Gp Ib-IX receptor causing defective platelet adhesion. It is due to genetic mutations in the genes forming the GPIb complex of glycoproteins Ibα, Ibβ, V, and IX.

It is characterised by petechiae and purpura at birth, along with prolonged bleeding time(BT), normal platelet count, normal PT and aPTT. Additionally, the presence of large platelets differentiates Bernard-Soulier syndrome from Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia, where the platelets are normal in size.

Other options -

Option B - GpIIb-IIIa complex deficiency leads to Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia which is another congenital platelet function disorder characterized by defective platelet aggregation.

Option C - Deficiency of factor VIII leads to hemophilia A. It is an X-linked recessive disorder with symptoms of easy bruising, intramuscular hematomas, hemarthrosis, hematuria, and bleeding from minor traumatic lacerations. It is characterised by prolonged aPTT and normal PT and bleeding time.

Option D - Excessive activation of the coagulation cascade is seen in disseminated intravascular coagulation(DIC) along with excessive thrombus accumulation in the microvasculature. This leads to widespread deposition of fibrin and excessive consumption of clotting factors and platelets. Thus, causing coagulopathy.

questions.text: The graph below represents the CO2 dissociation curve of a normal person. Which of the following phenomena best explains the change of the curve from point A to point B on increasing PO2 in blood?
questions.solution:
The reason for the CO2 dissociation curve to shift from point A to point B on increasing blood PO2 is explained by Haldane effect.  

The binding of O2 with hemoglobin (Hb) displaces CO2 from the blood. This is known as the Haldane effect. It helps in the transport of CO2 from the tissues to the lungs. 

The given graph shows two CO2 dissociation curves: when the PO2 is 100 mm Hg (which is the case in the lung blood capillaries); and when the PO2 is 40 mm Hg (which is the case in the tissue capillaries). At the normal PCO2 of 45 mm Hg in the tissues (represented by point A), 52% volume of CO2 combines with the blood. Upon entering the lungs, the PCO2 falls to 40 mm Hg and the PO2 rises to 100 mm Hg. The increase in PO2 shifts the CO2 dissociation curve from the top curve to the lower curve, i.e. point B.

The Haldane effect results from the fact that the combination of O2 with Hb in the lungs causes the Hb to become a stronger acid. The more acidic Hb has less tendency to combine with CO2, thus displacing much of the CO2 that is present in the carbamino form from the blood. The increased acidity of the Hb also causes it to release an excess of H+, and these ions bind with HCO3− to form carbonic acid, which then dissociates into water and CO2, and the CO2 is released from the blood into the alveoli.

Thus, the Haldane effect approximately doubles the amount of CO2 released from the blood in the lungs and the amount picked up by the tissues.

The image below demonstrates the Haldane effect at the lungs:

Other options:

Option A: A right shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve in response to an increase in blood CO2 and hydrogen ions, enhances the release of O2 from the blood in the tissues. This enhances the oxygenation of the blood in the lungs. This is known as the Bohr effect.

Option B: The exchange of bicarbonate ions for chloride ions in the RBCs to maintain electroneutrality during the transport of CO2 is known as the Hamburger effect.

Option D: The pressure of a fixed mass of gas is inversely proportional to its volume if its temperature is kept constant is known as Boyle’s law.

questions.text: Identify the skin condition shown in this photograph of a newborn.
questions.solution:
The neonate is most likely suffering from Harlequin ichthyosis, as evidenced by the presence of armor-like skin.

It is the most devastating type of autosomal recessive congenital icthyosis. It is due to mutations of the ABCA12 gene. The gene plays a role in lamellar body formation in the stratum granulosum and desquamation of the stratum corneum. 

It presents in the neonatal period with armor‐like skin (truncal plates with fissuring). It can impair body movement and breathing. Bilateral ectropion and eclabium are present. Respiratory problems are the major cause of death due to alveolar collapse in neonates. They are also prone to skin and lung infections.

Defective lamellar bodies in the stratum granulosum seen in electron microscopy are pathognomic of Harlequin ichthyosis. In early life, constant supportive care is required. Treatment includes moisturizing cream, antibiotics, etretinate, or retinoids.

Other options - 

Option A) Ichthyosis vulgaris - The most common type of ichthyosis, involving mutations in filaggrin protein. Filaggrin is an epidermal protein that helps retain moisture in the stratum corneum. Ichthyosis is not present at birth but develops during the first months of life. The scaling usually involves the extensor surfaces of the extremities with flexural sparing. They are strongly correlated with atopic dermatitis and other forms of atopy such as allergic rhinitis, asthma, etc.

Option B) Bathing suit ichthyosis is a type of congenital ichthyosis caused by mutations in the TGM1 gene. It presents as a collodion baby at birth where the neonate is encased in a shiny parchment‐like membrane. Shedding of the collodion membrane is followed by the development of large dark grey/brownish scales affecting the trunk and the scalp, but sparing the face and extremities resembling a bathing suit. The disease tends to become worse in the summer months and improves in winter.

Option D) Lamellar ichthyosis is also a congenital ichthyosis, involving mutations in the TGM1 gene. It is characterized by large plate‐like dark‐brown hyperkeratoses covering the entire body with mild palmoplantar involvement. The extreme spectrum of lamellar ichthyosis is congenital ichthyosiform erythroderma (CIE) which is similar to erythroderma seen in psoriasis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient who is a known case of alcoholic cirrhosis presents with confusion and lethargy. He is not oriented to time or person. Examination reveals flapping tremors. The patient is started on a disaccharide laxative. What is the mechanism for its use in this condition?

choices.text: Promotes fluid secretion by epithelial cells
Converts NH3 to NH4+ to promote excretion

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with alcoholic liver cirrhosis presenting with confusion, lethargy, and flapping tremors is suggestive of hepatic encephalopathy (HE). Lactulose is a synthetic disaccharide laxative used for the management of HE. It converts NH3 to NH4+ to promote its excretion, thus reducing blood ammonia levels.

Hepatic encephalopathy is defined as a change in mental status and cognitive function that occurs in patients with chronic liver disease. In such patients, encephalopathy is precipitated by electrolyte abnormalities, volume depletion, or infection. Asterixis (flapping tremors) is found during examination on extending their arms and bending their wrists backward.

Treatment involves managing the underlying precipitating event. Lactulose forms the mainstay of management. It is a non-absorbable, disaccharide laxative that causes colonic acidification. This drop in colonic pH traps the ammonia by converting it to the ammonium ion. This is eliminated with stools. The goal of management with lactulose is to help patients have at least two to three stools per day. 

Lactulose is often combined with gut antibiotics such as rifaximin which eliminates ammonia-forming gut bacteria. Zinc supplementation is also useful without any harmful effects.

questions.text: An elderly man complains of inability to extend the fingers of his left hand. On examination, the patient was able to extend his left elbow and wrist, but cannot extend the metacarpophalangeal joints of the hand. Which among the following structures is likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of radial nerve injury. The structure marked as 4 is the radial nerve. 

The radial nerve originates from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus. It has both motor and sensory function. The motor component supplies the posterior compartment of the arm, posterior compartment of the forearm and muscles of the hand. The sensory component provides cutaneous sensations over the extensor aspect of the arm and forearm and the dorsum of the hand (over the first three fingers and the lateral half of the 4th finger).

In the the arm, the radial nerve gives out motor branches to supply the triceps brachii, anconeus, brachioradialis and extensor carpi radialis longus. Sensory branches in the arm are posterior cutaneous nerve of arm, posterior cutaneous nerve of forearm and lower lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm.

At the tip of the lateral epicondyle, the nerve divides into the superficial radial nerve and posterior interosseous nerve.

Posterior interosseus nerve provides motor supply to the supinator, extensor digitorum, extensor digiti minimi, extensor carpi ulnaris, extensor pollicis longus, extensor indicis, abductor pollicis longus, and extensor pollicis brevis. The superficial radial nerve gives sensory innervation to the extensor aspect of the forearm and dorsum of the hand.

Radial nerve is prone to nerve injuries. In lesions around the shoulder joint and axilla, extension of the elbow, wrist, and hand are lost (crutch palsy).

In high lesions like fractures of the humerus and prolonged tourniquet pressure, there is wrist drop, due to weakness of the radial extensors of the wrist, as well as inability to extend the metacarpophalangeal joints. It will also have a sensory loss on the skin over the anatomical snuff box.

Low lesions occur due to the fracture or dislocations of the elbow. The wrist and elbow extension is preserved but the patient cannot extend the metacarpophalangeal joint.

questions.text: A patient with traumatic injury to the skull is diagnosed to have an epidural hematoma. The area of impact is at the pterion, causing damage to the underlying artery. Which of the following foramen does this artery traverse through?
questions.solution:
Traumatic injury to the pterion can damage the underlying anterior branch of the middle meningeal artery. The middle meningeal artery enters the middle cranial fossa through the foramen spinosum, labeled as 3 in the image.

The structures passing through the foramen spinosum are:

  • Middle meningeal artery
  • Nervus spinosus 
  • Middle meningeal vein

The pterion is an H-shaped sutural junction that overlies the anterior branch of the middle meningeal artery and the lateral fissure of the cerebral hemisphere. The bone in this area is thin and any injury to this area may lead to rupture of the middle meningeal artery leading to extradural hematoma. 

The four bones forming the pterion are:

  • Frontal bone
  • Squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Greater wing of the sphenoid bone
  • Parietal bone


The foramina marked in the image are:

3 - Foramen spinosum

questions.text: A young patient presents with painless central loss of vision. On evaluation, the Arden’s index is reduced and fundus examination is as below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a young patient presenting with painless central loss of vision (macular pathology) with reduced Arden’s index and egg-yolk appearance in the macular region suggests Best’s disease.

Best's disease also known as vitelliform macular dystrophy is an autosomal dominant macular dystrophy in which lipofuscin accumulates in the central macula, causing progressive central vision loss. It is primarily a cone dystrophy linked to bestrophin(VMD2) gene mutations. 

Clinical features are hemeralopia (day/bright light  blindness) and central scotoma. Ocular findings include vitelliform(yolk like) appearance of the fundus and abnormal electrooculogram(EOG) with relatively normal electroretinogram(ERG).

EOG reveals reduced Arden’s index. Arden index is the ratio of the light peak over the dark trough in EOG. An Arden index value of above 185 is considered normal and below 150 is abnormal. 

Other options:

Option A: Stargardt’s disease is an autosomal recessive disorder and it is the most common juvenile macular dystrophy. It is also a cone dystrophy characterised by lipofuscin accumulation within the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE). Clinical features are hemeralopia and central scotoma as like Best disease.

Characteristic features include a fundus image of beaten-bronze macular atrophy surrounded by lipofuscin flecks and a silent choroid/dark choroid on fundus fluorescein angiography(FFA).

Option C: Retinitis pigmentosa is a pigmental retinal dystrophy where the photoreceptors, especially rods are affected. Most of them are hereditary and show autosomal dominant inheritance. Night blindness is a characteristic feature. Tubular vision is seen in advanced cases. 

Retinal pigmentary changes on fundus examination reveal jet-black spots resembling bone corpuscles.

Option D: Macular hole (MH) is a vitreoretinal interface disease characterized by a partial or full-thickness neurosensory retinal defect in the centre of the macula. Females are more commonly involved (F: M=3:1) in their sixth or seventh decade of life. 

Fundus showing a full-thickness macular hole with a surrounding cuff of subretinal fluid confirms the diagnosis. Other features include, FFA showing early foveal hyperfluorescence without a leak and the presence of full-thickness macular hole in optical coherence tomography (OCT).

questions.text: You are an intern posted in anesthesia. Your senior resident is performing a procedure which lasts less than 20 minutes. She asks you to load an intermediate-acting non-depolarising neuromuscular blocker. Which of the following agents will you prefer for the procedure?
questions.solution:
Vecuronium is an intermediate-acting, non-depolarising neuromuscular blocker. Thus, the first sign of recovery after vecuronium administration would be seen about 20-50 minutes from administering this agent.

Vecuronium is an N-demethylated derivative of pancuronium. The molecular modification results in the following:

  • Increased potency 
  • Reduced vagolytic properties and devoid of significant cardiovascular effects. It is the most cardiostable muscle relaxant, making it the muscle relaxant of choice in cardiac patients.
  • Molecular instability when in solution
  • Increased lipid solubility, leading to greater biliary elimination 

Sugammadex can be used to reverse the neuromuscular blockade action of vecuronium like rocuronium.

Other options:

Option B: Succinylcholine is a depolarising neuromuscular blocker.

Options C & D: Pancuronium is a long-acting agent (>50 mins) and Gantacurium is an ultra-short-acting agent (<10 mins).

Related Pearl: Types of muscle relaxants

There are 2 types of muscle relaxants: depolarizing and non-depolarizing.

Depolarizing Muscle Relaxant- Succinylcholine

Non-Depolarizing Muscle Relaxants:

  • Ultra short-acting (<10 minutes) - Gantacurium
  • Short-acting (10-20 minutes) - Mivacurium
  • Intermediate-acting (20-50 minutes)
    • Atracurium
    • Cisatracurium
    • Vecuronium
    • Rocuronium
  • Long-acting (>50 minutes)
    • Pancuronium
    • Doxacurium
    • Pipecuronium

Related Pearl: High yield in muscle relaxants

  • Shortest acting non-depolarizing muscle relaxant:
    • Gantacurium (Not FDA approved)
    • Mivacurium: 12-20 minutes. (FDA approved)
  • Shortest acting depolarizing muscle relaxant: Succinylcholine (3-6 minutes)
  • Muscle relaxant having the maximum duration of action: Doxacurium (benzylisoquinoline) > Pancuronium (Aminosteroid)
  • Muscle relaxant causing pain on IV injection site: Rocuronium
  • Muscle relaxant which crosses placenta: Gallamine
  • Muscle relaxant acting directly on muscle: Dantrolene
  • Muscle relaxants with central action: benzodiazepine, mephenesin, baclofen, carisoprodol, metaxalone
  • Muscle relaxant and mode of clearance:
    • Hepatic clearance: Pancuronium, rapacuronium and vecuronium
    • Biliary clearance: Vecuronium and rocuronium
    • Renal clearance: Doxacurium, pancuronium, vecuronium, and pipecuronium
  • Muscle relaxant with sympathetic stimulation:
    • Gallamine
    • Pancuronium
  • Muscle relaxant with vagolytic activity:
    • Gallamine
    • Pancuronium
    • Rocuronium (mild)

questions.text: A 55 year old male diagnosed with colorectal cancer is posted for colectomy. He is set to undergo another procedure concurrently, where part of the ileum is brought to the skin surface. Choose the correct statement about this procedure.

choices.text: Performed in the left iliac fossa
End should be flush with skin
24hr output prior to discharge should be  >1 litre

questions.solution:
The proposed surgery is ileostomy, and hyponatremia is a known complication following the surgery.

An ileostomy is a procedure done in the right iliac fossa(option A), where the ileum is brought through the rectus abdominis muscle. Ileostomies are generally favored for fecal diversion after colectomy.

The ileostomy effluent is usually liquid and empties continuously. Hence ileostomy patients are more likely to develop dehydration and electrolyte problems like hyponatremia (option C), which is a frequent reason for hospital readmission following an elective colorectal surgery. Hence, prior to hospital discharge, one should ensure that the 24-hour stoma output is less than 1000 mL.

Ileostomies also have a high rate of chemical dermatitis due to the more alkaline pH associated with small bowel effluent, which is why the end of the ileum is spouted (option B), rather than flush with the skin.

Ileostomy and colostomy are the two most common types of artificial stomas for the GI system.

Ileostomy Colostomy
Any portion of the entire ileum can be chosen for stoma creation Only mobile parts of the colon (transverse colon and sigmoid colon) can be used
Gross appearance - margin of the stoma is elevated (pouting) from the skin  Gross appearance - flush to the skin
The output is liquid in nature and therefore higher in volume The output is semi-solid or solid in nature
Higher chance of skin excoriation and electrolyte imbalance Higher chance of parastomal hernia

questions.text: A 55-year-old multiparous woman presented with a mass descending from the vagina. On examination, a bulge is seen in the anterior vaginal wall as shown in the image below. The patient also reports difficulty in emptying her bladder completely. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the image showing bulge in the anterior vaginal wall indicates that the bladder is bulging into the vagina and is consistent with the diagnosis of cystocele.

The descent of one or more of the genital organs below their normal anatomical position is called pelvic organ prolapse (POP). It occurs when the muscles and tissues that support the pelvic organs become weakened or damaged, leading to one or more organs bulging into the vaginal canal. 

Clinical types:

1. Vaginal prolapse

a) Anterior vaginal wall

  • Upper two-thirds – Cystocele
  • Lower one-third – Urethrocele

b) Posterior vaginal wall

  • Upper one-third – Enterocele
  • Lower two-thirds – Rectocele

2. Uterine descent

Treatment options may include pessary, pelvic floor exercises or surgery depending on the severity of prolapse.

DeLancey introduced a three-level system of genital tract supports:

  • Level I includes uterosacral and cardinal ligaments. Damage to these ligaments leads to uterine descent, enterocoele, and vault prolapse.
  • Level II includes pelvic fascia, paracolpos,arcus tendineus, pubocervical, and rectovaginal fascia. Damage to these structures leads to cystocele and rectocele.
  • Level III includes levator ani muscle and its damage leads to urethrocele, gaping introitus, and deficient perineum.

Other options:

Option A: Rectocele refers to a bulge in the lower two-thirds of the posterior vaginal wall due to weakness or damage in the rectovaginal septum. The patient may present with difficulty in passing stools.

Option B: Enterocele refers to a bulge in the upper one-third of the posterior vaginal wall when small bowel descent through the pouch of Douglas. It presents with symptoms of difficulty in completing a bowel movement and feeling of pressure, achiness or fullness in the pelvic area.

Option D: Uterine prolapse occurs when the uterus bulges into the vagina. This can cause a feeling of pressure in the pelvic areas. The presenting symptoms include mass protruding outside the vagina, which is aggravated by straining or coughing.

Related Pearl: DeLancey's levels of support of the genital organs

Level 3

questions.text: A 60-year-old man who lost his wife 2 months back was brought to the OPD. He complains of feeling low whenever he thinks of his wife and has lost interest in daily activities. He does not have any suicidal ideations and experiences moments where he is motivated to move on. He mentioned that he had heard his wife's voice once while alone at home. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The scenario described here, after the loss of a loved one, is a normal grief reaction. This reaction also occurs with other losses, such as the loss of a body part, or, for younger people with a miscarriage or abortion.

Normal grief or bereavement begins immediately or a few months after the loss of a loved one. It is characterized initially by shock and denial. The signs and symptoms include feeling low, constant thoughts about the deceased, crying, irritability, and difficulties with sleep and concentration. However, the symptoms are not as pervasive as in depression. The patient's motivation to move on also points in favor of normal grief. The functional impairment is mild.

Transient hallucinations related to the deceased person (hearing the voice of the deceased occasionally) occur in certain cases of normal grief reaction and are not considered psychosis.

Other options: 

Option B: Psychotic depression is characterized by the presence of delusions and/or hallucinations along with the symptoms of depression. It reflects a poor prognosis

Option C: Delusional disorder - Delusions are false beliefs, that are firmly held despite objective and obvious contradictory proof. Other members of the culture do not share this belief. This is the most common manifestation of delusional disorders. In this scenario, the husband is aware of the fact that his wife is dead.

Option D: Schizophrenia is defined by the presence of psychosis (hallucinations, delusions, and disorganized speech) for more than 6 months. Mood symptoms are absent or present for only brief periods. 

The following pearl differentiates between features of normal grief and depression.

Related Pearl: Normal vs abnormal grief

Grief/bereavement

Sadness, tearfulness, decreased sleep, decreased appetite, decreased interest in the world

Shame and guilt are less common

Shame and guilt are common

Threaten suicide less often

Threaten suicide more often

Symptoms can last up to 1 year

Usually, return to baseline level of functioning within 2 months

Related Pearl: The 5 stages of grief model by Kübler-Ross

  • Denial - Patients may become numb and dazed at the news of their own imminent death and refuse to accept the diagnosis. 
  • Anger - Patients may get angry towards God or themselves. 
  • Bargaining - Patients may start to bargain with God or friends and doctors for a cure to buy some more time.
  • Depression - Patients may go into depression.
  • Acceptance - Patients finally accept that their death is inevitable and make further preparations (eg., making a will, etc).

questions.text: The PAGE DNA electrophoresis of the affected cell shows a step-ladder pattern. Moreover, Annexin V is positive. Which of the following molecules promote the occurrence of the type of cell death being described?
questions.solution:
A step-ladder pattern in DNA electrophoresis and positive Annexin V suggests apoptosis as the type of cell death. BAX is an pro-apoptotic factor.

The figure below represents a step ladder pattern seen in the case of apoptosis. This pattern is produced by the cleavage of genomic DNA by key apoptotic proteases-caspases. A DNA ladder is produced by the cleavage of genomic DNA between nucleosomes to generate fragments with lengths corresponding to multiple integers (approximately 180 base pairs). Annexin V is a marker for this process.

Apoptosis is defined as the programmed cell death characterized by activation of intrinsic enzymes that degrade the cells' genomic DNA, nuclear and cytoplasmic proteins.

Genes involved in the regulation of apoptosis:

  • BCL2, BCL-XL, MCL-1 are anti-apoptotic genes that keep the outer mitochondrial membrane-impermeable to death-inducing proteins. Thereby they prevent the leakage of cytochrome c and other death-inducing proteins into the cytosol.
  • BAX and BAK are pro-apoptotic factors that insert into the mitochondrial membrane and create channels that allow proteins from the inner mitochondrial membrane to leak out into the cytoplasm.
  • Initiators of apoptosis include BAD, BIM, BID, Puma, and Noxa. Their activity is upregulated and activated by sensors of cellular stress and damage.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient presented with chest pain, exertional dyspnea, and syncope. On auscultation crescendo-decrescendo early systolic murmur was heard at the second intercostal space in the right upper sternal border. The examiner performed one of the manoeuvres in dynamic auscultation which showed decreased intensity of the murmur. What could be the manoeuvre performed?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of aortic stenosis and there will be decreased intensity of the murmur on doing handgrip due to increased afterload.

Manoeuvres like sustained handgrip, simultaneous inflation of blood pressure cuffs above the systolic in both upper limbs and infusion of vasopressors increase systemic vascular resistance (afterload). Since increasing afterload will prevent blood from flowing in a normal forward path, it will increase any murmurs that are due to backwards flowing blood and decrease the ones due to forward blood flow.

Murmurs that increase in intensity on sustained handgrip:

  • Mitral regurgitation
  • Ventricular septal defect
  • Aortic regurgitation

Murmurs that decrease in intensity on sustained handgrip:

  • Aortic stenosis
  • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

Aortic stenosis is the narrowing of the aortic valve. It may be caused due to the calcification of the normal aortic valve or the congenital bicuspid valve, and rheumatic heart disease. Narrowing of the aortic valve causes a decreased stroke volume. This results in a weak pulse (Parvus) which rises slowly to a delayed peak (tardus), best appreciated in the carotid arteries.

The clinical features of AS are:

  • Exertional dyspnea: This occurs due to left ventricular (LV) diastolic dysfunction. Raised end-diastolic LV volume and reduced LV compliance lead to increased LV pressure, leading to elevation of pulmonary capillary wedge pressure.
  • Angina pectoris: This occurs due to the combination of the increased O2 needs of hypertrophied myocardium and the reduction of O2 delivery.
  • Syncope: This occurs due to the combination of decreased cardiac output and systemic arterial dilation which leads to a reduction of cerebral perfusion.

The murmur in aortic stenosis is typically an ejection systolic murmur best heard at the right second intercostal space and transmitted to the carotids.

Other options:

Option A - Passive leg raise causes increased preload which leads to an increase in the intensity of stenotic and regurgitant lesions and a decrease in the intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and mitral valve prolapse. 

Option B - Squatting causes an increase in preload and afterload which leads to an increase in the intensity of stenotic and regurgitant lesions and a decrease in the intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and mitral valve prolapse. 

Option D - Expiration causes an increase in the intensity of most left-sided murmurs.

questions.text: An elderly patient presents with complaints of fatigue and easy bruising. Peripheral smear demonstrates pancytopenia with macrocytosis and hyposegmented neutrophils. Bone marrow aspirate is hypercellular showing dyserythropoiesis with ringed sideroblasts. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with fatigue, easy bruising, peripheral smear showing pancytopenia with macrocytosis and hyposegmented neutrophils, and bone marrow examination showing dyserythropoiesis with ringed sideroblasts is suggestive of myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS). 

MDS is a hematogenous disorder characterized by bone marrow failure and cytopenias. It is a disorder seen in the elderly. Patients present with features of marrow failure such as fatigue, dyspnea, pallor, easy bruising, and increased risk for infections. 

Evaluation involves a complete blood count, peripheral smear, and bone marrow examination. The peripheral smear reveals bi- or pancytopenia with macrocytosis. Platelets are large and neutrophils are hypogranulated and hyposegmented. Bone marrow examination shows a hypercellular marrow with dyserythropoietic changes and ringed sideroblasts. There is an increase in myeloblasts. The proportion of blasts determines the disease prognosis. 

MDS has a high risk for AML transformation. Progression to leukemia is associated with a poor prognosis. Management involves the use of drugs like lenalidomide which is particularly useful in patients with chromosomal 5q deletion. Other agents used in management include erythropoietin analogs and hypomethylating agents (eg. azacitidine, decitabine). 

Related Pearl: Bone Marrow Changes in Myelodysplastic Syndrome (MDS)

The myelodysplastic syndrome can lead to dysplasia of the erythroid series, myeloid series, and megakaryocytes.

Dysplasia of erythroid series:

  • Megaloblastoid maturation - Abnormally large erythroid cells
  • Nuclear budding abnormalities - Nucleus with abnormal shape
  • Ring sideroblasts - Erythroblasts with stainable iron in the cytoplasm 

 

Dysplasia of myeloid series:

  • Neutrophils with a decreased number of secondary granules
  • Pseudo-Pelger-Hüet cells- neutrophils with only two nuclear lobes

 

Dysplasia of the megakaryocytes:

  • Megakaryocyte with single nuclear lobe
  • Pawn ball megakaryocytes- cells with multiple separate nuclei

If only one lineage is affected, then it is called single lineage dysplasia. If multiple lineages are affected, then it is called multilineage dysplasia. If the percentage of ring sideroblasts is more than 15% it is called MDS with ring sideroblasts (MDS-RS).

questions.text: A 50-year-old known diabetic and chronic smoker is brought to the hospital due to sudden onset chest pain radiating to the left arm. His cardiac troponins are elevated. His ECG shows complete heart block. Which of the following JVP waves is likely to be abnormal in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has clinical features suggestive of acute myocardial infarction and has a complete heart block. In this patient, an abnormality may be seen in 'a' wave of the JVP, labeled as 'A' in the given image.  

The 'a' wave is representative of the presystolic contraction of the right atrium. Patients with complete AV block have cannon 'a' waves in the JVP due to the contraction of atria against the closed tricuspid valve.

Causes of canon ‘a’ waves include:

  • Complete AV block
  • Ventricular tachycardia
  • Premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats

Complete heart block (Third-degree AV block): The ECG shows severe bradycardia, junctional escape rhythm, and independent P (red arrows) and QRS complexes (green arrow):

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation

Related Pearl: Types of Heart block

questions.text: During your visit to the CHC, you notice the ANM takes one frozen vial of a vaccine, as control, and another vial of the same vaccine.  She shakes both the vials and is trying to compare the rate of sedimentation of solutes in both vials. For which of the below-mentioned vaccines would you not be performing this test?
questions.solution:
The freeze damage to vaccines is detected by the Shake test. It is used for all freeze-sensitive vaccines - all the 'T-series' vaccines. The shake test is not used for the MMR vaccine.

The freeze damage to vaccines is detected by Shake test.

  • A frozen vaccine is used as a control vial and the vial suspected to be damaged by freezing is taken as the test vial.
  • Both are shaken after thawing and the rate of sedimentation is compared.
  • If the rate of sedimentation in test vial is slower than the control vial, then it is usable and has not been damaged.
  • Some of the most widely used vaccines are freeze-sensitive. Examples: Diphtheria, Tetanus, Pertussis, Liquid Haemophilus influenza type b (Hib), Hepatitis B.

Measles vaccine:

  • Strains used: 1. Edmonston Zagreb strain (most common). 

                            2. Schwartz strain.

                            3. Moraten strain.

  • Dose: 0.5ml.

  • Route: Subcutaneous.

  • Site: Right arm (usually).

  • Age of administration in National immunization schedule (India): 9 months (can be lowered to 6-9 months in epidemics and malnutrition) and 16-24 months.

  • Diluent for reconstitution: Distilled water or sterile water. (To be used within 4 hours after reconstitutuion).

  • Measles (and MMR) vaccine can lead to Toxic shock syndrome.

  • Measles vaccine is contraindicated in pregnancy.

  • Cold chain temperature for storage: +2 to +8 degree Celcius.

  • Protective efficacy: >90% with one dose; >99% with two doses.

  • Duration of protection: Life long.

  • IP of vaccine induced measles: 7 days.

  • Ideal gap between two successive doses: 6 months.

questions.text: Choose the correct option regarding the following graph.

choices.text: Point C represents the value which occurs with greatest frequency
Here the mode is greater than the mean
It is a positively skewed distribution
Point B represents the mean of the distribution

questions.solution:
This is an example of a left-skewed or negatively skewed distribution, and shows the relation between mean, median and mode as Mode>median > mean.

The relationship among the three measures of central tendency depends on the shape of the distribution. All three measures are identical in an unimodal symmetrical distribution (such as the normal distribution), so Mean=Median =Mode. In a skewed distribution, the three variables of central tendency are not equal.

In a positively skewed/ right-skewed distribution, the mode is simply the most frequently occurring score (the highest point on the curve); the mean is pulled up by the influence of a relatively small number of very high scores; and the median lies between the two, dividing the distribution into two equal areas under the curve. On the curve mean > median > mode.

Conversely, in a negatively skewed/ left-skewed distribution, the mode is again the most frequently occurring score (the highest point on the curve); the mean is pulled down by the influence of a relatively small number of very low scores; and the median lies between the two. On the curve, we find mean < median < mode.

Related Pearl: Mean, Median, Mode in Different Distribution Shapes

  • The relationship between the mean, median and mode depends upon the distribution.
  • In a unimodal symmetrical distribution like a normal distribution, all the three measures are approximately the same, as shown in Figure (2) in the following image, i.e., mean = median = mode.
  • Figure (3) in the following image shows a positively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the positive direction. In this, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode.
  • Figure (1) in the following image shows a negatively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the negative direction. In this, the mean will be smaller than the median, i.e., mean < median < mode.

Unimodal symmetrical distribution

Mean = Median = Mode

Positively (right) skewed distribution

Mean > Median > Mode

Negatively (left) skewed distribution

Mean < Median < Mode
  • As seen in the figures above, in any distribution curve, the mode is generally the highest point. The mean will be pulled up or down based on the values in the distribution. The median will lie between the mode and mean and divide the distribution in two equal halves under the curve.
  • A bimodal distribution will have two high points as shown in the image below.
  • Mathematically, the relationship between mode, median and mean in asymmetrical distributions can be given as:
    Mode = 3 median – 2 mean (or) Mean = ½ (3 median – mode).
  • Outlier is the statistical term used for an observation or value that is very distant from other observations in the distribution.
  • In a distribution with outliers, preferred measure of central tendency is the median.
  • Mode is least affected by outliers but mean is the most affected out of all the measures of location.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true with respect to viral antigen processing and presentation in an infected cell?

MHC - Major histocompatibility complex

choices.text: Occurs only in the professional antigen presenting cells
The newly synthesized viral proteins are cleaved within an endosome
The processed viral proteins are mostly associated with class II MHC molecule
The viral antigens are presented to the CD8+ T cells

questions.solution:
The viral antigens are presented to the CD8+ T cells via the cytosolic pathway of antigen processing and presentation.

There are 2 pathways of antigen processing and presentation:

  1. Cytosolic pathway - The endogenous (intracellular) antigens are cleaved within a proteasome (option B) and the cleaved fragments are associated with the class I MHC protein (option C) in the rough endoplasmic reticulum. The complex of the peptide fragment and class I MHC protein then migrates to the cell surface, where it is presented to the CD8 cytotoxic T cells. This pathway is essential for the clearance of endogenously synthesized antigens like viral proteins and tumor antigens and occurs in most of the nucleated somatic cells of the body (option A).

  2. Endocytic pathway - The exogenous antigens (extracellular microbes, toxins) are cleaved into peptide fragments within an endosome, where the fragments are associated with the class II MHC proteins. This complex then migrates to the cell surface to be presented to the CD4 helper T cells. This pathway occurs only in antigen-presenting cells such as B cells, macrophages, and dendritic cells.

Related Pearl: MHC Classes I and II

Expressed on antigen-presenting cells: macrophages, B lymphocytes, dendritic cells

Heterodimer consisting of non-covalently associated α and β chains, both of which are polymorphic.

α chains are encoded by three genes- HLA-A, HLA-B, and HLA-C

Encoded by HLA-D, with subregions: HLA-DP, HLA-DQ, and HLA-DR.

Display antigenic peptides that are derived from viral and tumor proteins

Present antigens that are internalized into vesicles, and derived from extracellular microbes

questions.text: A patient living in the coastal area presents with fever, nocturnal cough, breathlessness, and wheezing for 4 weeks. Lab investigations show an absolute eosinophil count >5000/μL along with raised IgE. Sputum and stool samples are absent for egg and larvae. Chest X-ray shows a bilateral mottling pattern. This condition can be managed with which of the following drug?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with eosinophilia, absent egg/larvae on sputum and stool samples, chest x-ray showing a mottled/miliary pattern are suggestive of Tropical Pulmonary Eosinophilia. Diethylcarbamazine (DEC) is the drug of choice for this condition.

Tropical Pulmonary Eosinophilia is a hyperresponsive pulmonary syndrome that occurs in response to trapped microfilariae within the lung parenchyma. It is a type 1 hypersensitivity reaction. 

Clinical features:The patient has a history of residence in a filaria endemic area and usually presents with nocturnal paroxysmal wheezing and cough. Other manifestations include weight loss, low-grade fever, and lymphadenopathy. Hepatosplenomegaly may be seen due to the trapping of microfilariae in the reticuloendothelial system.

Investigations:

  • Eosinophilia > 3000/μL, leukocytosis
  • X-ray chest: Mottled opacities or miliary lesions in the middle and lower lung fields, increased broncho vascular markings
  • PFT: Restrictive changes in most cases and obstructive defects in half
  • Elevated levels of IgE and Anti Filarial antibody titers
  • Microfilaria are sequestrated in the lungs and hence not found in blood

Treatment: Diethylcarbamazine(DEC) at a daily dosage of 4-6 mg/kg for 14 days. 

If the stool/sputum sample was positive for egg/larva, then diagnosis will be Loeffler's syndrome. Based on the egg/larva seen, treatment is given.

If Ascaris or Ancylostoma larva/eggs are found, then albendazole or mebendazole are indicated. If Strongyloides larva is present, then ivermectin is indicated.

questions.text: As an anaesthesia resident, you see the following curve in the capnograph. What would your next step be?

choices.text: Observation as the capnograph is normal

questions.solution:
The capnograph depicts a presentation of malignant hyperthermia. Removal of the offending agent and rapid administration of dantrolene sodium will be the next step in management.

When volatile anaesthetics or succinylcholine are used, malignant hyperthermia should be suspected in case of an unexpected rise in end-tidal CO2 ( ETCO2), This is considered to be one of the earliest and most sensitive indicators of malignant hyperthermia. It can supported by taking arterial blood gas reports with metabolic acidosis.

Malignant hyperthermia is a rare genetic hypermetabolic disease of the muscle. It occurs due to a mutation of the gene for the ryanodine receptor (Ryr 1), located on chromosome 19. It is an ion channel responsible for calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum.

The key clinical features are:

  • Succinylcholine-induced masseter muscle rigidity (causing trismus) or generalized muscle rigidity
  • Tachycardia
  • Hypercarbia (increased CO2 production) and reduced oxygen saturation
  • Hyperthermia (rise of 1° Celsius can occur every 5 minutes)
  • Arrhythmia
  • Hypertension
  • Myoglobinuria and myoglobinemia indicate muscle damage
  • Metabolic derangements like hyperkalemia and mixed metabolic and respiratory acidosis

Treatment is to discontinue the triggering agents i.e. succinylcholine followed by administration of 100% oxygen.

Dantrolene sodium is the drug of choice. It is given rapidly at a dose of 2.5 mg/ kg intravenously and can be repeated every 5-10 minutes till the attack subsides.

Metabolic acidosis and hyperkalemia need to be corrected.

Hyperthermia must be controlled by cooling the patient. 

Continuous monitoring in intensive care is required for 24 to 48 hours.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient is set to undergo a daycare procedure. Which of the following drugs should be avoided for the said procedure?
questions.solution:
Morphine would be avoided for the daycare procedure as it increases the risk of postoperative nausea and vomiting.

Morphine is a long-acting opioid and since opioids increase the risk of postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV), it should be avoided in daycare surgery. Instead, analgesics like paracetamol and other NSAIDs are preferred to manage pain in daycare procedures. 

Day surgery involves a patient being admitted and discharged for a specific procedure within a 12-hour working day. Each component of the pathway has to be safe and efficient and to be performed in sequence. This is ensured by the following measures:

  • the patient is informed and fit for the procedure
  • the procedure itself is achievable as a day case
  • the procedure is scheduled early on the operating list to allow safe recovery and discharge
  • the home environment can support a postoperative ambulatory patient.

The IV anaesthetic of choice for daycare surgery is propofol (Option A) due to its smooth induction and rapid recovery. The antiemetic action is also beneficial. Thiopental results in prolonged postoperative sedation and is not preferred in ambulatory anaesthesia, also benzodiazepines and ketamine are avoided for similar reasons.

The inhalational anaesthetic of choice for daycare surgery is sevoflurane (Option C). The low blood-gas partition coefficient, blood-brain coefficient, and minimal airway irritation of sevoflurane promote rapid induction and rapid recovery.

Sugammadex (Option D) produces a rapid and complete reversal of neuromuscular blockade produced by rocuronium or vecuronium.

Related Pearl: Types of muscle relaxants

There are 2 types of muscle relaxants: depolarizing and non-depolarizing.

Depolarizing Muscle Relaxant- Succinylcholine

Non-Depolarizing Muscle Relaxants:

  • Short-acting (10-20 minutes) - Mivacurium
  • Intermediate-acting (20-50 minutes)

    • Vecuronium
    • Rocuronium
  • Long-acting (>50 minutes)

  • Drug of choice for OPD analgesia: Alfentanyl
  • Most potent: sufentanyl
  • Shortest acting opioid-remifentanyl

BCYE: Buffered Charcoal Yeast Extract
questions.solution:
Milk ring test (MRT) is positive for Brucella. It is best cultured in Castaneda medium.

The MRT is used for the detection of infected animals in dairy farms. A sample of whole milk is mixed with a drop of Brucella antigen and incubated at 70 °C for 40–50 min.

If antibodies are present in the milk, the bacilli are agglutinated and rise with the cream to form a blue ring at the top, leaving the rest of the milk unstained (MRT positive). If antibodies are absent, the solution remains uniformly blue (MRT negative).
