questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the clinic at 17 weeks of gestational age with a history of a lump in her left breast for the past 3 months. On examination, you find a lump of 2 X 2 cm in the upper outer quadrant of her left breast. Which of the following investigations would you initially advise her for the assessment of the breast lump?
questions.solution:
Ultrasonography (USG) is the preferred initial investigation in pregnant women who present with a breast lump. It can differentiate between solid and cystic lesions of the breast and can detect abnormal axillary lymph nodes.

USG is preferred in pregnant women, lactating women, and young women (less than 40 years) since breast tissue is dense in these populations.

Other options:

Option A) Mammography is less useful in young women due to the increased density of breast tissue.

Option B) MRI is not the initial investigation used for the assessment of breast lumps. It can be used in high risk cases where metastasis or spread to other breast is suspected.

Option D) Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is not recommended in pregnant women. It is difficult to distinguish breast cancer from the normal cellular proliferation in the breast tissue due to hormonal changes.

questions.text: A patient was undergoing the following procedure for the removal of gallstones. However, it required multiple attempts to retrieve the stone. What is the commonest complication expected in such cases after the procedure?
questions.solution:
The image depicts the procedure of Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangio Pancreatography (ERCP). Pancreatitis is the most common complication of ERCP. The Pancreatitis is usually mild and resolves in a few days.

Multiple attempts at cannulation, sphincter of Oddi dysfunction or history of recurrent pancreatitis and therapeutic procedures instead of diagnostic ones impart a higher risk of pancreatitis

In this procedure, a side-viewing endoscope is passed through the pylorus of the stomach into the second part of the duodenum to visualize the papilla.

It is then cannulated, and dye is injected into the pancreatic or bile duct to visualize the pancreatic or biliary tree. Minor procedures like biopsy and endoscopic stone removal can be done via this itself.

Other investigations which might cause confusion in identification are those of :

MRCP (image below)

Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiopancreatography (image below)

questions.text: A 18-year-old woman complains of rough, dry skin on the extensor surface of her upper arms. On examination, multiple small, rough, follicular papules are noted as shown. There is no associated pruritus. She has no other complaints and her dietary history is not significant. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an 18 year old woman who is otherwise healthy, presenting with rough, dry skin and multiple small follicular papules on the extensor surface of upper arms, with no associated pruritus, is suggestive of Keratosis pilaris.

Keratosis pilaris is an inherited abnormality of keratinization. It affects the follicular orifices leading to keratotic follicular plugging, perifollicular erythema, and follicular atrophy. It usually occurs during puberty. It presents as small, keratotic papules on the extensor aspects of the limbs, particularly the arms. Treatment is purely reserved for cosmetic purposes and involves the use of keratolytics and topical retinoids.

Other options: 

Option A: Atopic dermatitis typically presents with erythematous, pruritic patches or plaques, often associated with a personal or family history of atopy. Flexural surfaces are commonly involved in adults.

Option B: Phrynoderma (also known as toad skin) is one of the differentials for keratosis pilaris. It occurs due to the deficiency of vitamins A, B complex, C, E, and essential fatty acids. In phrynoderma, keratotic follicular papules are commonly present over the elbows and knees, but can also extend to the shoulders, neck, back, thighs, buttocks, and abdomen. Management includes nutritional improvement.

Option D: Psoriasis presents with well-demarcated, erythematous plaques with silvery scale, commonly affecting extensor surfaces such as the elbows and knees. It is often associated with nail changes and may involve systemic manifestations such as psoriatic arthritis. Given below is an image of plaque psoriasis.

questions.text: Given image illustrates the position of the fetus in a female, while in active labour. Choose the right statement with regards to this .

choices.text: Anterior fontanelle is palpable on vaginal examination
Head engages through left oblique diameter of maternal pelvis
Mandates C- section, as there is no mechanism of labor

questions.solution:
The given image is representative of the right occiput posterior position of the fetus, where the anterior fontanelle is palpable on vaginal examination.

Occcipitoposterior is an abnormal position of the vertex, where the occiput is placed posteriorly over the sacroiliac joint or directly over the sacrum. The right occiput posterior(ROP) is the most common variant in this category, where the occiput is placed over the right sacroiliac joint.

In more than 50% of cases, this position is associated with either an anthropoid or android pelvis(option A), as the wide occiput can comfortably be placed in the wider posterior segment of the pelvis.

Marked deflexion of the fetal head too favors the posterior position of the vertex.

On vaginal examination, the anterior fontanelle is felt easily because of deflexion of the head(option B). The sagittal suture occupies any of the oblique diameters of the pelvis.

The head engages through the right oblique diameter in ROP(option C) and the left oblique diameter in LOP. The engaging anteroposterior diameter is either suboccipitofrontal(10cm) or occipitofrontal(11.5cm).

In the majority of the cases(90%), anterior rotation of the occiput occurs by 3/8th of a circle(135 degrees) and delivery of the head occurs by extension. Hence, a C-section is not necessary(option D) routinely and is needed only in a minority of cases complicated by deep transverse arrest or occipitosacral arrest.

questions.text: What is the chemotherapeutic agent of choice for the management of metastatic gastrointestinal stromal tumor?
questions.solution:
Imatinib is the chemotherapeutic agent of choice for metastatic gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST).

Imatinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor. In GIST, it inhibits the mutant c-KIT gene. Its adverse effects include myelosuppression, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, edema, and periorbital swelling.

Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST) are mesenchymal tumors originating from the interstitial cells of Cajal, located in the gastrointestinal myenteric plexus. The most common mutation associated with GIST is the c-KIT gene mutation. They compromise 1-3% of all gastrointestinal tumors. The most common sites are the stomach, small bowel, and rectum. They are considered to have metastatic potential if larger than 5cm.

Symptoms of GIST include pain abdomen, nausea, vomiting, hematemesis, and malena.

They are diagnosed on endoscopy and can be confirmed by targeted biopsy by endoscopic ultrasound. The primary mode of treatment is surgical resection if they are easily resectable. Smaller tumors (<5cm) are treated by wedge resection and larger tumors (>5cm) may require gastrectomy or duodenectomy, with 3-6 months of imatinib therapy before operation. Imatinib therapy should be continued for large tumors with high malignant potential.

Other options:

Option A: Erlotinib is an EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitor. It is used in the management of non-small cell lung cancer and pancreatic cancer. 

Option C: Sorafenib is an intracellular kinase inhibitor. It is used in the management of hepatocellular carcinoma.

Option D: Dasatinib is a BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase inhibitor. It is used in the management of imatinib-resistant CML.

Related Pearl: Indications for Imatinib

BCR-ABL kinase mutations

  • Chronic myelogenous leukaemia (CML)
  • Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL)

C-KIT mutations

  • Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST)

PDGFR mutations

  • Dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans
  • Hypereosinophilia syndrome
  • Chronic myelomonocytic leukaemia (CML)

Related Pearl: Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor (GIST)

M/C mesenchymal tumor of GIT arising from interstitial cells of Cajal (pacemaker cells of GIT). Stomach is the m/c site.

GISTs express:

  • c-KIT (CD117)
  • PDGF receptor A
  • CD34
  • SDH

Clinical Features:

  • Peaks at 60 years of age.
  • M/C symptom: Upper GI bleeding
  • Other symptoms: Pain, lump, perforation, incidental finding
  • Carney's Triad: Sporadic GIST, Paraganglioma, Pulmonary chondroma

Management:

  • IOC for primary GIST: CECT abdomen
  • IOC for recurrent GIST: PET-CT
  • IHC markers: CD117/C-KIT (M/C), DOG 1 (most specific), CD 34
  • Route of metastasis: Hematogenous

The following image shows microscopy of GIST composed of spindle-shaped tumor cells:

  • Fletcher's classification (Tumor size & No. of mitotic figures) is used to classify the tumors according to their malignancy risk.
  • Prognosis is determined by: Mitotic index, tumor size & location of tumor (Stomach GISTs are less aggressive).
  • Complete surgical resection is the mainstay treatment. For unresectable, recurrent, or metastatic GISTs, imatinib, a tyrosine kinase inhibitor, can be used.

questions.text: A researcher is conducting a study on the electron transport chain (ETC) and oxidative phosphorylation. Identify the correct statement about the same.

choices.text: ETC complexes are present in the outer mitochondrial membrane
Complex I of ETC is NADH-Q oxidoreductase
Cyanide and carbon monoxide are inhibitors of complex III
Oxidative phosphorylation of NADH generates 1.5 ATP

questions.solution:
Complex I of the electron transport chain is the enzyme NADH-Q oxidoreductase. 

The electron transport chain represents the final pathway through which electrons, originating from the oxidation of carbohydrates, fatty acids, and amino acids, are channeled toward a final reaction with oxygen to produce water and ATP. The ETC complexes are embedded in the inner mitochondrial membrane (option A).

Complex I is NADH-Q oxidoreductase. It oxidizes NADH and reduces coenzyme Q. The oxidation of compounds by ETC complexes leads to the release of free energy. This is used to pump H+ to the intermembrane space. This results in the formation of a proton motive force that is used for the phosphorylation of ADP to ATP. 

Thus, oxidation is coupled with phosphorylation to generate ATP. NADH generates 2.5 ATP (option D) and FADH2 generates 1.5 ATP.

The table below summarizes the inhibitors of the electron transport chain.  

Complexes of ETC Inhibitors
Complex I: NADH-Q oxidoreductase Piericidin A, amobarbital, rotenone
Complex II: Succinate-Q reductase TTFA (thenoyltrifluoroacetone), carboxin, malonate
Complex III: Q- cyt c oxidoreductase BAL (British anti-lewisite), antimycin A
Complex IV: Cyt c oxidase Hydrogen sulfide, carbon monoxide, cyanide (option C)
Complex V: ATP Synthase Atractyloside, oligomycin

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents to the emergency room with diabetic ketoacidosis. He is a known case of heart failure and diabetes mellitus and is on medications. On examination, the below finding was noted as shown in the image. Which of the following drugs is the likely cause for his presentation?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a diabetic, heart failure patient presenting with diabetic ketoacidosis and the image showing Fournier's gangrene is suggestive of canagliflozin as the likely causative drug.

Canagliflozin is a sodium-glucose transporter 2 (SGLT-2) inhibitor. Other SGLT-2 inhibitors include dapagliflozin and empagliflozin. They act by inhibiting the SGLT-2 transporter which is present on the proximal segment of the renal tubule and responsible for the reabsorption of 80-90% of filtered glucose. It inhibits glucose reabsorption resulting in glycosuria and change in the renal threshold. This results in a decrease in the blood glucose level. 

SGLT-2 inhibitors have a cardioprotective effect resulting from improved cardiac cell metabolism, improvement of ventricular loading mechanism, and reduction of cardiac cell necrosis and fibrosis. It also has a renoprotective property.

The common side effects include urinary tract infections and genital mycotic infections due to the high glucose content of the urine. Fournier's gangrene is also one of the important adverse effects. There is a risk of the development of euglycemic diabetic ketoacidosis. It increases the risk of fractures and lower limb amputations due to the creation of an imbalance with the minerals and circulating parathormone and vitamin D. 

Other options:

Option A- Acarbose is an α-glucosidase inhibitor that inhibits the α-glucosidase enzyme in the brush border epithelium of the intestine and reduces the absorption of starch, dextrin, and disaccharides. The most important adverse effects are malabsorption, flatulence, diarrhea, and abdominal bloating. Hypoglycemia can occur when it is given along with insulin or insulin secretagogues.

Option C- Metformin belongs to the biguanide class of hypoglycemic drugs that activate AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) and reduce hepatic glucose production. The most common adverse effects of metformin include anorexia, abdominal discomfort, diarrhea, vitamin B12 deficiency, and lactic acidosis. Metformin should be used cautiously in renal failure patients.

Option D- Pioglitazone belongs to the thiazolidinediones class of hypoglycemic drugs that stimulate the peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma (PPAR-γ) in muscle, fat, liver, and reduce insulin resistance. The most common adverse effects include weight gain and edema due to an increase in adiposity and fluid retention. They can increase the incidence of heart failure and the risk of fractures. Some cases of macular edema have been reported.

questions.text: A 19-year-old female presents with primary amenorrhea and anosmia. She has had no breast development or axillary or pubic hair growth. Physical examination reveals normal female genitalia and USG shows a hypoplastic uterus. What is the expected hormone profile in this patient?

choices.text: Low GnRH, low FSH, low LH
High GnRH, low FSH, low LH
Normal GnRH, low FSH, low LH
High GnRH, high FSH, high LH

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 19-year-old female presenting with primary amenorrhea, anosmia, no breast development or axillary or pubic hair growth and normal female genitalia with USG showing hypoplastic uterus is suggestive of Kallman syndrome. 

Kallman syndrome is characterized by hypogonadotropic hypogonadism: Low GnRH, low FSH, low LH, and low Estradiol (decreased gonadotropin secretion from the pituitary gland and subsequent decreased gonadal function) and anosmia. The primary cause is a deficiency in gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) production in the hypothalamus.

GnRH is the key hormone that stimulates the pituitary gland to release FSH and LH. In Kallman syndrome, GnRH production is significantly reduced, leading to low FSH and LH. FSH and LH are gonadotropins that stimulate follicle development and ovulation in females and sperm production in males. 

Estradiol is the primary female sex hormone produced by the ovaries under the stimulation of FSH and LH. In this case, due to low FSH and LH, estradiol production is also significantly decreased, leading to amenorrhea and lack of secondary sexual development.

Kallman syndrome can be inherited as an X-linked, autosomal dominant or autosomal recessive disorder. There is a mutation in the KAL-1 gene on the short arm of the X chromosome. This gene encodes an adhesion protein called anosmin-1.  Anosmin-1 is required for the migration of GnRH and olfactory neurons. Hence in patients with Kallman syndrome, the GnRH neurons fail to migrate and instead remain near the nasal epithelium which is unable to stimulate the pituitary gland to release LH and FSH.

Management includes combined estrogen and progestin therapy to induce menstruation. Exogenous gonadotropins are used to induce ovulation.

Other options:

Option B. High GnRH, low FSH, low LH, and low Estradiol: This profile may be seen in - primary pituitary insufficiency and , where there is decreased production of all pituitary hormones, including FSH, LH, and GnRH. In severe cases, GnRH levels can remain elevated in a compensatory attempt to stimulate the failing pituitary gland, while FSH and LH remain low.

Option C. Normal GnRH, low FSH, low LH, and low Estradiol may be seen in functional hypothalamic amenorrhea. This condition involves hypothalamic dysfunction leading to decreased GnRH secretion, but without structural abnormalities. While GnRH levels may be near normal in some cases, they are typically insufficient to adequately stimulate FSH and LH production, resulting in low levels of both hormones and low estradiol.

Option D: High GnRH, high FSH, high LH, and low Estradiol: This profile may be seen in Ovarian dysgenesis: In abnormal development of the ovaries, as in streak ovaries in Turner syndrome, leading to decreased estrogen production. In some cases, the compensatory response can lead to elevated GnRH, FSH, and LH levels in an attempt to stimulate the dysfunctional ovaries.

questions.text: A 39-year-old male with frequent abdominal pain presents to the emergency room. The image of his IV pyelogram is given below. The most likely underlying cause for the finding is:
questions.solution:
The IV pyelogram shows dilated calyces and pelvis of the right kidney with a normal-functioning left kidney. This is due to the presence of a large staghorn calculus (struvite stone) in the pelvicalyceal system of the right kidney. This is caused due to infection with urea-splitting organisms, such as Proteus, Klebsiella, Serratia, or Enterobacter species.

Staghorn calculi are radio-opaque stones that grow in a branching pattern along the pelvicalyceal system. The above organisms metabolize the urea into ammonium and bicarbonate. Increased metabolism of urea results in alkalinity of the urine, and precipitation of magnesium, ammonium, and phosphate - resulting in the formation of struvite stones.

These stones can grow to be very large and can cause significant impairment of renal function. Treatment involves the surgical removal of the stone and antibiotics to treat the infection.

Note: The X-ray also shows renal calyceal stones on the right.

Related Pearl: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones

Xanthine, indinavir, and triamterene stones are radiolucent.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman was taken up for Cesarean section. Spinal anesthesia was given and the patient went into hypotension. Which of the following would be the vasopressor of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Phenylephrine is the vasopressor of choice in pregnant patients developing hypotension following neuraxial anesthesia (spinal and epidural).

Phenylephrine is preferred because besides effectively controlling hypotension, it has less placental transfer and lesser chances of fetal acidosis than ephedrine.

The patient should receive an adequate intravenous fluid bolus of crystalloid like Ringer lactate solution (typically 1000–1500 mL) or colloid (typically 250–500 mL) solution at the time of neural blockade to avoid hypotension. On developing hypotension even after adequate fluid management, vasopressors are administered for the further management.

After the administration of the spinal anesthetic injection, the patient is placed supine with left uterine displacement (to prevent aortocaval compression) and supplemental oxygen (40–50%) is given.

Blood pressure should be monitored every 1–2 min until it stabilizes.

Hypotension following epidural anesthesia typically has a slower onset.

Other options:

Option A- Dopamine is not used in pregnant women developing hypotension because it lowers the pO2 levels in umbilical vessels. 

Option B- Vasopressin is reserved for circulatory collapse or patients who do not respond to volume infusion and catecholamines. Hence, it is not preferred here.

Option C- Ephedrine has more placental transfer and there is a higher risk of fetal acidosis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman comes to the clinic with complaints of episodic flushing. She also complains of diarrhea, which is watery, non-bloody, explosive, and accompanied by abdominal cramping. Further evaluation reveals a tumor in the ileum with the histopathology shown below.  Which of the following is not true about this condition?

choices.text: 5- HIAA is used for lab diagnosis
Pellagra can develop due to tryptophan deficiency

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette with symptoms of abdominal cramping, explosive diarrhea, and episodic flushing, along with the characteristic histopathological findings (stippled chromatin pattern, without mitotic activity or necrosis) points to the diagnosis of carcinoid syndrome. The statement- 'anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies are present' is untrue about this condition.

Carcinoid syndrome is the result of a carcinoid tumor that secretes excessive amounts of serotonin, which is a product of the amino acid tryptophan. Serotonin is ultimately metabolized and excreted in urine as 5-HIAA (5-hydroxy indole acetic acid). 

The following tests can be used in the diagnosis of carcinoid tumors:

  • Urinary excretion of 5-HIAA and serotonin
  • Serum chromogranin concentration
  • Blood serotonin concentration
  • Plasma 5-HIAA concentration
  • Tumor localization with CT, MRI, somatostatin receptor imaging, and endoscopic biopsy

In carcinoid syndrome, elevated levels of serotonin stimulate fibroblast growth and fibrogenesis, which leads to the development of cardiac valvular lesions. These lesions most often affect the right side of the heart because the inactivation of humoral substances by the lung protects the left heart. In a few cases, the left side of the heart may be affected (in patients with right-to-left shunt, as in patent foramen ovale).

Alterations in tryptophan metabolism are seen in all patients with over 70% of dietary tryptophan converted to serotonin. Some tumors also produce histamine, kallikrein, prostaglandins, and tachykinins.

These features of serotonin result in the following symptoms that are found often in carcinoid syndrome-

  • Episodic flushing
  • Diarrhea - explosive, non-bloody, and accompanied by abdominal cramping
  • Bronchospasm
  • Cardiac valvular lesions - commonly involve the right side because the left heart is protected by the humoral inactivation of substances by the lungs
  • Pellagra- because of shunting of most of the dietary tryptophan to serotonin synthesis. (4 D's: diarrhea, dermatitis, dementia, death)
  • Muscle wasting due to poor protein synthesis
  • Mesenteric and retroperitoneal fibrosis

Treatment:

  • Somatostatin analog therapy
  • Antidiarrheal therapy
  • Surgical excision

Incorrect option: 

Anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies are used to diagnose celiac disease. Celiac disease is a malabsorptive disorder that can present in early childhood with diarrhea. This usually occurs after introducing cereals into the child's diet. The symptoms usually disappear over a few years and may or may not re-appear in adulthood. The diagnosis is made by testing for autoantibodies (such as anti-tissue transglutaminase, anti-endomysial, and anti-gliadin) and by performing a small intestine biopsy, which can show flattening of the villi.

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant woman in her 30th week of gestation was found to have an amniotic fluid index (AFI) of 4 cm. Which among the following options could be a cause of this presentation?
questions.solution:
Amniotic fluid index (AFI) less than 5 cm suggests oligohydramnios, among the given options amnion nodosum is a cause of oligohydramnios, the other options are causes of polyhydramnios.

Oligohydramnios is defined as:

  • Amniotic fluid volume less than 200 ml
  • AFI less than 5 cm
  • The maximum vertical pocket of liquor is less than 2 cm

Causes of oligohydramnios are amnion nodosum (failure of secretion by the cells of the amnion covering the placenta), postmaturity, renal agenesis, obstructive uropathy, maternal usage of prostaglandin inhibitors, angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, etc.

Polyhydramnios is defined as:

  • Amniotic fluid volume of more than 2L
  • AFI more than 25 cm
  • A deepest vertical pocket is more than 8 cm 

Causes of polyhydramnios are anencephaly, cleft palate, facial clefts, hydrops fetalis, maternal diabetes, esophageal or duodenal atresia, open spina bifida, aneuploidy, chorioangioma of the placenta, infections like cytomegalovirus, toxoplasmosis, etc.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old patient diagnosed with CKD was on dialysis for 6 months and came with complaints of weakness. Blood investigations revealed Hb of 7g/dl. Which is the preferred drug that can be delivered via ORAL route to treat this anemia?

CKD - Chronic Kidney Disease
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of moderate anemia in chronic kidney disease. The FDA recently approved daprodustat as an oral treatment for anemia caused by CKD for adults who have been receiving dialysis for at least four months. The drug acts by increasing erythropoietin levels.

Anemia in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) is primarily due to decreased erythropoietin production. It presents as normocytic normochromic anemia in the peripheral smear. Patients complain of fatigue and diminished ability to exercise. Anemic associated with CKD can also be treated with human recombinant erythropoietin (EPO) such as darbepoetin. However, darbepoetin is only available as an intravenous injection.

Adequate iron stores are required in the bone marrow before the treatment is initiated with erythropoetin stimulating agents (ESA). This is because new red cell production once ESA is administered will exceed the amount of iron that is available in the body stores. Hence, iron supplements (oral or IV) must be given first to ensure the effectiveness of EPO therapy.

Other treatment options for anemia in CKD are: Vitamin B12 and folate supplementation, blood transfusion - in severe anemia and failure to EPO therapy.

questions.text: The ST segment on an ECG corresponds to which of the following in the cardiac muscle action potential?
questions.solution:
The ST segment on an ECG corresponds to Phase 2 of the cardiac muscle action potential. 

During Phase 2, also known as the plateau phase, there is a balance between inward calcium currents and outward potassium currents, resulting in a sustained depolarization of the cell membrane. This correlates with the isoelectric line seen as the ST segment on the ECG.

Phases of the cardiac muscle action potential:

Phase 0 (Depolarization): Opening of fast sodium channels. When the cardiac cell is stimulated, the fast sodium channels (voltage-gated sodium channels) open and cause sodium influx. This depolarizes the cell and the membrane potential becomes positive. It reached about +20 mV and the sodium channels close. The rapid upstroke of the action potential in this phase corresponds to the onset of the QRS complex.

Phase 1 (Initial repolarization): Closing of fast sodium channels. The fast sodium channel closes and the potassium channels open. the potassium ions leave the cell leading to repolarisation. (Option A)

Phase 2 (Plateau): Fast potassium channels close and calcium channels open. The slowly opening voltage-gated Ca2+ channels start opening in phases 0 and 1. The influx of calcium through these channels is balanced by the decrease in the efflux of potassium via the potassium channels. This produces the plateau. 

Phase 3 (Rapid repolarization): Slow potassium channels open and calcium channels close. The potassium ions leave the cell through slow potassium channels and the calcium channels close stopping the influx of calcium ions. This ends the plateau and brings the membrane potential to resting level. This phase corresponds to the T wave. (Option C)

Phase 4 (Resting membrane potential): around −80 to −90 millivolts. (Option D)

questions.text: A 20-year-old male is brought to the causality following a head injury. His GCS is 13/15 and examination reveals blood in the tympanic membrane and the following finding. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 20-year-old male with GCS 13/15, hemotympanum (blood in the tympanic membrane)  and the image of battle sign (bruising behind the ear) are features of fracture of the skull base, particularly of the middle cranial fossa.

A basilar skull fracture occurs due to direct impact behind the ear or crush injuries of the head and present with the following features:

  • Hemotympanum
  • Battle sign: bruising behind the ear
  • Racoon eyes
  • CSF rhinorrhoea

Other options:

Option A: Depressed skull fracture occurs due to the impact of a moving object. 

Option B: Anterior cranial fossa fracture occurs due to direct impact. It is a contrecoup injury which occurs when there is a direct blow to the chin (in boxing). The impact is transmitted to the maxilla and base of the skull and results in contrecoup fracture of the cribriform plate of the ethmoid. It presents with CSF rhinorrhea and periorbital hematoma or raccoon eyes and the image is shown below. 

Option C: Posterior cranial fossa fractures occur due to a direct impact on the back of the head.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient presented with painless axillary lymphadenopathy. A lymph-node biopsy was done and histopathology revealed the following. Immunophenotyping revealed CD20+, BCL6+ ,CD15-  and CD30-. The findings are suggestive of which of the following subtypes of Hodgkin's lymphoma?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with immunophenotype positive for CD20 & BCL6 and negative for CD15 and CD30, and the histopathology picture showing lymphohistiocytic variants of Reed Steenberg cell, also called popcorn cell, is characteristic of nodular lymphocyte-predominant subtype of Hodgkin's lymphoma (NLPHL).

The nodular Lymphocyte predominance subtype is a non-classical Hodgkin's lymphoma commonly seen in young males <35 years of age. Common presentations include cervical or axillary lymphadenopathy.

It is characterized by lymphohistiocytic variants with multilobed nuclei. They resemble popcorn kernels and are are positive for CD20 and BCL6 while negative for CD15 and CD30. 

The below histopathology image shows popcorn cells of NLPHL.

Hodgkin's lymphomas are a group of lymphoid neoplasms arising from a single or group of lymph nodes and can spread to anatomically contiguous lymphoid tissues. It usually presents as painless lymphadenopathy. The distinctive feature of Hodgkin's lymphoma is the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells.

Reed-Stenberg cells are neoplastic cells derived from the germinal center or post–germinal center B cells. They appear as large cells with multiple nuclei or a single nucleus with multiple nuclear lobes. Each cell contains a large inclusion-like nucleolus and abundant cytoplasm.

WHO classifies Hodgkin's lymphoma into 5 subtypes:

  • Nodular sclerosis: Frequent lacunar cells
  • Mixed cellularity
  • Lymphocyte-rich
  • Lymphocyte depletion
  • Nodular lymphocyte predominance

The first 4 subtypes are considered classical Hodgkin's lymphoma. The RS cells are CD 15+ and CD30+. The lymphocyte predominant type is considered non-classical Hodgkin's lymphoma with CD15-, CD30-, CD20+, and EB -. 

Other options: 

Option A: Nodular sclerosis is the most common subtype equally affecting young males and females. Histology shows frequent lacunar cells and occasional diagnostic RS cells with the background infiltrate composed of T lymphocytes, eosinophils, macrophages, plasma cells, and fibrous bands. The RS cells are positive for CD15 and CD30.

Option B: Lymphocyte-rich is an uncommon subtype seen in older-aged adults with increased occurrence in males. Frequent mononuclear and diagnostic RS cells and background infiltrates rich in T lymphocytes are seen. The RS cells are positive for CD15 and CD30.

Option C: Lymphocyte depletion is an uncommon subtype seen in older men. A reticular variant is observed in this subtype with frequent diagnostic RS cells and a small amount of background reactive cells. The RS cells are positive for CD15 and CD30.

Note: Mixed cellularity is most commonly associated with HIV due to its high incidence.

questions.text: An angiography study was done for a patient who presented with chronic dysphagia. The following vascular anomaly of the aortic arch was found to be the cause. Identify the anomaly.
questions.solution:
The vascular anomaly that is causing the dysphagia in this patient is an aberrant right subclavian artery. This condition is known as dysphagia lusoria.

Dysphagia lusoria is dysphagia produced due to compression of the esophagus by a developmental vascular anomaly, often an aberrant right subclavian artery. It arises directly from the aortic arch.

It can be diagnosed by CT angiography. Treatment is surgical repair either by reconstruction or ligation of the aberrant right subclavian artery.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old male patient presents with complaints of lethargy, increased thirst, and increased frequency of urination. On examination, his BMI was 19 kg/m2 and laboratory investigation showed low levels of C-peptide, raised blood glucose, and absent ketone bodies. Anti-GAD antibodies were positive. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Anti-GAD: Antibodies to glutamic acid decarboxylase
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a 32-year-old, thin-built male, presenting with polyuria, polydipsia, lethargy with laboratory investigation showing low C-peptide, and positive anti-GAD antibodies is suggestive of latent autoimmune diabetes in adults (LADA). 

LADA is adult-onset diabetes with features of both type 1 and type 2 diabetes mellitus (DM). They phenotypically appear as type 2 but have autoantibodies like anti-GAD in favor of type 1. The general characteristics of LADA include:

  • Age of onset more than 30 years
  • Family history of autoimmunity
  • Low or normal body mass index
  • Low C-peptide levels
  • Anti-GAD antibodies positive
  • Do not present with ketoacidosis initially due to the slow progression of beta-cell destruction

The diagnosis can be made based on three criteria as given by The Immunology of Diabetes Society:

  • Adult age of onset (>30 years of age),
  • Positive circulating autoantibodies, and
  • No need for insulin treatment initially for several months after diagnosis

Initially, they don't require insulin but are more likely to be on insulin treatment within 5 years of onset. 

Other options:

Option A: Ketosis-prone type 2 diabetes patients are usually middle-aged men who are overweight and have a positive family history of diabetes. They have features similar to classic type 2 diabetes but often present with severe hyperglycemia and severe ketosis as in type 1 diabetes. Autoantibodies against beta-cells are negative in these patients. 

Option B: MODY or maturity-onset diabetes of the young is an autosomal dominant monogenic form of diabetes that occurs in patients less than 25 years of age. This is due to beta-cell dysfunction that impairs insulin secretion. The patients are non-ketotic and do not have pancreatic autoantibodies.

Option C: Type 1 diabetes mellitus most commonly develops before 20 years of age with most of them having evidence of islet-directed autoimmunity. Most of the patients present with hyperglycemia and ketoacidosis. There is increased lipolysis and ketone body production which results in muscle wasting, polyphagia, fatigue, and weakness.
In LADA, the destruction of islet cells proceeds at a much slower speed. This is why they present later, and may not require insulin treatment initially (unlike Type 1 DM).

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with fever and painful enlargement of her thyroid gland. She also gives a history of having an upper respiratory tract infection (URTI) 2 days ago. A biopsy of the thyroid gland showed findings as seen in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The painful enlargement of the thyroid gland with a history of URTI and the image above showing granulomatous inflammation in the thyroid gland are suggestive of subacute granulomatous thyroiditis.

This condition is also known as painful subacute thyroiditis, de Quervain thyroiditis, and migratory thyroiditis (this is because the pain can shift to different locations in the thyroid). It is subacute granulomatous thyroiditis that occurs secondary to viral infections. Many viruses such as mumps, influenza, coxsackie, adenoviruses, and echoviruses have been clinically implicated in this condition and this condition occurs due to virus-induced host tissue damage that stimulates a cytotoxic T-lymphocyte response to one or more thyroid antigens that damages thyroid follicle cells. Peak incidence is observed at 30-50 years and women are generally affected three times more often than men. Histopathology shows the presence of granulomas in the thyroid gland.

Clinically, it presents as a painfully enlarged thyroid and is sometimes accompanied by fever and examination reveals a small goiter that is very tender.

It has three distinct phases:

  • Thyrotoxic phase
  • Hypothyroid phase
  • Recovery phase

It is treated with large doses of aspirin, NSAIDs, steroids, and/or beta-blockers to relieve the observable clinical symptoms. Antithyroid drugs do not have any role. In case the hypothyroid phase is prolonged - levothyroxine can be used.

Other options: 

Option A: Subacute lymphocytic thyroiditis (postpartum thyroiditis) is typically painless. It often occurs after pregnancy and is characterized by lymphocytic inflammation in the thyroid.

Option B: Hashimoto thyroiditis is an autoimmune disease that presents as painless enlargement of the thyroid associated with some degree of hypothyroidism in middle-aged women.

Option D: Riedel's thyroiditis is a rare disorder characterized by a nonpainful, rapidly growing thyroid mass with extensive fibrosis involving the thyroid and contiguous neck structures.

questions.text: An 18-year-old male patient presented with a history of fever, sore throat, and enlarged lymph nodes. He was prescribed ampicillin after which he developed a maculopapular rash. Which of the following is the standard diagnostic test for this condition?
questions.solution:
A young adult with fever, sore throat, lymphadenopathy and development of a maculopapular rash after administration of ampicillin likely has infectious mononucleosis. The standard diagnostic test for this condition is the Paul Bunnell test, which is a heterophile antibody reaction test.

Infectious mononucleosis (IM), or kissing disease or glandular fever, is caused by Epstein–Barr virus (EBV). Patients present with fever, pharyngitis, bilateral symmetrical lymphadenopathy and splenomegaly. A drug-induced rash may develop on using beta-lactam antibiotics. Large, atypical lymphocytes are seen in the peripheral blood of affected patients.

Paul-Bunnell test is a heterophile agglutination test used for the diagnosis of IM. It identifies the heterophile antibodies produced in IM that agglutinate erythrocytes of different animal species. These antibodies can be demonstrated by the end of the first week of illness, but are occasionally delayed until the third or fourth week and may persist for months. In this test, the inactivated serum of a patient is mixed with 1% suspension of sheep erythrocytes in serial dilutions. After incubation at 37°C for four hours the tubes are examined for agglutination. An agglutination titre of 100 or above is suggestive of infectious mononucleosis.  

Other serological tests such as immunofluorescence and ELISA are employed to detect antibodies against EBV. The lgM antibody to VCA (virus capsid antigen) appears soon after primary infection and disappears in 1-2 weeks. It indicates primary infection. The IgG anti-VCA antibody persists throughout life and indicates past or recent infection. The new appearance of antibodies to the EB nuclear antigen (EBNA) is a marker for primary infection.

Other options:

Option A: Cold agglutination test is used to detect primary atypical pneumonia caused by Mycoplasma.

Option B: Weil-felix test is used for rickettsial infections.

Option D: Microscopic agglutination test is used for diagnosing leptospirosis.

questions.text: What is the primary goal of the Integrated Disease Surveillance Programme?

choices.text: To promote healthy lifestyle choices among individuals
To collect monthly disease surveillance data
To detect early warning signals of outbreaks
To conduct research on rare diseases

questions.solution:
The main purpose of Integrated Disease Surveillance Programme (IDSP) is to detect early warning signals of outbreaks.

IDSP (formely known as Integrated Disease Surveillance Project)  is a national decentralised state-based surveillance program. The mission is to detect early warning signals for timely and effective public health action so that it can be initiated against outbreaks of prone diseases in both urban and rural areas. It also provides essential data to monitor ongoing disease control programs. 

The program includes a Central Surveillance Unit, State Surveillance Units, and District Surveillance Units, and collects weekly disease surveillance data (Option B) on epidemic-prone diseases from reporting units such as hospitals and medical colleges. The data is analyzed for disease trends and investigated by a Rapid Response Team consisting of specialists whenever there is a rising trend of illness.

The surveillance is necessary to recognize cases or clusters of cases, access the public health impact of health events, demonstrate the need for public health intervention programs, monitor the effectiveness of prevention and control measures, and identify high-risk groups or geographical areas for targeted interventions.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms shows bipolar staining as depicted by the arrow in the image below?
questions.solution:
The depicted staining pattern is bipolar staining (safety-pin appearance) which is seen in Klebsiella granulomatis. 

Organisms showing bipolar staining include -

  • Vibrio parahaemolyticus
  • Burkholderia species especially B.pseudomallei
  • Haemophilus ducreyi
  • Klebsiella granulomatis(Calymmatobacterium granulomatis)
  • Yersinia pestis
  • Pasteurella multocida
  • Lactobacillus species

Klebsiella granulomatis previously known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis causes a sexually transmitted disease called Donovanosis.

The incubation period is 1–12 weeks. It presents as a painless beefy red ulcer that bleeds readily on touch. Lymph node involvement is rare. However, pseudo buboes (subcutaneous granulomas) may be seen in the inguinal region in 10% of cases due to subcutaneous abscess.

It is a clinical diagnosis. Additionally, smears from the lesion stained with Giemsa or Wright’s stain show Donovan bodies. These are large cyst-like macrophages filled with deeply stained capsulated bacilli having a safety-pin(bipolar) appearance. Rupture of these cysts leads to the release of bacilli and spread.    

Treatment includes azithromycin 1 g orally once per week or 500 mg daily for at least 3 weeks, until all lesions have completely healed. Alternatively, doxycycline or co-trimoxazole is given for 14 days. Both sexual partners should be treated and all those who are diagnosed should be tested for HIV.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought in cardiopulmonary arrest to the ER, the EMT has tried to gain venous access for the past 1 minute, but in vain. It is decided to get access through the following method. Which of the following is true regarding resuscitation using this route?

choices.text: Only emergency epinephrine can be given through this route
Only blood products and fluids can be administered through this route
Any medications, blood products, and fluids can be administered
Only fluids to be given through this route

questions.solution:
The given image shows intraosseous cannulation for fluid transfusion in the anterior proximal tibia. Any and all medications, blood products, and fluids can be administered through this route.

The intraosseous route is an alternative to the intravenous (IV) route in the transfusion of fluids in shock. 

  • The marrow of long bones has a rich network of vessels that drain into a central venous canal, emissary veins, and ultimately the central circulation.
  • So, the bone marrow functions as a non-collapsible venous access route.

Intraosseous cannulation is recommended for patients in whom IV access proves difficult or unattainable. (e.g., in cardiopulmonary arrest). In such a case, if venous access is not available within 1 min, an intraosseous needle should be placed in the anterior proximal tibia.

Complications are uncommon, but may include osteomyelitis with prolonged infusions and tibial fracture.

questions.text: A child presents with complaints of dry skin, developmental delay, and hypotonia. Examination reveals the presence of sparse and brittle hair as shown below. Evaluation reveals low serum copper levels. Which of the following steps of collagen synthesis will be affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child presenting with dry skin, developmental delay, hypotonia, examination showing sparse and brittle hair (described as 'kinky' hair), and low serum copper levels is suggestive of Menkes disease. The step of collagen synthesis that will be affected in this patient is the formation of the covalent cross-links.

Menkes disease is a progressive neurodegenerative condition that follows an X-linked recessive pattern of inheritance. It is caused by a defect in the ATP7A gene that codes for a copper-transporting protein. There is a defect in intestinal copper absorption and transport resulting in low serum copper and ceruloplasmin levels.

Symptoms begin in infancy and are characterized by developmental delay, failure to thrive, hypotonia, hypothermia, and seizures. Facial features include chubby cheeks with associated colorless, friable hair. 

The final step of collagen synthesis involves the formation of covalent cross-links. This is done by the enzyme lysyl oxidase, a copper-containing protein. This is essential for the strength and rigidity of collagen. As a result of deficiency of copper in Menkes disease, this step of collagen synthesis is affected. 

Other options:

Option A: Defective scaffolding by fibrillin is a feature seen in Marfan's syndrome, where the tropoelastin fails to form the elastin fibres. Clinical features include tall stature, subluxation of the ocular lens, mitral valve prolapse, aortic regurgitation and aortic dissection.

Option B: Glycosylation of hydroxylysyl residues is an essential step in triple-helix formation. Glycosylation is followed by disulfide bond formation. This step is affected in osteogenesis imperfecta. It is characterized by growth delay, brittle bones (history of fractures during childbirth), blue sclera, dentinogenesis imperfecta, and hearing loss.

Option D: Cleavage of terminal polypeptides is part of the proteolytic processing of procollagen that occurs after exocytosis. It is not affected in Menkes disease.

questions.text: A patient presenting with a movement disorder of his hands is diagnosed with essential tremors. Identify the correct statement about this condition.

choices.text: It can run in families as an autosomal dominant disorder
Tremors are usually asymmetric and of low frequency
Multiple body parts are rarely involved

questions.solution:
Essential tremors can run in families with an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance.

Essential tremor is the most common movement disorder. It is characterized by a symmetric, high-frequency tremor (6–10 Hz) that most commonly affects the upper extremities (option B). However, multiple body parts are involved in almost half the cases (option D). These include the head, the tongue, and the lower limbs. 

A characteristic feature of the tremor is that it improves with alcohol intake and worsens with stress (option C). If severe, the tremors can interfere with activities of daily living such as eating, or writing. 

Mild cases do not warrant any treatment. However, severe cases are managed with beta-blockers (most commonly propranolol) and primidone.

questions.text:
The population statistics of a country are being predicted. According to the Malthusian growth model, if a country's _______ is 2%, then the population will double in ______.

[Abbreviations: AGR-Annual growth rate, TFR-Total fertility rate]
questions.solution:
As per the Malthusian growth model, when the annual growth rate is 1%, the population doubles in 70 years. Therefore, when the annual growth rate is 2%, the population will double in 35 years.

The Malthusian growth model/ rule of 70:

Rating Annual growth rate Population doubles in
Slow growth <0.5% >139 years
Moderate growth from 0.5% ~139 years
Rapid growth from 1% 70 years
Very rapid growth from 1.5% approximately 50 years
Explosive growth from 2% 35 years
Explosive growth from 3% 20-25 years

The growth rate of India is estimated at 1% as per 2020 UN data. Therefore, it falls in the rapidly growing phase of population growth.

questions.text:
A woman presents with insidious onset worsening exertional breathlessness and occasional exertional chest pain. On examination, she has increased JVP, peripheral edema, ascites, and a loud P2. Her investigations are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
  • Chest X-ray - enlarged central pulmonary arteries and vascular pruning 
  • Echocardiography - hypertrophied right ventricle
  • ECG - right ventricular hypertrophy

JVP: Jugulovenous pulse, STEMI: ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is pulmonary hypertension. 

Pulmonary hypertension (PH) is characterized by an elevation in pulmonary arterial pressures and increased vascular resistance caused by various causes. It is defined by mean pulmonary artery pressure (mPAP) > 20mmHg

Clinical features include dyspnea, edema, chest pain, and syncope. It is irreversible as it does not have a curative treatment and thus can lead to decompensated right heart failure and death. 

Clinical signs may include right heart failure features such as elevated JVP, edema, ascites as a result of disease progression. Chest auscultation may reveal loud P2, S3 and S4. 

Investigations of PH include: 

  • Echocardiogram with bubble study - it is an important screening test. It usually shows a dilated, hypertrophied right ventricle and increased pulmonary artery systolic pressure.
  • Right heart catheterization - it is the gold standard test to establish the diagnosis of PH and to select appropriate therapy.
  • Chest X-ray - may show obliteration of retrosternal space, enlarged pulmonary arteries, and peripheral vascular pruning.
  • ECG - right ventricular hypertrophy

Other options: 

Option A: Acute STEMI would reveal ST elevations in ECG. It is an acute event while this patient has had insidious onset exertional chest pain. Pain is classically described as heavy, squeezing, and crushing. Cardiac biomarkers are also raised in STEMI.

Option C: Left-sided heart failure is characterized by pulmonary edema, dyspnea, orthopnea, and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. Elevated JVP, weight gain, gastrointestinal symptoms and ascites are signs of right-sided heart failure. 

Option D: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is the most common cause of sudden death in young individuals. It is characterized by exertional dyspnea, angina, left-sided congestion, and left-ventricular outflow obstruction.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about Okazaki fragments?

choices.text: It is synthesized in short fragments of 1-5kb size
It is synthesised on the leading strand
Upto 1000 Okazaki fragments may be synthesized for each replication fork

questions.solution:
Okazaki fragments are synthesized on the lagging strand, not the leading strand.

DNA polymerase δ synthesizes Okazaki fragments, which are short, newly synthesized DNA fragments that are formed on the lagging template strand during DNA replication. They are complementary to the lagging template strand.

Primase synthesizes RNA primers to start the replication. Upto 1000 Okazaki fragments may be synthesized for each replication fork

questions.text:
You are an intern posted in the labor ward. You see that a pregnant woman at her 32nd week of gestation has a BPP score of 2. Her BPP score remained the same when monitored for the next two hours. What is the next best step in this case?

BPP - biophysical profile
questions.solution:
A persistent biophysical profile (BPP) score of 2 for 2 hours points towards fetal asphyxia. Immediate delivery should be done regardless of the gestational age in this patient.

BPP is a multi-parametric screening test to assess uteroplacental insufficiency. It consists of five components (Mnemonic: BATMaN):

B - Breathing movements of the fetus
A - Amniotic fluid volume
T - Tone of the fetus
M - Movements of the fetus
N - Non-stress test (NST)

Parameters Minimal Normal Criteria
Fetal breathing movements ≥ 1 episode lasting over 30 seconds
Amniotic fluid volume (AFV) ≥ 1 pocket measuring 2 cm in two perpendicular planes (2 ×2 cm pocket)
Fetal muscle tone ≥ 1 episode of active limb or trunk extension with the return of flexion; Eg. opening and closing of the hand
Gross body movements   ≥ 3 body or limb movements
Non-stress Test (NST) Reactive

Each parameter has a maximum score of 2 and a minimum score of 0. So the total maximum score will be 10.

Interpretation of BPP scores:

BPP score Interpretation Management
8-10 Normal, nonasphyxiated fetus Repeat test weekly (or biweekly in diabetic mother or post-term pregnancy)
6 Possible fetal asphyxia

Deliver, if AFV is abnormal or >36weeks or if the repeat test score is ≤ 6

If the repeat score >6, observation and repeat test weekly
4 Probable fetal asphyxia

If >36 weeks then deliver

If <32 weeks - repeat testing the same day - if persistently low, then deliver
0-2 Almost certain fetal asphyxia Test for 2 hours - if persistent score of ≤ 4 - then deliver regardless of gestational age

questions.text: A patient presented with chest pain radiating to jaw and dysphagia. Motility disorder of esophagus is suspected and manometry is done which shows simultaneous multi-peaked contractions of high amplitude (>120 mm Hg). Probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with chest pain radiating to jaw and dysphagia with manometry showing simultaneous multi-peaked contractions of high amplitude (>120 mm Hg) is characteristic of Diffuse Esophageal Spasm.

Diffuse Esophageal Spasm:

  • DES is a condition in which there are incoordinate contractions of the Oesophagus, causing dysphagia and/or chest pain. 
  • The abnormal contractions are more common in the distal two-thirds of the esophageal body.
  • There is marked hypertrophy of the circular muscle.
  • The classic manometry findings in DES are simultaneous multi-peaked contractions of high amplitude (>120 mm Hg) or long duration (>2.5 seconds).
  • Barium meal shows corkscrew esophagus or pseudo diverticulosis.
  • Peristalsis is normal.
  • Treatment 
    • Calcium channel antagonists, vasodilators and endoscopic dilatation have only transient effects.
    • Surgical treatment includes extended oesophagealmyotomy up to the aortic arch may be required.
    • Surgical treatment of diffuse spasm is more successful in improving dysphagia than chest pain.

Manometric Findings in:

Nutcracker Esophagus:

  • Peristaltic esophageal contractions 2 standard deviations above normal.
  • Amplitude > 180 mmHg and duration > 6 seconds.

Hypertensive Lower Esophageal Sphincter:

  • Elevated LES presure> 26mmHg and normal relaxation of LES.
  • Esophageal body may be hyper-peristaltic or normal.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male with Parkinson’s disease came with complaints of heart burn, nausea and vomiting. The resident accidentally prescribed a drug that worsened the symptoms of Parkinson’s disease. What could be the drug prescribed?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of gastroesophageal reflux disease and the drug that has worsened the symptoms of Parkinson’s could be metoclopramide.

Metoclopramide is a prokinetic (5HT4 agonist action) and antiemetic (5HT3 antagonist action). It additionally sensitises muscarinic receptors in the smooth muscles of the gastrointestinal tract resulting in increased lower esophageal sphincter tone and stimulates gastric antrum contractions.

It has dopamine-antagonistic action(D2 inhibitor) in the central nervous system resulting in extrapyramidal effects, such as acute dystonia, Parkinson-like symptoms (tremors, bradykinesia, rigidity), tardive dyskinesia, galactorrhea due to hyperprolactinemia, and methemoglobinemia in neonates.

Extrapyramidal symptoms can be treated by discontinuation of metoclopramide and administration of anticholinergics or antihistaminics.

Other options:

Option B: Cisapride is a benzamide derivative that is prokinetic with minimal antiemetic potential due to the absence of D2 receptor antagonistic antagonism. It has no effect on CTZ and does not cause hyperprolactinemia or symptoms of extrapyramidal symptoms.

Option C: Ondansetron is a 5-HT3 receptor antagonist. It blocks impulses at the peripheral origin in GIT. It is most commonly indicated for the treatment of postoperative and chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting. Headache and dizziness are the common adverse effects.

Option D: Mosapride is a congener of cisapride that was later introduced had a major 5-HT4 agonistic action and a minor 5-HT3 antagonistic action in the myenteric plexus, resulting in similar gastrokinetic and LES tonic action. Similar to cisapride, it lacks the D2 blocking property that prevents extrapyramidal or hyperprolactinaemic side effects. It also lacks a clinically significant antiemetic action.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male presents with urinary hesitancy, frequency, and nocturia. On per rectal examination, the prostate gland is found to be enlarged. What is the phenomenon underlying the prostate enlargement in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The prostate enlargement in this elderly adult male presenting with urinary hesitancy, frequency, and nocturia is due to benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) which is an example of pathologic hyperplasia.

BPH is characterized by an increase in the number of prostatic cells as a response to hormonal stimulation by androgens, leading to gland enlargement.

Hyperplasia is defined as an increase in the number of cells in an organ or tissue in response to a stimulus, which is usually hormonal in nature. Hyperplasia can be physiologic or pathologic.

  • Physiologic hyperplasia (Option D) occurs as a response to hormonal stimuli to increase the functional capacity of an organ or as a compensatory mechanism after damage or resection. Examples include hyperplasia of the female breast at puberty and pregnancy, liver regeneration after resection, and hematopoiesis in the bone marrow in response to a deficiency of mature red blood cells.
  • Pathologic hyperplasia occurs as a response to inappropriate or excess growth hormones acting on cells. Examples include BPH and endometrial hyperplasia.

Other options: 

Option A: Hypertrophy is defined as an increase in cell size without an increase in cell numbers that leads to enlargement of the organ. An example of pathologic hypertrophy is the cardiac muscle hypertrophy in response to pressure overload from hypertension or valvular disease, which eventually leads to heart failure.

Option B: Physiologic hypertrophy occurs as a response to increased functional demand or stimulation by hormones or growth factors. Examples include growth of the uterus during pregnancy, and skeletal muscle hypertrophy in body builders.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man in the ICU is suffering from acute respiratory distress syndrome. Which one of the following statements is true for the dead space volume as seen in this patient?

choices.text: Physiologic dead space = Anatomical dead space
Physiologic dead space > Anatomical dead space
Physiologic dead space < Anatomical dead space
Physiologic dead space < Alveolar dead space

questions.solution:
In the case of alveolar-capillary membrane compromise as seen in acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), physiological dead space > anatomical dead space.

ARDS is characterized by damage to the alveolar-capillary interface in the lungs due to leakage of protein-rich inflammatory fluid from the capillaries. This promotes the formation of hyaline membranes that impair optimal gaseous exchange, thereby giving rise to significant alveolar dead space (sites of wasted ventilation). Since physiological dead space is the sum of alveolar dead space (virtually nil in healthy lungs) and anatomical dead space, in the case of ARDS, physiological dead space is greater than anatomical dead space. 

Dead space is the airway and lung volume that does not participate in gas exchange.

Types:

  • Anatomical dead space- the volume of the air-occupying conducting zone where no gaseous exchange takes place. It is about 150 mL in healthy individuals.
  • Alveolar dead space- the volume of gas not equilibrating with blood (present in cases of damaged alveolar diffusion membrane). 
  • Physiological dead space (Total dead space) = Anatomical + Alveolar dead space.

In healthy individuals with fully functional alveoli, the alveolar dead space is virtually nil. This makes physiological dead space = anatomical dead space. 

In pathological states, due to the presence of alveolar dead space in the form of nonfunctional alveoli, the following equation holds true.

Physiological dead space (alveolar + anatomic) > Anatomic dead space.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with a history of nasal stuffiness, blood-stained nasal discharge, swelling of the cheek, loosening of teeth, and weight loss. On examination, there is an expansion of the alveolus and palate. Investigations confirmed maxillary sinus carcinoma. Which among the following is true about the condition?

choices.text: Growths situated posterosuperior to Ohngren’s line have a good prognosis
The most common variety is squamous cell carcinoma
Submandibular and upper jugular nodes are not enlarged
It is more commonly seen in young females

questions.solution:
The most common variety of maxillary sinus carcinoma is squamous cell carcinoma.

Maxillary sinus carcinoma arises from the sinus lining and is more commonly seen in males and in people aged 40-60 years. Those engaged in nickel refining show a higher incidence of this cancer. The most common variety is squamous cell carcinoma (SCC).

Early features of maxillary sinus carcinoma may present with vague symptoms of sinusitis. Other early features of SCC of the maxillary sinus are nasal stuffiness, blood-stained nasal discharge, facial paraesthesias or pain, and epiphora. Maxillary sinus carcinoma may remain silent for a long time and then spreads to destroy the maxillary sinus and invades the surrounding structures.

The late features of SCC of the maxillary sinus depend on the direction and extent of spread. Some examples are as follows:

  • Medial spread causes nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and epistaxis.
  • Inferior spread causes expansion of alveolus with dental pain, loosening of teeth, poor fitting of dentures, ulceration of gingiva, and swelling in the hard palate.
  • Anterior spread causes swelling of the cheek and later invasion of the facial skin.
  • Superior spread causes proptosis, diplopia, ocular pain, and epiphora.
  • Enlargement of submandibular and upper jugular nodes is seen in maxillary sinus SCC.

Ohngren’s line extends from the medial canthus of the eye to the angle of the mandible. According to Ohngren’s classification, growths situated anteroinferior to this line have a better prognosis than growths posterosuperior to it.

The image given below shows Ohngren’s line:


A CT scan (coronal as well as axial planes) helps in staging the disease and is the best non-invasive method to find the extent of the disease.

Treatment of early cases (Stages I and II) is done with surgery and removal of the tumor. Late stages(stage III and IV) are treated with combined modalities of surgery and radiation. The five-year survival rate is (40-50%).

questions.text: Individuals who had subclinical infection and developed carrier state without suffering from overt disease are known as:
questions.solution:
Healthy carriers are those who had a subclinical infection and developed carrier state without suffering from overt disease. However, they still shed the disease agent.

Examples: Poliomyelitis, cholera, meningococcal meningitis, salmonellosis, and diphtheria.

All individuals with a subclinical infection are not considered as carriers. Only those, who disseminate or shed the disease agent are considered as carriers. For example, in polio, the infection may be subclinical, and the person may shed the virus, thus acting as a healthy carrier. In contrast, a patient with tuberculosis may have a subclinical infection but doesn't disseminate the tubercle bacilli. In such case, the individual with subclinical tuberculosis infection is not a carrier.

Other options:

Paradoxical carriers are carriers who acquired the pathogen from another carrier. Example: A carrier with subclinical polio infection, who acquired the pathogen from another household member, who is also a carrier for polio virus.

Incubatory carriers are those who shed infectious agents during the incubation period of the disease. Which means, these carriers transmit the disease before the onset of the illness. Examples: measles, mumps, polio, pertussis, influenza, diphtheria and hepatitis B.

Convalescent carriers are those who continue to shed the disease agent during the period of convalescence. This may occur in cases where the clinical recovery does not coincide with the bacteriological recovery, and the individual may continue to shed the disease agent. Examples: Typhoid fever, dysentery (bacillary and amoebic), cholera, diphtheria and whooping cough.

questions.text: Which among the following is true regarding the instrument shown in the image?

choices.text: Most commonly used for rotational delivery
Used in the delivery of aftercoming head of breech

questions.solution:
The image shows Piper forceps, and it is used to assist the delivery of aftercoming head in breech presentation. It is identified by its distinct perineal curve.  

It has a cephalic curve, reverse pelvic curve, and long parallel shanks that permit the baby’s body to rest against it during head delivery.

Options A, B, and C are in reference to Kielland forceps. It has a sliding lock and thus can assist in rotational deliveries. It can correct asynclitism and is also useful in deep transverse arrest in patients with persistent occiput transverse position.

Related Pearl: Obstetrics forceps

Commonly used forceps: 

1) Simpson forceps

  • The most commonly used types of forceps in outlet delivery.
  • Has elongated cephalic curve.
  • These are used when there is substantial molding of the fetal head.

2) Elliot forceps

  • Has an adjustable pin for regulating the lateral pressure on the handles.
  • They are used most often when there is minimal molding.
  • More suitable for outlet delivery.

3) Kielland forceps

  • Has small pelvic curve and a sliding lock.
  • Suitable for head with little molding.
  • The most common forceps used for rotational delivery.
  • Helps correct asynclitism.

4) Piper forceps

  • Distinct perineal curve.
  • Allows for application to the after-coming head in breech delivery.

5) Tucker-McLane forceps

  • Suitable for fetal head with little molding.
  • Used in rotational delivery.

6) Barton forceps and traction handle

  • Used in rotational delivery.
  • Most importantly used for delivery of occipitotransverse positions in a platypelloid pelvis.
  • It is an obsolete procedure.

Related Pearl: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

 

Lovset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder. 

 

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

 

Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

  • Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.
  • Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.
  • Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.
  • Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.
  • Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.

 

Mnemonic:

  • Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)
  • Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is brought to the Pediatrician with symptoms of common cold caused by rhinovirus. Which of the following receptors does this virus use to enter the cell?
questions.solution:
The receptor used by the rhinovirus to enter the cell is intercellular adhesion molecule 1 (ICAM-1).

Rhinoviruses are responsible for more than 50% of viral colds and have approximately 100 serotypes. Transmission is by contact with respiratory secretions.

Symptoms include profuse, watery nasal discharge frequently accompanied by symptoms of headache, malaise, sneezing, nasal congestion, sore throat, and cough. Illness generally lasts 10 days to 2 weeks. The infection is typically self-limiting.

Other options

Option B: CD21 is a complement receptor used by the Epstein-Barr virus.

Option C: Integrins are receptors interacting with the extracellular matrix that are used by the adenoviruses.

Option D: CD4, which is a part of the immunoglobulin superfamily, is utilized by HIV and human herpes 7 viruses to enter the cell.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with watery diarrhea associated with frequent epigastric pain, bloating, and indigestion for the past few weeks that did not respond to medications. Stool culture is negative. His lab reports show microcytic hypochromic anemia and serum K+ 2.9 mmol/L. Upper GI endoscopy is normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario describes watery diarrhea, hypokalemia (serum K+<3.5 mM), and symptoms of achlorhydria (bloating, indigestion, iron deficiency) which suggests the diagnosis of WDHA syndrome caused by VIPoma.

VIPoma is pancreatic endocrine neoplasia. The tumor secretes vasoactive intestinal peptides which are responsible for the secretory watery diarrhea and other symptoms mentioned above. While suspecting a case of VIPoma it is essential to conduct a VIP assay so as to confirm the presence of other tumors of neural crest origin such as neuroblastoma or pheochromocytoma. 

Diagnosis can be made by the demonstration of an elevated plasma VIP level and the history of large-volume diarrhea.

Other options: 

Option A: Gastrinoma is a neuroendocrinal tumor characterized by hypersecretion of gastrin resulting in gastrointestinal tract ulcers. The most common presentations of gastrinoma are epigastric pain, diarrhea, and peptic ulcers. The ulcers occur at typical locations (proximal duodenum) and atypical locations (distal duodenum, jejunum). However, in this scenario, the endoscopy findings were normal.

Option C: Delta cell tumor, aka somatostatinoma, is also a pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor presents with cholelithiasis, diarrhea, neurofibromatosis.

Option D: Pancreatic carcinoid is associated with excess serotonin and presents with sweating, flushing, diarrhea, and edema.

Related Pearl: Pancreatic Endocrine Neoplasms

Endocrine neoplasm

Clinical features

Glucagonoma

Mild diabetes mellitus, a characteristic skin rash (necrolytic migratory erythema), and anemia

Insulinoma

Clinically significant hypoglycemia

Gastrinoma

Peptic ulceration often unresponsive to therapy and in unusual locations such as the jejunum

Somatostatinoma

Diabetes mellitus, cholelithiasis, steatorrhea, and hypochlorhydria

VIPoma

Watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, achlorhydria, or WDHA syndrome

Pancreatic polypeptide-secreting endocrine tumors

Present as mass lesions as even high plasma levels of this hormone fail to cause symptoms

Islet hyperplasia (previously known as nesidioblastosis) is seen in maternal diabetes, Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome , and rare mutations in the β-cell K+-channel protein or sulfonylurea receptor.

In maternal diabetes, the fetal islets respond to hyperglycemia by increasing their size and number. In the postnatal period, these hyperactive islets may be responsible for serious episodes of hypoglycemia.

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the image below
questions.solution:
The image is of the Priestley-Smith retinoscope. It is a mirror retinoscope and has a plane mirror at one end and concave at the other. It has a central hole of about 2.5mm anteriorly and 4mm posteriorly.

Retinoscopy is an objective method used to determine the error of refraction by applying the method of neutralization. It is also called skiascopy or shadow test. 

Principle: When light is reflected from a mirror into the eye, the direction in which light will travel across the pupil will depend upon the eye's refractive state. Distance: Usually, the doctor sits at a distance of 1 meter or an arm's length. Types of retinoscopes:

  • Priestley–Smith retinoscope
  • Streak retinoscope

The image given below shows a retinoscopy being performed on a patient.

The image below shows Jackson’s cross cylinder (flip-cross technique) which is used to refine the power and axis of the cylindrical lens.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male with a history of bipolar I disorder presents with symptoms of depressed mood, low energy levels, and suicidal thoughts. Which of the following medications can be used for managing this presentation?
questions.solution:
Quetiapine is used as a first-line agent for the management of acute bipolar depression.

Bipolar I disorder most often starts with depression and is a recurring condition. Patients experience both mania as well as depression. Depression is usually seen in patients between the ages of 15-25 years. 

Differentiating major depressive disorder from bipolar depression is important as management is different. Antidepressant medications like tricyclic antidepressants (eg. amitriptyline, imipramine), monoamine oxidase inhibitors (eg. phenelzine), and serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (eg. venlafaxine) are not recommended for management because of the risk of precipitating mania. They are not appropriate as monotherapy for bipolar depression.

Atypical antipsychotics are used for managing bipolar depression. Quetiapine has shown the most efficacy. Lurasidone has also been approved by the FDA.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an AIDS-defining neoplasm?
questions.solution:
Multiple myeloma is not an AIDS-defining neoplasm.

The neoplasms considered to be AIDS-defining are:

  • Kaposi’s sarcoma
  • Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma
  • Invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix

In addition to these AIDS-defining neoplasms, there is also an increase in the incidence of other malignancies such as multiple myeloma, leukaemia, Hodgkin’s lymphoma, melanoma and carcinomas involving various organs.

Since the introduction of potent combination anti-retroviral therapy, the incidence of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma and Kaposi’s sarcoma has declined.

questions.text: A young female patient presents with abdominal distension and a palpable pelvic mass. Ultrasonography indicates the mass to be ovarian. Staging laparotomy is done and the histopathological slide from this specimen is shown below. Which of the following can act as a reliable tumor marker in post-treatment surveillance?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and the histopathological image showing Schiller Duval bodies are suggestive of a yolk sac tumor/ endodermal sinus tumor. Serum levels of alpha-fetoprotein can act as a reliable tumor marker in posttreatment surveillance. 

Yolk sac tumor originates from embryonal structures of the yolk sac by selective differentiation. Hence, they are rich in alpha-fetoprotein. Therefore, serum alpha-fetoprotein levels are a reliable tumor marker in surveillance after treatment.

A yolk sac tumor is an aggressive malignant germ cell tumor of the ovaries. It presents as abdominal distension and a palpable pelvic mass in children and young women. On appearance, these tumors are yellow, friable (hemorrhagic), and solid mass. 

Most of the yolk sac tumors have Schiller-Duval bodies and they are pathognomonic. This structure consists of a central capillary surrounded by tumor cells, present in a cystic space that is lined by flat to cuboidal tumor cells.

Other options:

Option B: Lactate dehydrogenase(LDH) is a tumor marker in dysgerminoma ovaries.

Option C: Placental alkaline phosphatase(PLAP) is a tumor marker in dysgerminoma ovaries

Option D: Human chorionic gonadotropin(hCG) is a tumor marker in embryonal carcinoma and dysgerminoma ovaries.

Related Pearl: WHO Classification of Ovarian Tumors

  • Mucinous tumors
  • Endometrioid tumors

  • Brenner tumors (transitional cell tumors)

  • Undifferentiated carcinoma
II. Sex cord-stromal tumors:

  • Pure sex cord tumors- Granulosa cell tumor (Adult/Juvenile), Sertoli cell tumor
  • Mixed sex cord-stromal tumors- Sertoli–Leydig cell tumors

III. Germ cell tumors:

  • Dysgerminoma

  • Embryonal carcinoma

  • Teratoma (Mature/immature)
  • Mixed forms
