questions.text:
A patient presents with complaints of colicky pain radiating from the loin to the groin and USG shows the presence of renal calculi. You have been asked to look for tenderness at the renal angle. Which of the following forms the boundaries of this angle?

USG - Ultrasound

choices.text: Lower border of 11th rib and medial border of psoas major
Lower border of 12th rib and medial border of psoas major
Lower border of 11th rib and lateral border of erector spinae
Lower border of 12th rib and lateral border of erector spinae

questions.solution:
The boundaries of renal angle are formed by the lower border of 12th rib and lateral border of the erector spinae muscle.

The lower pole of the kidney occupies this angle. Tenderness in this angle is usually suggestive of infection in and around the kidney or renal stones.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old female had recurrent abortions. On evaluation, she was diagnosed with APLA syndrome. Now she came with complaints of severe headache for the past 2 days. She also had an episode of seizure. Her BP and temperature were higher than normal. What is the diagnosis and the investigation of choice respectively, for this condition?

APLA: antiphospholipid antibody
questions.solution:
A 35-year-old female who was diagnosed with APLA syndrome now presenting with complaints of severe headache for the past 2 days, an episode of seizure with BP and temperature higher than normal is suggestive of cortical vein thrombosis that is diagnosed by MR venography.

It is more common in patients with inherited thrombophilias or antiphospholipid antibodies. Headache is the most frequent presenting symptom, neurological deficits are common, and up to a third of patients have convulsions.

Thrombosis of the lateral or superior sagittal venous sinus usually occurs in the puerperium and often in association with preeclampsia, sepsis, or thrombophilia.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old male presents with increased forgetfulness, difficulty in speech and difficulty learning new things. Amyloid PET imaging revealed diffuse Aβ plaques throughout the neocortex. What changes are seen in neurotransmitters in the brain?

Ach- Acetylcholine
NE- Norepinephrine
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario along with amyloid PET imaging showing diffuse Aβ plaques throughout the neocortex is suggestive of Alzheimer's disease. There will be decreased acetylcholine(Ach), norepinephrine(NE) and serotonin.

Alzheimer's disease is the most common cause of dementia in the elderly. Its incidence increases with age. It has an insidious onset with deficits developing over the course of 5-10 years. Initially, the patient presents with forgetfulness but then progresses to language deficits, loss of mathematical skills, and motor skills. In the end stages, the patient becomes mute, incontinent, and unable to walk.

The pathogenesis of Alzheimer's disease involves the accumulation of Aβ amyloid in the brain. The hallmarks of this condition are amyloid plaques comprised of aggregated Aβ amyloid and neurofibrillary tangles. Neurofibrillary tangles are the cytoplasmic accumulation of tau filaments. Neuritic plaques are focal collections of axonal or dendritic processes around a central amyloid core. In pyramidal neurons, they appear as flame-shaped. These lesions lead to neuronal death. 

On gross examination, the brain shows cortical atrophy which can be seen with gyral narrowing and sulcal widening in the frontal, temporal, and parietal lobes. This will lead to compensatory enlargement of the ventricles.

Other options

Option B: Increased Ach and decreased dopamine is seen in Parkinson’s disease.

Option C: Decreased GABA and serotonin along with increased norepinephrine is seen in anxiety.

Option D: Decreased dopamine, NE and serotonin are seen in depression.

Related Pearl: Alzheimer’s disease

Alzheimer’s disease:

  • Age of onset > 60 years
  • Mini-mental state examination (MMSE) < 24
  • Diagnosis: Clinical
    • 2 or more areas of cognitive deficits
    • Progressive worsening of memory and other cognitive function
    • No disturbance in consciousness
    • Other systemic causes must be ruled out 

Risk Factors:

  • Most important risk factor: Old age
  • Other risk factors – Family history, presenilin-1, presenilin-2, Apolipoprotein E4 (ApoE ε4 allele), Ubiquitin, Down syndrome and smoking.

Protective factors: NSAIDs and Apolipoprotein E2

Causes: Decrease in acetylcholine causing depletion of the cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert resulting in short-term memory defects. 

Early findings:

  • Anterograde memory loss (immediate recall affected, distant memories preserved)
  • Visuospatial deficits (lost in own neighborhood)
  • Language difficulties (difficulty finding words)
  • Cognitive impairment with a progressive decline
  • Anosognosia 
  • Visual processing dysfunction (posterior cortical atrophy syndrome)
  • Difficulties with naming and repetition (logopenic aphasia)

Late findings:

  • Psychotic symptoms: delusions
  • Apraxia: Difficulty to perform learned motor tasks
  • Lack of insight regarding deficits
  • Non-cognitive neurologic deficits: Pyramidal and extrapyramidal, myoclonus and seizures
  • disrupted sleep - wake pattern.
  • Urinary incontinence.
  • Loss of procedural memory

Histopathology:

  • Senile plaques (amyloid deposits), neurofibrillary tangles (composed of tau proteins), neuronal loss, synaptic loss, and granulovacuolar degeneration of neurons.

The image below shows neurofibrillary tangles in Alzheimer's disease.

CT/MRI:

  • Later stages: Cortical and subcortical atrophy prominent in parietal and temporal lobes, particularly hippocampus. 

Treatment:

  • NMDA antagonist: memantine
  • Cholinesterase inhibitors: donepezil, galantamine, rivastigmine.
  • Monoclonal antibodies against the N-terminus of the Aβ peptide - lecanemab, donanemab

questions.text: A patient presents with complain of nasal obstruction. On examination, atrophic changes are noted in the nasal mucosa, along with greenish-black crusting and foul odor suggestive of atrophic rhinitis. What is the likely cause of the patient’s nasal obstruction?
questions.solution:
This is a clinical scenario of a patient with atrophic rhinitis. Patients complain of paradoxical obstruction despite having widened nasal chambers due to degeneration of the sensory nerves of the nasal mucosa, leading to a loss of sensation to airflow. 

Atrophic rhinitis (ozaena) is a chronic inflammation of the nose with atrophy of nasal mucosa and turbinate bones. Roomy nasal cavities with foul-smelling crusts are seen. Patients present with a foul smell from the nose, marked anosmia (merciful anosmia), and paradoxical nasal obstruction (nasal obstruction despite wide nasal passages).

Medical management includes nasal irrigation and removal of crusts. 25% glucose in glycerine, antibiotics (quinolones or metronidazole), and mucolytics can be used.

Other options: 

Options A and B: Turbinates undergo resorption and atrophy in atrophic rhinitis, leading to the widening of the nasal chambers and not narrowing.

Option D: Atrophic rhinitis is also characterized by the arrested development and shrinking of paranasal sinuses. They have thick walls and appear opaque on X-ray. 

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Atrophic Rhinitis

Atrophic rhinitis is more common in females and usually starts at puberty. It is a bilateral condition.

  • Symptoms:
    • Foul smell from the nose
    • Nasal obstruction in spite of roomy chambers due to large crusts filling nasal cavity
    • Epistaxis on removing of the crusts
    • Anosmia due to degeneration of nerve elements (merciful anosmia).
  • Signs:
    • Greenish or greyish black dry crusts covering the turbinates and septum
    • After removal of crusts, nasal cavities appear roomy with atrophy of turbinates
    • Nasal mucosa appears pale.

Related Pearl: Etiology of atrophic rhinitis

Etiology of primary atrophic rhinitis:

  • Hereditary- Involves more than one member of a family
  • Endocrinal- More common in females, starts at puberty and regresses after menopause
  • Racial- More common in mongoloid and caucasian races
  • Nutritional deficiency- Vitamin A, D, iron deficiencies
  • Autoimmune- Antigens of the nasal mucosa
  • Organism- Klebsiella ozaenae

Etiology of secondary atrophic rhinitis:

  • Specific infections like syphilis, lupus, leprosy and, rhinoscleroma
  • Long-standing purulent sinusitis
  • Radiotherapy to nose
  • Excessive surgical removal of turbinates
  • Diphtheroids, Proteus vulgaris, Escherichia coli, staphylococci and streptococci

questions.text: All of the following statements belong to the 10 steps of successful breastfeeding recommended by the Baby Friendly Hospital Initiative (BHFI), except _____.

choices.text: Help mothers initiate breastfeeding within 4 hours of birth
Practice rooming in 24 hours a day

questions.solution:
BHFI recommends breastfeeding as soon as possible after birth.

BFHI is sponsored by the WHO and the United Nations Children’s Fund to promote breastfeeding.

Related Pearl: Baby-friendly hospital initiative (revised 2018)

Ten steps to successful breastfeeding (Revised 2018)

Critical management procedures

1  a. Comply fully with the International Code of Marketing of Breast-milk Substitutes and relevant World Health Assembly resolutions.

    b. Have a written infant feeding policy that is routinely communicated to staff and parents.

    c. Establish ongoing monitoring and data-management systems.

2. Ensure that staff has sufficient knowledge, competence, and skills to support breastfeeding.

Key clinical practices

3. Discuss the importance and management of breastfeeding with pregnant women and their families.

4. Facilitate immediate and uninterrupted skin-to-skin contact and support mothers to initiate breastfeeding as soon as possible after birth.

5. Support mothers to initiate and maintain breastfeeding and manage common difficulties.

6. Do not provide breastfed newborns any food or fluids other than breast milk, unless medically indicated.

7. Enable mothers and their infants to remain together and to practice rooming-in 24 hours a day.

8. Support mothers to recognize and respond to their infants’ cues for feeding.

9. Counsel mothers on the use and risks of feeding bottles, teats, and pacifiers.

10. Coordinate discharge so that parents and their infants have timely access to ongoing support and care.

questions.text: Abdominal examination of a 28-year-old primigravida, who is in the second stage of labour, reveals Bandl’s ring between the active upper segment and the distended lower segment. Which would best describe this ring?
questions.solution:
Bandl's ring is a pathological retraction ring.

Bandl's ring/ pathological retraction ring is formed in cases of obstructed labor. The upper segment of the uterus contracts and retracts vigorously in an attempt to overcome the obstruction while the lower segment dilates.

With each contraction, there is myometrial shortening so that the actively contracting upper segment becomes progressively thicker and shorter. The passive lower segment is progressively stretched and becomes thinner. The junction between the two segments stands out prominently as a pathological retraction ring.

Clinically, the patient is usually in a lot of distress. She will complain of continuous pain in the abdomen and there may be features of maternal exhaustion. It is an indication of cesarean delivery.

Note:

Constriction ring/ Schroeder's ring is formed due to incoordinate uterine action when there is localized spastic contraction of a ring of circular muscle fibers of the uterus. It is formed due to injudicious use of oxytocin and premature rupture of membranes (PROM).

questions.text: A sample of peripheral blood was collected during the night at 1 am for a patient admitted with bilateral lower limb non-pitting edema and the smear microscopy showed the presence of an organism as given in the image below. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
The image demonstrates sheathed microfilaria with nuclei-free tail tip indicative of Wuchereria bancrofti. The clinical scenario is suggestive of elephantiasis. The treatment of choice is Diethylcarbamazine (DEC)

DEC is used in the treatment of lymphatic filariasis and loasis at a daily dosage of 4-6 mg/kg for 14 days. 

The disease can present as classical filariasis or occult filariasis. Clinical features include:

Classical filariasis- Fever, lymphangitis, hydrocele, elephantiasis(non-pitting brawny edema), milky white urine(chylous), etc.

Occult filariasis- Massive eosinophilia, hepatosplenomegaly, dyspnea, arthritis, glomerulonephritis, etc. 

Diagnosis is confirmed by the demonstration of microfilaria in blood, chylous urine, exudate of lymph varix, and hydrocele fluid.  The filarial species is nocturnally periodic,  hence it is preferable to collect night blood samples between 10 pm and 4 am. Diethylcarbamazine is the drug of choice.

Image showing elephantiasis:

Other options: 

Option B: Ivermectin is the preferred drug for the treatment of  Strongyloides stercoralis infection. Ivermectin given orally for 2 days is considered the treatment of choice for human strongyloidiasis. Extended treatment for at least 14 days or at least a week after parasites have been eradicated is required in case of disseminated strongyloidiasis.

Option C: Praziquantel is the drug of choice for the treatment of infections caused by trematodes like Schistosoma, Clonorchis, Opisthorchis, Fasciolopis, Paragonimus, and cestodes like Hymenolepis, Diphyllobothrium, and Taenia.

Option D: Albendazole is the drug of choice for infections caused by nematodes like Ascaris and Trichura, and in cases of neurocysticercosis caused by larval forms of Taenia solium, a cestode.

Related Pearl: Filarial worms and their morphology

questions.text: A 48-year-old female who was on a antihypertensive now came with complaints of swelling and redness of her great toe. Lab investigations show hyperuricemia along with hypokalemia and hypocalcemia. What could be the drug leading to this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with lab findings of hypokalemia and hypocalcemia is suggestive of gout secondary to the use of furosemide.

Furosemide is a loop diuretic. It acts by inhibiting the Na+-K+-2Cl- symporter in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, resulting in increased excretion of sodium, potassium, and chloride. Hypokalemia, hypocalcemia, hyperuricemia, and hypomagnesemia are the important side effects. 

Other options:

Option B: Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic that acts by inhibiting the Na-Cl symporter in the distal convoluted tubule resulting in increased excretion of sodium and chloride. Hydrochlorothiazide results in hypokalemia and hypercalcemia, whereas this patient presents with hypocalcemia. Other findings include hyperuricemia and hypomagnesemia.

Option C:  Losartan is the angiotensin receptor blocker used for the treatment of hypertension. Hyperkalemia is an important side effect of ARBs. Losartan appears to be a safe and efficacious agent to lower serum uric acid levels in patients with hyperuricemia.

Option D: Spironolactone belongs to potassium-sparing diuretics and causes hyperkalemia.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman at 28 weeks of gestation presents with severe acute pain abdomen. Her past history is significant for a uterine fibroid. On examination, her temperature is 38.5°C and the uterus is tender. Investigations revealed leukocytosis and elevated ESR. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In this case, there is a severe acute pain abdomen with fever and elevated leukocyte count in a 28-week pregnant woman with fibroid. Hence the most likely diagnosis is red degeneration of fibroid.

Red degeneration is the most common complication of fibroids in pregnancy. It is due to the breakdown of fibroid resulting in ischemia and pain. Key clinical features in this condition are:

  • Low-grade fever
  • Tender uterus on palpation
  • Elevated leukocytes
  • Elevated ESR

The diagnosis is confirmed with an ultrasound. It is usually self-limiting and can be managed with non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.

Other options

Option A - Calcareous degeneration of fibroid is associated with deposition of phosphates and carbonates in the periphery along the course of the vessels. It is seen in old patients with long-standing myomas. They are described as 'womb-stones' in graveyards. They can be detected on a plain X-ray of the abdomen.

Option B - Sarcomatous change of fibroid is rare in women <40 years of age. It is more commonly seen in a postmenopausal woman, who presents with a tumor which grows suddenly, causing pain and postmenopausal bleeding.

Option D - Torsion of fibroid is seen with pedunculated fibroids and can present with abdominal pain in pregnancy. However, it is not associated with fever and elevated leukocytes.

Related Pearl: Secondary changes and complications in fibromyomas

  • Hyaline change, cystic degeneration and atrophy
  • Calcareous degeneration, osseous degeneration
  • Red degeneration
  • Sarcomatous change
  • Torsion, hemorrhage
  • Infection/ ulceration, particularly in the dependent part of a submucous polyp
  • Inversion of the uterus
  • Endometrial carcinoma associated with fibromyoma
  • Endometrial and myohyperplasia
  • Accompanying adenomyosis
  • Parasitic fibroid

Related Pearl: Complications of pregnancy due to fibroids

  • Increased risk of abortion or miscarriage
  • Preterm labor
  • Abnormal presentation
  • Accidental hemorrhage
  • Dystocic labor
  • Postpartum hemorrhage
  • Puerperal sepsis
  • Uterine inversion

Related Pearl: Indications for treatment in an asymptomatic fibroid

  • Infertility caused by a cornual fibroid blocking the tube, or a submucous fibroid causing habitual abortions.
  • Any fibroid of more than 12 weeks size
  • A pedunculated fibroid which can undergo torsion
  • A fibroid causing pressure on the ureter/ bladder, leaving residual urine and causing a urinary infection.
  • Rapidly growing fibromyoma in a menopausal woman implying impending malignancy
  • When the nature of the tumor cannot be ascertained clinically (laparotomy is needed on this occasion).

questions.text: Given below is an image illustrating a unique mechanism of cell-to-cell spread of a bacterium. Identify the pathogen.
questions.solution:
The given image depicts actin polymerization, which is a mechanism of cell-to-cell spread employed by Listeria monocytogenes.

After entry into the host cell, Listeria causes lysis of phagosome by forming pores,mediated by listeriolysin O. The organisms proliferate, and ActA, another listerial protein, induces host cell actin polymerization, which propels them to the cell membrane. Pushing against the host cell membrane, they cause formation of elongated protrusions called filopods/listeriopods. These filopods are ingested by the adjacent cells, the listeriae are released, and the cycle begins again. L. monocytogenes can thus move from cell to cell without being exposed to antibodies, complement, or polymorphonuclear cells.

Immunity to Listeria is primarily cell-mediated, as demonstrated by the intracellular location of the infection and by the marked association of infection with conditions of impaired cell-mediated immunity such as pregnancy, advanced age, AIDS, lymphoma, and organ transplantation.

questions.text: A female patient who underwent total thyroidectomy 2 days back, presents with severe dyspnea and stridor. She does not have any hoarseness or change in voice. Laryngoscopy reveals both vocal cords to be in a paramedian position. She undergoes a procedure for lateralization of the vocal cords. What is the likely procedure?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy. Type II thyroplasty involves lateralization of the vocal cords and can be done as definitive management for this condition.

Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy is often acute. Neuritis or surgical injuries following thyroidectomy are the most important causes. All the intrinsic muscles are paralyzed in this condition. The vocal cords lie in the median or paramedian position due to the unopposed action of the cricothyroid muscles (supplied by the superior laryngeal nerve). This leads to dyspnoea and stridor but the voice is good and there is no hoarseness.

Many cases of bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy develop stridor and dyspnea that may require tracheostomy as an emergency procedure. Widening the respiratory airway without a permanent tracheostomy can be achieved by:

Lateralization of the vocal cords~

  • Thyroplasty type II- This creates a lateral expansion of the larynx similar to lateralization of the vocal cords.
  • Arytenoidopexy is the fixing of the arytenoid in the lateral position.
  • Transverse cordotomy (Kashima operation)- This involves excising laterally the soft tissue at the junction of the membranous cord and the vocal process of arytenoid with laser.
  • Partial arytenoidectomy- This involves the excision of the medial part of the arytenoid with a laser.
  • Reinnervation procedures- Innervation of the paralyzed posterior cricoarytenoid muscle is achieved by implanting a nerve-muscle pedicle of sternohyoid or omohyoid muscle with its nerve supply from ansa hypoglossi.

Types of thyroplasty:

  • Type I - Medialization of the cords. Done for complete unilateral vocal cord palsy (palsy of both recurrent laryngeal nerve and superior laryngeal nerve)
  • Type II - Lateralization of the cords. Used to improve the airway in bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy
  • Type III - Shortening the cords to reduce vocal pitch
  • Type IV - Lengthening the cords to increase vocal pitch

questions.text: You notice a meteorologist using the instrument given below. What is he trying to measure?
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the above image is sling psychrometer (also called whirling psychrometer). It is used to measure the relative humidity.

Sling psychrometer:

  • It consists of two mercury thermometers (dry and wet), mounted side by side on a wooden frame.
  • A handle is present on one end of the frame, which allows for the rotation of the instrument.
  • By rotating the instrument, the bulbs are exposed to air at a definite velocity.
  • The wet bulb is first moistened by distilled water and the instrument rotated at the rate of four revolutions per second for about 15 seconds.
  • The instrument is rotated twice at an interval of 10 seconds. Two successive readings from the wet-bulb are obtained.
  • These readings are compared with the reading of the dry bulb, and with the help of suitable charts, the relative humidity of the air is determined.

Other instruments used to measure humidity include:

  • Dry and wet bulb hygrometer
  • Assman psychrometer

Other options:

Option A: The air temperature can be measured by several instruments such as globe thermometers, kata thermometer, dry and wet bulb thermometers.

Option C: Atmospheric pressure is measured by instruments called barometers. The commonly used instruments include Fortin's Barometer, Kew Pattern Station Barometer and Barograph.

Option D: Precipitation is a collective term used for rain, snow, hail, dew and frost. It is measured by Symon's Rain-gauge.

Related Pearl: Humidity

Absolute humidity is the weight of water vapor in a unit volume of air and it is expressed as g/kg of air or g/m3 of air.

Relative humidity (RH):

  • It is the ratio of the actual water vapor content to the maximum water vapor content in the air required for saturation of air at a given temperature and pressure. It is expressed as a percentage.
  • RH = Actual water vapor content x 100/ Total water vapor content
  • Very low RH can cause skin problems, irritation of the mucous membranes of the nose and throat, and precipitation of infections. 

Dew point is the temperature to which air has to be cooled to achieve saturation given the pressure and constant moisture content

questions.text:
A 40-year-old male with bronchial asthma was treated with regular inhaled corticosteroids. He now came with worsened symptoms and was commenced on theophylline as an add-on therapy. The anti-inflammatory effect of this drug is mediated through which mechanism?

PDE-Phosphodiesterase
questions.solution:
The anti-inflammatory effect of theophylline is mediated through PDE 4 inhibition. Other mechanisms for antiinflammation include increased IL 10(option C) and enhancement of histone deacetylation(option D).

Theophylline is a methylxanthine drug used in the management of asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Its  mechanisms of action are as follows

  • Inhibits phosphodiesterase non-selectively, (PDE3, PDE4) thereby, increasing cellular cAMP and cGMP, causing bronchodilation as well as inhibiting inflammatory mediators release.
  • Adenosine causes bronchoconstriction by releasing histamine and leukotrienes. Theophylline antagonizes adenosine receptors causing bronchodilation. (option B)
  • Increases IL-10 release, which has an anti-inflammatory effect.
  • Decreases gene transcription of pro-inflammatory cytokines.
  • Promotes apoptosis of granulocytes, reducing the inflammatory load in the airways.

Theophylline is mainly metabolized by the enzyme CYP1A2 enzyme. Various drug interactions of theophylline include:

  • Increased clearance (CYP1A2 enzyme induction) by smoking, phenytoin, rifampicin, and phenobarbitone.
  • Decreased clearance (CYP1A2 enzyme inhibition) by erythromycin, cimetidine, ciprofloxacin, oral contraceptives, and allopurinol.

Important side effects of this drug due to PDE4 antagonism are nausea, vomiting, and gastric discomfort, and those due to adenosine A1 receptor antagonism are diuresis, cardiac arrhythmias, and seizures.

questions.text:
The urine analysis of an SLE patient is shown in the image below. Choose the correct option regarding the pathogenesis of this finding.

SLE-Systemic lupus erythematosus

GBM-Glomerular basement membrane
questions.solution:
The urine microscopy shows orange-red to brown coloured casts, which are suggestive of RBC casts and this is a case of glomerular hematuria (presence of even a single RBC cast suggests a glomerular origin of hematuria) indicating lupus nephritis. Pathogenesis in lupus nephritis is majorly attributed to the DNA-anti DNA complex on GBM.

Lupus nephritis is a serious complication of systemic lupus erythematosus, seen in about 30-50% of patients with SLE. Renal involvement may be in the form of glomerulonephritis or tubulointerstitial nephritis. Glomerular lesions develop due to the deposition of the circulating immune complexes on the glomerular basement membrane, mesangium, and throughout the glomerulus.

Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) is a chronic autoimmune disorder representing a Type III Hypersensitivity reaction, ie, immune complex depositions. The typical autoantibodies that are diagnostic of SLE are Anti-Nuclear (ANAs) ( non-specific), Anti-double stranded DNA (Anti-dsDNA), and Anti-Smith (Anti-Sm) antibodies. Patients present with a multi-system involvement with symptoms like maculopapular butterfly rash, photosensitivity, oral or nasal ulcers, fever, and intermittent polyarthritis.

RBC casts form as RBCs entering the tubule fluid become trapped in the cylindrical mould of Tamm-Horsfall protein. For the diagnosis of glomerular diseases from urine, the 40/5/1 rule is followed:

  • 40% dysmorphic RBCs
  • 5% acanthocytes (a subtype of dysmorphic red blood cells with protruding blebs)
  • Even a single (1) RBC cast

Other options: 

Option A: Antiphospholipid antibodies are seen associated with anti-phospholipid syndrome (APS), a thrombotic disorder, but they are also frequently detected in immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP), a bleeding disorder.

Option B: There is no evidence that ANAs can penetrate intact cells, however, they react with exposed cell nuclei and form LE bodies, hence systemic manifestations are attributed more towards Anti-dsDNA antibodies.

Option C: Anti-LKM antibodies are seen in auto-immune hepatitis

questions.text: A patient with end-stage renal disease from diabetic nephropathy is a candidate for renal transplant. A live kidney donor has been identified. Identify the correct statement about renal transplant in this scenario.

choices.text: The donor’s right kidney is preferred for transplant
Nephrectomy of recipient's damaged kidneys is indicated here
The renal vein is anastomosed to the internal iliac vein
The iliac fossa is the ideal site for transplantation

questions.solution:
In this scenario, for the renal transplant from a live kidney donor, the iliac fossa is the ideal site for transplantation in the recipient.

Kidney transplantation is indicated in patients with end-stage renal disease (ESRD). It is associated with better outcomes and better life expectancy when compared to hemodialysis. The leading causes of ESRD necessitating renal transplant include diabetic nephropathy, hypertension, and chronic glomerulonephritis. 

Nephrectomy of damaged kidneys in the recipient for the causes above is not indicated (option B).  However, nephrectomy is indicated in cases of chronic pyelonephritis, large polycystic kidneys, significant vesicoureteral reflux, or uncontrollable renovascular hypertension.

The donor's left kidney is preferred for transplant because of a longer vascular pedicle (option A). The donor kidney is transplanted into one of the recipient's iliac fossae. This is because of the proximity of the iliac fossae to the bladder and iliac vessels. 

The transplant renal vein is anastomosed to the external or common iliac vein (option C). The transplant renal artery is anastomosed preferably to the internal iliac artery for live donors. However, it can also be anastomosed to the external or common iliac artery. After revascularisation of the transplanted kidney, the ureter is then anastomosed to the bladder.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presented with fever, abdominal cramps, and bloody diarrhea. On gram staining, gull wing-shaped gram-negative bacilli with leucocytes are seen and stool microscopy shows darting motility. Which of the following is a correct growth requirement for this micro-organism?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of fever, abdominal cramps, bloody diarrhea and gram staining showing gull-wing–shaped gram-negative bacilli with leukocytes and stool microscopy showing darting motility is suggestive of Campylobacter jejuni. The most suitable growth requirement is to incubate at 42°C, 5% oxygen.

Darting motility is seen in Vibrio cholerae and Campylobacter jejuni.

Campylobacters are gram-negative curved, or spiral-shaped organisms having a sea gull’s wing appearance (Shown in the image below). It is microaerophilic (shows growth in 5-10% oxygen) and thermophilic (prefers higher temperatures and grows best at 42°C). It is oxidase-positive, catalase-positive, and nitrate reduction positive. They multiply at a slower rate when compared to other Gram-negative, enteric bacteria, hence require antibiotic-containing selective media such as Campy-Blood agar, and Skirrow’s media for isolation of campylobacters from stool specimens.

Skirrow’s medium is selective for Campylobacter species. It contains vancomycin, polymyxin B, and trimethoprim to inhibit the growth of other bacteria. Plates were incubated at 43°C with 5 % oxygen, 10 % carbon dioxide, and 85 % nitrogen. Colonies may be observed after overnight incubation.

questions.text:
The laboratory results of a patient with congestive cardiac failure are given below. He does not have any preexisting renal condition. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Urine sodium  18 mEq/L
Urine osmolality 800 mOsm/L of water
Fractional excretion of Na <1%
Urine/plasma creatinine >40
questions.solution:
Based on the history of congestive cardiac failure and given laboratory values, the most likely diagnosis is prerenal acute kidney injury. 

Prerenal acute kidney injury occurs due to reduced renal plasma flow and intraglomerular hydrostatic pressure. Common causes are hypovolemia, liver failure, and congestive heart failure. The kidney has autoregulatory mechanisms to compensate for the decreased blood flow resulting in the retention of sodium and water to preserve blood volume. The urinary sodium and fractional excretion of sodium (FeNa) will be also very low. The ratio of urine creatine/plasma creatinine is usually greater than 40:1. The urinary sodium is generally <20 mEq/L.

Other options: 

Option A: Intrinsic acute kidney injury arises due to injury to the tubules, interstitium, blood vessels, or glomeruli. These include but are not limited to acute glomerulonephritis, vasculitis, sepsis, infections, and malignancies. 

Option C: Nephrotoxic acute kidney injury is a type of intrinsic kidney injury due to direct damage to the tubular cells of the kidney. They can be endogenous toxins such as myoglobin, hemoglobin, and uric acid. Contrast agents, aminoglycosides, and amphotericin B are also implicated.

Option D: Glomerulonephritis can cause intrinsic kidney failure by compromising the filtration barrier and the blood flow within the renal circulation. The FeNA is <1% and urinary sodium is generally <20 mEq/L.

questions.text: Identify the following instrument that was devised to measure the cooling power of air as well as low air velocities.
questions.solution:
The image shown above is of the kata thermometer, which is used to measure the cooling power of the air.

Related Pearl: Measurement of Air Temperature

A number of thermometers that employ mercury or alcohol are used for measuring air temperature.

These thermometers are mounted on a special screen called Stevenson screen as air should have free access to their bulbs and they must be protected from radiant heat.

The instruments used to measure air temperature are:

1) Dry bulb thermometers:

These are ordinary mercury thermometers mounted on a Stevenson screen at about 1.20 to 1.80 metres above sea level

2) Wet bulb thermometers:

These are just like the dry bulb variants but the bulb is kept wet by a muslin cloth that is fed with water from a bottle through a wick.

3) Maximum thermometer

This is a mercury thermometer that has a very fine constriction near the neck of the bulb

4) Minimum thermometer

The liquid in this thermometer is a spirit that has a dumb-bell shaped index immersed in it

5) Six’s maximum-minimum thermometer

  • This thermometer has both mercury and alcohol
  • It measures the maximum and minimum air temperatures reached over a period of time
  • A mercury-free variant of this thermometer is available

5) Globe thermometer:

  • It is used for the direct measurement of the mean radiant temperature of the surroundings.
  • It has a hollow metal globe (6 inches diameter) that has matte black paint which absorbs radiant heat. A specially calibrated mercury bulb thermometer is kept inside.
  • The difference between the readings of the globe thermometer and the bulb thermometer is the measure of the radiant heat.

7) Kata thermometers:

  • It is an alcohol thermometer and consists of a wet kata and a dry kata.
  • A wet kata reading of 20 and above and a dry kata reading of 6 and above were taken as indices of thermal comfort.
  • It was originally used to measure the cooling power of the air (air temperature, humidity and air movement) but currently it is used only as an anemometer to measure low air velocities.

questions.text: A 50-year-old lady presented with a 1.5 cm pigmented lesion on the face which is growing rapidly and is associated with itching. Dermoscopy examination is shown below which revealed an atypical, pigmented network. The dermatologist performs an excisional biopsy. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 1.5 cm pigmented lesion on the face which is asymmetrical, with an irregular border, made of black and brown pigments, and increasing rapidly in size, points towards a diagnosis of malignant melanoma. 

Dermoscopy is similar to a simple magnifying lens applied on the skin surface with an intervening oil layer. It is used for better visualization of surface lesions. It helps in differentiating malignant melanoma from other benign lesions in case of doubt. Other uses include examination of scabies burrows or trichoscopy and tungiasis.

Dermoscopic appearance patterns have been classified and specific scoring systems devised (ABCD dermoscopy score and seven-point checklist) to diagnose malignant melanoma. The following dermoscopic appearances point toward a diagnosis of malignant melanoma:      

  • Atypical network (seen as circled in question image - the spaces are placed at irregular intervals)
  • Atypical vascular structures
  • Atypical blotch
  • Atypical dots and globules
  • Regression structures
  • Crystalline structures
  • Negative network
  • Streaks
  • The blue-white veil over raised areas
  • Peripheral tan structureless areas.

If dermoscopic appearances point towards melanoma, a biopsy is done and accordingly treatment is initiated. If dermoscopic structures point towards a benign lesion, monitoring can be done.

Other options:

Option A: A dysplastic nevus is formed at the dermo-epidermal junction. They are usually smaller in size than melanoma, have a fuzzy border, and are more likely to show brown-tan pigmentation. Any blue-black pigmentation should raise suspicion of melanoma. The majority of dysplastic nevi regress on their own

Option B: Congenital melanocytic nevus may be small, medium, or large size (>20cm). A large-sized mole may show an atypical network and have a risk of melanoma growth. But a history of being present since birth or infancy needs to be present.

Option C: Acquired melanocytic nevus (common mole) is rarely more than 1cm in size. It also does not show an atypical network.

The image below demonstrates how a dermoscopy is performed:

Related Pearl: Clinical Findings suggestive of Melanoma

The ABCDE of melanoma consists of the rules for the examination of a nevus to assess its malignant potential:

A : Asymmetry

  • Melanoma lesions are irregular, or not symmetrical, in shape

B : Border irregular

  • Melanoma lesions usually have irregular borders that are ill-defined

C : Color variation

  • The presence of multiple colors (blue, black, brown, tan, etc.) or the uneven distribution of color

D : Diameter >6 mm

  • Melanoma lesions are often greater than 6 millimeters in diameter (approximately the size of a pencil eraser)

E : Evolution

  • There is a change in the size, shape, symptoms (such as itching or tenderness), surface (especially bleeding), or color of a mole

questions.text:
A patient, who is a known case of stage 5 CKD, presents with complaints of muscle weakness and bone pain. She receives hemodialysis twice weekly. Lab investigations reveal reduced serum calcium and elevated phosphate. Which of the following is responsible for this condition?

CKD - chronic kidney disease
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with a known history of stage 5 CKD, presenting with complaints of muscle weakness and bone pain, and investigations revealing reduced serum calcium and elevated phosphate is suggestive of renal osteodystrophy of CKD. The underlying pathophysiology involves increased levels of FGF-23.

FGF-23 is part of a family of phosphatonins that lowers serum phosphate levels in three ways:

  • increased renal phosphate excretion
  • stimulation of parathyroid hormone, which also increases renal phosphate excretion
  • suppression of formation of calcitriol, leading to diminished phosphorous absorption from the gastrointestinal tract

In CKD, due to decreased GFR, there is phosphate retention leading to increased FGF-23 and secondary hyperparathyroidism. 

Additionally, there is a decreased calcitriol production (1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D) and increased degradation of calcitriol by FGF-23. Decreased calcitriol results in decreased serum calcium which also stimulates parathyroid hormone production. 

The resultant secondary hyperparathyroidism increases bone turnover and leads to the development of osteitis fibrosa cystica. It results in the formation of abnormal osteoid and bone cysts. This is responsible for the clinical symptoms of bone pain and fragility fractures. High levels of parathyroid hormone also cause muscle weakness and constitutional symptoms like fatigue. 

Related Pearl: Parathyroid Diseases

questions.text: Which of the following antiarrhythmics is ineffective for use in the following arrhythmia?
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows irregular rhythm with absent P waves, suggestive of atrial fibrillation. Lidocaine is ineffective in the treatment of atrial fibrillation.

Lidocaine is a class IB antiarrhythmic, which acts by blocking the inactivated sodium channels more than those in the open state. Lidocaine shortens the action potential duration in the Purkinje fibres and ventricular muscle but has practically no effect on the action potential duration and effective refractory period of the atrial fibres.This is because atrial action potentials are so short that the Na+ channel is in the inactivated state only briefly. Hence lidocaine is not useful in atrial arrhythmias.

It is used in the treatment of ventricular tachycardia(VT) and ventricular fibrillation(VF), especially in cases of myocardial infarction and digitalis toxicity.

Other options:

Option A - Esmolol is a class II antiarrythmic.This quick and short acting beta blocker administered i.v. and is very useful for emergency control of ventricular rate in atrial fibrillation/flutter and can terminate supraventricular tachycardia.

Option C - Amiodarone is a class III antiarrythmic. It is a multichannel blocker and blocks potassium, sodium, calcium channels and the beta receptor. It is effective in a wide range of ventricular and supraventricular arrhythmias. Resistant VT and recurrent VF are the most important indications.It is also used to maintain sinus rhythm in AF when other drugs have failed. 

Option D - Sotalol is a beta blocker as well as K+ channel blocker, hence shares properties of class II and III antiarrythmics.It is effective in polymorphic VT, some WPW arrhythmias and for maintaining sinus rhythm in atrial fibrillation/flutter.

questions.text: A 30-year-old G3P2 woman was admitted to the labor room. You were asked to perform a vaginal examination and calculate the modified Bishop's score. Which among the following parameter is not used in this score?
questions.solution:
Cervical effacement % is not used in the calculation of the modified Bishop score. It has been replaced with cervical length.

The Bishop score is a cervical scoring system used to assess the induction of labor. The parameters calculated include:

  • Cervical length (effacement in the original score): The length of the cer­vical canal reflects the degree of cervical effacement
  • Cervical position: It refers to the relation­ship of the cervical os to the fetal head.
    • It can be posterior, mid-position, or anterior.
  • Cervical dilatation: It is determined by estimating the average diameter of the cervical opening. The cervix is said to be fully dilated at 10 cm.
  • Consistency of the cervix: Maybe soft, firm, or inter­mediate between these two.
  • Station of the head: It refers to the level of the presenting fetal part in the birth canal concerning the ischial spines. Each fifth represents 1 cm above or below the spines.
    • As the presenting fetal part descends from the inlet toward the ischial spines, the designation is -5,
      -4, -3, -2, -1, 0 stations till the ischial spines.
    • Past the ischial spines, it is +1, +2, +3, +4, and +5 sta­tions to delivery.
    • Station +5 cm indicates that the fetal head is visible at the introitus.

These parameters are noted while doing a vaginal examination. The maximum attainable score is 13. A Bishops score >=9 indicates a high likelihood for successful induction of labor. A score <=6 is considered unfavorable.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used to achieve dilatation of the pupil has no cycloplegic action?
questions.solution:
Phenylephrine, an alpha 1 agonist, has no cycloplegic action. It causes isolated mydriasis by the contraction of the dilator pupillae (radial muscle) of the iris.

Atropine, cyclopentolate, and tropicamide are antimuscarinics that are available for ophthalmic use and cause cycloplegia to a variable extent. This cycloplegia/paralysis of accommodation occurs due to their parasympatholytic action, which decreases the tone of the ciliary body.

questions.text: Identify the marked finding in a patient who underwent cataract surgery.
questions.solution:
The image shows a Soemmering’s ring. It is defined as a thick ring of after cataract or secondary cataract that persists or develops after extracapsular cataract extraction. No treatment is needed if the central posterior capsule is clear.

If the central posterior capsule is covered by a thin membrane, YAG-laser capsulotomy or discission with cystitome/Zeigler’s knife is done. If the membrane is thick, surgical membranectomy is needed.

Other options:

Option A: Vossius ring – Formed after blunt trauma as a circular brown ring on the anterior lens capsule. It is caused by the contracted pupillary margin striking against the lens capsule.

Option C: Weiss or Vogt’s ring – It is seen in posterior vitreous detachment as a ring around the optic disc. This appearance is caused by the attachment of the peripapillary glial tissue to the detached vitreous cortex.

Option D: Fleischer’s ring – It refers to a brown ring formed by iron deposition around the base of the cone in keratoconus.

questions.text: A hospital is considering to introduce a new diagnostic test for a particular disease. They want to evaluate the efficiency of this test compared to the existing standard test, based on health outcomes. Which economic evaluation method would be most appropriate for this analysis?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate economic evaluation method for the given scenario would be Cost-effectiveness analysis.

The Cost-effectiveness analysis measures the costs and outcomes of different interventions and calculates the cost-effectiveness ratio. The benefits of the health care system are expressed in terms of results achieved (Eg: the number of lives saved or the number of days free from disease). This is a more promising tool in the health field than cost-benefit analysis. But in many cases, it is not possible to use cost-effective analysis. 

Other options:

Option A: Cost-benefit analysis: Here the economic benefits of any program are compared with the cost of the program. The benefits are expressed in monetary terms (whereas in cost-effectiveness analysis it is expressed in terms of results achieved)to identify whether it is economically sound and to select the best one from several alternate programs. The main drawback of this technique is that the benefits of a particular program in the health field cannot always be expressed in monetary terms. Usually, the benefits are expressed in terms of births or deaths prevented, or illness avoided or overcome.

Option C: Input-output analysis: It provides information on how much input is needed to produce a unit amount of output. In the health field, input refers to all health service activities that consume resources (manpower, money, materials, and time); and output refers to useful outcomes such as cases treated, lives saved, or inoculations performed.

Option D: Cost-Accounting: It is a quantitative method of management of healthcare programs that provides basic data on the financial structure of a given program. Financial records are maintained which helps associate costs with the purpose for which they are incurred.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man working in the mining industry comes with complaints of dyspnea.  A chest X-ray showed eggshell calcification in the hilar lymph nodes and the CT scan of the patient is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A 42-year-old man who works in the mining industry presenting with complaints of dyspnea, chest X-ray showing eggshell calcification of the hilar lymph nodes and the given CT showing a “crazy paving pattern” is suggestive of silicosis.

Silicosis is an occupational disease caused by exposure to silica or crystalline quartz. It is seen in people who work in mining, stone cutting, sandblasting, and quarrying.

Silicosis presents as small rounded opacities in the upper lobe. There may be calcification of hilar lymph nodes which leads to the appearance of eggshell calcification. HRCT will show a characteristic crazy paving pattern due to interlobular septal thickening on the background of ground-glass opacity.

Other options:

Option A:  Asbestosis is an occupational disease and is characterized by diffuse interstitial fibrosis of the lung due to asbestos exposure. It is seen in people who work in shipbuilding, processing, construction, and mining industries. Irregular or linear opacities are usually noted in the lower lung fields and are the radiographic hallmark of asbestosis. HRCT will show the presence of pleural plaque, and subpleural curvilinear lines that appear parallel to the pleura.

Option C: Berylliosis is an occupational disease due to chronic exposure to beryllium. It is seen in people who work on processing alloys for high-tech industries. Chest radiography shows nodules along the septal lines with hilar and mediastinal lymph node enlargement. HRCT will show pulmonary nodules, diffuse interstitial fibrosis, and interlobular septal thickening. 

option D: Byssinosis is an occupational disease due to chronic exposure to cotton dust as in textile and rope-making industries. Chest X-ray shows hyperlucency, diaphragmatic flattening, and emphysema. A chest CT demonstrates ground glass opacities largely distributed in the basal regions with centrilobular nodules.

questions.text: Identify the correct statement about the post-mortem phenomenon shown in the image below.

choices.text: It occurs in the large muscle groups of the body
It is associated with an absent primary relaxation
It helps to identify the time since death

questions.solution:
The given image depicts the post-mortem change of cadaveric spasm and primary relaxation is absent in cadaveric spasm.

Cadaveric spasm has been observed in the following situations:

  • Drowning death
  • Brain Injury
  • Fear or Excitement
  • Electrocution

Cadaveric spasm is an antemortem change that indicates the cause and manner of death. This phenomenon is alternatively referred to as instantaneous rigor or cataleptic rigidity.

Primary relaxation of body muscles is absent whereas it is present before rigor mortis sets in.

The victims do not undergo postmortem flaccidity (unlike rigor mortis), thereby directly entering a state of instantaneous rigor. This results in muscle stiffening which indicates the victim's attitude at the time of death. Cadaveric spasm is limited to select muscles mostly voluntary, smaller groups of muscles (option A) i.e., the muscles that were in a state of contraction at the time of death. The mechanism of cadaveric spasm is thought to be due to neurogenic phenomena. The cells do not undergo necrosis since cell death has not occurred as they may respond to electrical stimuli (option C).

Predisposing factors for this postmortem change include excitement, fear, fatigue, electrocution, nervous system injury, and convulsant poisons such as strychnine. It is a unique phenomenon that cannot be replicated by any other situation, and it is not possible to induce it through any means following the cessation of life. Hence it is useful to get an idea about the manner of death (option D).

A significant amount of force is necessary to overcome stiffness. The phenomenon seamlessly transitions into typical rigor mortis and ceases to exist after rigor mortis subsides. The process of protein coagulation can be observed under microscopic analysis in burns, but not in cases of cadaveric spasm.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with AIDS presents to the local clinic with fever, nausea, vomiting, and confusion. A diagnosis of invasive cryptococcosis was made. Which of the following is false regarding the causative agent?

choices.text: Can de demonstrated by India ink
Can be cultured in Niger seed agar

questions.solution:
Cryptococcus neoformans cannot be diagnosed with the (1→3)-β-D-glucan assay. 

(1→3)-β-D-Glucan assay is used for the diagnosis of Candida infections, invasive aspergillosis, and Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia. It is not useful in the case of invasive cryptococcosis.

C. neoformans is an opportunistic fungus that is found as a saprophyte in soil enriched with pigeon droppings. Infection is initiated by inhalation of the yeast cells. Cryptococci have been classified into 5 serotypes (A, B, C, D, and AD) based on their capsular polysaccharide:

  • Three of these serotypes, A, D, and AD, are classified as varieties of C. neoformans: C. neoformans var. grubii (serotype A), C. neoformans var. neoformans (serotype D), and a hybrid of serotypes A and D (serotype AD). Although serotype AD is very similar to serotypes A and D, the isolates still comprise a discrete group that can be distinguished.
  • Serotypes B and C are now classified as a different species: Cryptococcus gattii.

The image given below shows the life cycle of C. neoformans:

Pathogenic varieties of Cryptococcus, including C. neoformans and C. gattii, are laccase positive. They also have the ability to grow at 37°C, and these factors are used to differentiate them from non-pathogenic cryptococci.

The primary pulmonary infection may be asymptomatic or may mimic an influenza-like respiratory infection, often resolving spontaneously. Cutaneous infection results in ulcers and granulomata. In immunocompromised individuals, the yeasts may multiply and disseminate to other parts of the body, but preferentially to the CNS, causing cryptococcal meningoencephalitis, which presents with headache and nuchal rigidity.

Diagnosis is established by microscopic examination of cerebrospinal fluid, which shows gram-positive round budding yeast cells on gram staining. India ink preparation reveals capsulated budding yeast cells (option B). The image given below shows Cryptococcus neoformans stained with India ink:

Mucicarmine stain can also be used in the identification of Cryptococcus. The image given below shows a mucicarmine-stained specimen of lung tissue containing cryptococci:

The culture on Sabouraud dextrose agar (SDA) at 37°C appears as smooth, mucoid, and creamy white. The cryptococcal antigen can also be demonstrated by the latex agglutination test (option C). Niger seed agar is a solid medium used for selective and differential isolation of C. neoformans from clinical specimens (option D). C. neoformans and C. gattii produce brown colonies on this medium due to the formation of melanin, which is produced because laccase uses caffeic acid as the substrate.

Treatment of cryptococcal meningitis involves combination therapy of amphotericin B with flucytosine. Fluconazole can be administered along with these drugs in AIDS patients to prevent relapse.

questions.text: A couple arrives at an infertility clinic with a complaint of not being able to conceive even after unprotected sexual intercourse for 2 years. Starting the investigations for the cause of the same, the gynecologist orders a semen analysis of the husband. In a semen analysis report, according to WHO criteria, which of the following is an abnormal finding?
questions.solution:
Progressive motility of 22% is the abnormal finding in the semen analysis. Total motility should be at least 42% and 30% should have progressive forward motility.

Semen abnormalities:

  • An acidic pH or lack of fructose indicates an obstruction in the efferent ductal system.
  • A low semen volume reflects incomplete specimen collection, short abstinence interval, partial vas deferens obstruction or retrograde ejaculation
  • Oligospermia: A sperm concentration <15 million/ ml, and counts <5 million/mL are considered severe.
  • Azoospermia: Absence of sperm in semen due to outflow tract obstruction as a result of congenital absence of vas, infection, vasectomy, or non-obstructive causes like testicular failure.
  • Teratospermia or teratozoospermia: Abnormal sperm morphology 

Note: 

Morphology is the most important factor/marker of semen analysis.

The revised WHO recommendations, 2021 for normal semen analysis are as follows:

questions.text: Which of the following scenarios is a contraindication for the use of the contraceptive device given below?

choices.text: 3 months postpartum female who is breastfeeding

questions.solution:
The given image represents Mirena, an intrauterine contraceptive device. It is contraindicated for use in pelvic tuberculosis.

Mirena is a third-generation intrauterine contraceptive device, containing 52mg of levonorgestrel. Its approved life span is 5 years. Apart from contraception, it is used for the treatment of menorrhagia, endometrial hyperplasia without atypia, and dysmenorrhea secondary to endometriosis and adenomyosis.

The absolute contraindications( WHO category 4 medical eligibility criteria) for its use are :

  • Pregnancy or suspected pregnancy
  • Undiagnosed genital tract bleeding
  • Endometrial cancer
  • Breast cancer
  • Cervical cancer
  • Current purulent cervicitis (sexually transmitted infection)
  • Current pelvic inflammatory disease (including pelvic tuberculosis)
  • Distorted uterine cavity
  • Gestational trophoblastic disease
  • Puerperal sepsis

All the other options fall under WHO Category 1 of medical eligibility criteria, making the use of Mirena safe in these conditions.

questions.text: While performing laparoscopic surgery, there is a sudden drop in the patient's blood pressure when you inflate the abdomen to create pneumoperitoneum. The characteristic 'mill-wheel' murmur is heard on an esophagal stethoscope. Which of the following is the most appropriate management of this condition?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the presence of a sudden drop in the patient's blood pressure while inflating the abdomen during laparoscopic surgery and the presence of the characteristic 'mill-wheel' murmur on an esophagal stethoscope is suggestive of air embolism. The most appropriate management is inserting a central venous catheter to aspirate the air out of the right ventricle.

Gas emboli is a serious complication of laparoscopic surgery. It is commonly seen when gases like helium, neon or argon are used to create pneumoperitoneum, a technique that enhances laparoscopic surgery by distending the abdominal cavity and splitting up its contents.

Hypotension during insufflation should raise suspicions about gas emboli. The characteristic "mill wheel" murmur can be detected using an esophagal stethoscope to confirm the diagnosis. It is treated by positioning the patient in a left lateral decubitus position, with the head down, to trap the gas in the right ventricle's apex. The gas can then be aspirated out of the right ventricle rapidly by placing a central venous catheter.

Other options:

Options A, B, and C: Bradycardia, which is a common complication during laparoscopic surgery, is caused by a vagovagal response due to rapid stretching of the peritoneal membrane during CO2 pneumoperitoneum. This can be managed by desufflation of the abdomen, the use of vagolytic medications (such as atropine), and rapid volume replacement.

questions.text: A 50 year old man was newly diagnosed with stable angina. He presented with constipation two weeks after the initiation of treatment. Which drug is possibly implicated in his new symptom?
questions.solution:
Constipation is a frequent side effect of oral verapamil.

Verapamil is a calcium channel blocker and a class IV antiarrhythmic, used in the treatment of angina, hypertension, supraventricular tachyarrythmias and in the prophylaxis of migraine (off label). It delays the AV nodal conduction, thereby decreasing the heart rate and also dilates the arterioles.

Its side effects include :

  • Hypotension
  • Sinus bradycardia or AV block especially, in combination with β blockers
  • Constipation
  • Worsening of heart failure

Other options:

Option A - Adverse effects to look out for with aspirin use are occult blood loss in stools, hypersensitivity reactions, salicylism at anti inflammatory doses and Reye’s syndrome in children with viral infection.

Option B - The side effects attributed to statins include elevation in serum aminotransaminase and creatine kinase, muscle aches, myopathy (especially when co-administered with inhibitors of CYP3A4)

Option C - Common side effects of telmisartan are hypotension, hyperkalemia and teratogenicity.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old male on ART presents with a ring-enhancing sign on his CT brain. The following is his MR spectroscopy image with a lipid peak. The most likely diagnosis is?

ART: antiretroviral therapy
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the presented MR spectroscopic image showing a significant lipid peak, point towards the diagnosis of Tuberculoma of the brain.

An MR Spectroscopy analyses the metabolite distribution within a chosen volume of brain tissue, thereby providing semiquantitative information. 

MR spectroscopy findings of a tuberculoma :

  • elevated choline peak
  • increased choline to NAA ratio
  • significant increase in lipid
  • inverted high lactate

Tuberculomas (parenchymal granulomas) can mostly occur at the junction of white and grey matter. On CT they appear as small rounded lesions, solid lesions show homogenous enhancement on contrast CT and show ring enhancement when central caseation or liquefaction occurs. 

The following image shows normal MR spectroscopy findings.

Other options :

Option A: In Canavan disease, there is a marked increase in N-acetyl aspartate. Its concentration decreases with insults to the brain such as neoplasm, infarct, or abscess. N-acetyl aspartate (NAA) which is the most prominent resonance in a proton spectrum, is accepted as a normal neuronal functional marker.

Option B: In Glioma MR spectroscopy shows a raised choline peak with a depressed N-acetyl aspartate peak, but absent lipid peak.

Option C: Lymphoma typically demonstrates marked increase in choline, decreased creatine and NAA with less marked increase in lipid peak.

questions.text: A 68-year-old chronic smoker complains of cough, hemoptysis, and chest pain. The radiological investigations reveal a tumor arising from a major bronchus. Histopathology shows small cells with a salt and pepper pattern of chromatin and basophilic staining of the vascular walls. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A 68-year-old chronic smoker presenting with cough, hemoptysis, and chest pain with radiological findings of a tumor arising from a major bronchus and histopathology showing small cells with a salt and pepper pattern of chromatin and basophilic staining of the vascular walls (Azzopardi effect) is most likely small cell carcinoma of the lung.

Small cell carcinoma of the lung belongs to the neuroendocrine tumors and originates from neuroendocrine progenitor cells, Kulchitsky cells that lines the bronchial epithelium. It is a highly malignant tumor with a high association with cigarette smoking. They mainly arise from the major bronchi.

Histopathology of small cell lung carcinoma shows clusters of small cells which are round, oval, or spindle-shaped, and a prominent nuclear molding. These cells have scant cytoplasm, ill-defined cell borders, finely granular nuclear chromatin (salt and pepper pattern), and absent or inconspicuous nucleoli. Azzopardi effect is described as basophilic staining of vascular walls due to coating by DNA from necrotic tumor cells.

Neuroendocrine markers seen in small cell lung carcinoma include:

  • Chromogranin
  • Synaptophysin
  • CD56

Paraneoplastic syndromes associated with small cell carcinoma of the lung are Cushing syndrome due to ACTH production and hyponatremia due to inappropriate ADH secretion. Small cell lung cancer-associated SIADH is due to the ectopic release of antidiuretic hormone. It is associated with increased thirst and hyponatremia. 

Other options:

Option A- Adenocarcinoma is a malignant epithelial tumor with differentiation in glands or mucin production by the tumor cells. These tumors are commonly found in women and in non-smokers. These tumors are more peripherally located and are smaller. On histopathology, the tumor shows a lepidic pattern of spread with tumor cells crawling along the normal-appearing alveolar septa. The tumor cells are positive for thyroid transcription factor 1 (TTF-1) and napsin A.

Option B- Squamous cell carcinoma is found to be more common in men and has a strong association with smoking. They have precursor lesions like squamous dysplasia, squamous metaplasia, or in situ carcinomas. On histopathology, it is characterized by keratinization and/or intercellular bridges. Keratinization occurs in the form of squamous pearls. It is positive for p40 and p63 markers. Hypercalcemia is the common paraneoplastic syndrome associated with this type.

Option C- Large cell carcinoma is an undifferentiated malignant epithelial carcinoma. On histopathology, the cells are large, with large nuclei, prominent nucleoli with a moderate amount of cytoplasm.

questions.text: A pathologist used Von Kossa stain in a biopsy sample of a brain tumour. Choose the correct option regarding the finding and deposition identified.
questions.solution:
The Von Kossa is a black stain used for staining calcium.

Calcification is often found in slowly growing brain tumours, such as oligodendrogliomas, meningiomas, and Craniopharyngiomas. The hallmark of malignant disease is haemorrhage which is frequently found in glioblastoma multiforme (GBM). 

The following staining techniques are used for calcium:

  • Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) :
    • Calcium forms a blue-black lake with hematoxylin 
  • Azan stain :
    • Used to distinguish osteoid from the mineralized bone
  • Alizarin red S stain :
    • Forms an orange-red lake with calcium
    • Works best with small amounts of calcium
    • An example is Michaelis–Gutmann (MG) bodies, seen in malakoplakia
  • Von Kossa method : 
    • Useful for tissues containing large amounts of phosphates and carbonates, such as bone
    • Silver ions react with phosphate in the presence of acidic material
    • Silver phosphate gets degraded to silver in the presence of light, giving black colour

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents with muscle pain, early fatigue, painful cramps, and cola-colored urine after joining a gym. The muscle biopsy reveals the findings shown in the slide below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A clinical scenario of a 20-year-old presenting with muscle cramps, pain, fatigue, and likely myoglobinuria (causing cola-colored urine), and muscle biopsy specimen showing vacuolar myopathy is suggestive of McArdle's disease. It is caused by the deficiency of muscle glycogen phosphorylase. 

McArdle disease, also known as type V glycogen storage disorder, is an autosomal recessive condition. It typically presents during late childhood or in the second decade of life. The muscle glycogen phosphorylase enzyme deficiency interferes with ATP generation by glycogenolysis in the muscles. This causes muscle glycogen accumulation.

Symptoms are exercise intolerance associated with muscle cramps. Due to high-intensity exercise, sudden persistent muscle contraction occurs. This leads to severe muscle damage resulting in a massive release of muscle proteins and myoglobin in the blood. Myoglobinuria secondary to rhabdomyolysis leads to the passage of burgundy-colored urine in some patients. 

A unique feature associated with McArdle is the improvement in symptoms after a rest for a few minutes. This is termed as the second wind phenomenon. 

Standard diagnosis includes muscle biopsy, which shows periodic acid Schiff (PAS)-positive vacuoles of high glycogen content due to lack of myophosphorylase and genetic testing (PYGM gene sequencing). Avoiding strenuous exercise prevents symptoms. Glucose administration before exercise can improve tolerance. Vitamin B6 is also recommended.

Other options:

Option B: Cori's disease is due to the deficiency of glycogen debranching enzyme. Infants usually present with ketotic hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, and hyperlipidemia. Muscle weaknesses are mostly seen in the third to the fourth decade of life. 

Option C: Hers disease is due to the deficiency of liver glycogen phosphorylase. Untreated children present with poor growth, ketotic hypoglycemia, and hepatomegaly.

Option D: Andersen disease is due to the deficiency of glycogen branching enzyme. Infants present with failure to thrive, hepatomegaly, progressive liver cirrhosis, and cardiomyopathy. Death occurs mostly by the age of 5 due to liver failure.

questions.text: A reactionary haemorrhage after tonsillectomy is due to improper clipping action of which of the following muscles?
questions.solution:
A Reactionary haemorrhage after tonsillectomy is due to improper clipping action of the superior constrictor muscle.

The tonsillar artery perforates the superior constrictor and ramifies in the tonsil. Therefore, the presence of a clot can hinder the clipping action of the superior constrictor muscle, resulting in a reactionary haemorrhage. A simple removal of the clot would restore the clipping action of the superior constrictor and arrest the bleeding.

Types of haemorrhages after a tonsillectomy:

Primary haemorrhage - Occurs at the time of operation.
Reactionary haemorrhage - Occurs within a period of 24 hours.
Secondary haemorrhage - Usually seen between the fifth to tenth post-operative days

questions.text: A 50-year-old smoker came with complaints of hemoptysis. Imaging revealed a mass obliterating the aortic knuckle indicating disease of which of the following sites?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a mass obliterating the Aortic knuckle indicates lesion localised to the left upper lobe.

The loss of clear demarcation between the normal lung and its surrounding soft structures (heart, diaphragm) is called the silhouette sign. It occurs due to loss of contrast between lungs and adjacent soft tissue when the lung parenchyma is no longer filled with air. 

This sign is useful in localising areas of airspace opacities, atelectasis or mass within the lung and to indicate the site of pathology.

  • right paratracheal stripe: right upper lobe
  • right heart border: right middle lobe or medial right lower lobe
  • right hemidiaphragm: right lower lobe
  • aortic knuckle: left upper lobe
  • left heart border: lingular segments of the left upper lobe
  • left hemidiaphragm or descending aorta: left lower lobe

Localising areas using silhouette signs can also be possible in Chest X-ray: Lateral view, following are the examples to indicate site of pathology in a lateral chest radiograph.

  • posterior border of the heart +/- posterior left hemidiaphragm: left lower lobe
  • anterior right hemidiaphragm: right middle lobe
  • posterior right hemidiaphragm: right lower lobe

The image given below shows the normal cardiac silhouettes in a Chest skiagram : PA view and lateral view respectively. 

SCV: Superior vena cava; RA: Right atrium; RV: Right ventricle; PA: Pulmonary artery; LV: Left ventricle; AO: Aorta

The silhouette sign is a misnomer as in the true sense it refers to the loss of silhouette or loss of distinctive outline in structure.

questions.text: A man has been arrested and booked under Sec. 80 BNS. Which of the following offences has he been accused of?
questions.solution:
The man has been accused of and arrested for dowry death. Section 80 of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS) deals with dowry deaths.

This legal provision comes into effect when the untimely demise of a woman occurs by burns/bodily injury or any other cause apart from normal circumstances within the first 7 years of her marriage. Evidence of cruelty or harassment by her spouse or relatives of her spouse in connection with demands for dowry must be shown. 


Other options:
Option A: Section 105 deals with culpable homicide not amounting to murder. Under this, the convict shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or imprisonment of either description for a term which shall not be less than five years but may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to a fine if the act by which the death is caused is done with the intention of causing death, or of causing such bodily injury as is likely to cause death. If it is determined that the act is committed with the knowledge that it is likely to cause death, but without any intention to cause death or to cause such bodily injury as is likely to cause death, the punishment is imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years and a fine.


Option C: Culpable homicide is defined under section 100 of the BNS. It states whoever causes death by doing an act to cause death, or intending to cause such bodily injury as is likely to cause death, or with the knowledge that he is likely by such act to cause death, commits the offence of culpable homicide.


Option D: Grievous hurt is defined by Sec.116 BNS. Grievous hurt refers to any hurt that endangers life, or which causes the victim to be in severe bodily pain, or unable to follow his ordinary pursuits for fifteen days. This includes emasculation, permanent privation of the sight of either eye, permanent privation of the hearing of either ear, the privation of any member or joint or the destruction or permanent impairment of the power of any member or joint, permanent disfiguration of the head or face, and fracture or dislocation of a bone or tooth.

questions.text: The autopsy of a middle-aged woman with tuberculosis reveals the following finding in the lung. Identify the pathophysiology of this lesion.

choices.text: IFN-gamma produced by Th2 cells resulting in non-caseating granuloma
IFN-gamma produced by Th1 cells resulting in caseating granuloma
IL-1 produced by Th2 cells, resulting in non-caseating granuloma
IL-1 produced by Th1 cells, resulting in caseating granuloma

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of tuberculosis and the image showing a cheesy appearance of necrosis due to incomplete proteolytic digestion of the necrotic tissue are suggestive of caseating granuloma. The pathophysiology is IFN-gamma produced by Th1 cells activates macrophages and results in the caseating granuloma. 

Note - In parasitic infections, such as schistosomiasis, the granulomas are associated with strong Th2  cell response and eosinophils.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man was recently diagnosed with secondary syphilis and was started on treatment. He was admitted to the hospital with complaints of fever with chills, headache, and myalgia noticed 3 days after starting treatment. His pulse rate is 92/min and his blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. What is the next line of management in this case?

choices.text: Decreasing the dose of the offending drug
Treatment with antipyretics for symptomatic relief

questions.solution:
The given clinical picture of fever with chills and headache after treatment with a drug for secondary syphilis is suggestive of Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction and is associated with the use of penicillin in syphilis disease.

Symptomatic management of pyrexia with antipyretics is the next line of management. Penicillin treatment need not be interrupted during the course of the treatment and thereafter. Steroids are usually not indicated.

Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction is a host immune reaction due to the release of spirochetal antigen by the dying T.pallidum on treatment with penicillin. This occurs in primary and in most cases of secondary syphilis after several hours of the first dose of penicillin.

It is characterized by fever, shivering, myalgia,headache and exacerbation of lesions. Physical findings of tachycardia, increased respiratory rate and vasodilation with mild hypotension can be observed. Additionally, increased neutrophil count may be present.

The treatment of syphilis is based on the CDC’s 2015 guidelines:

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a prolonged immune response seen after exposure to self-antigens that were initially sequestered during the development of the immune system?
questions.solution:
Post-traumatic orchitis is an example of a prolonged inflammatory response after exposure to self-antigens that were sequestered during early developmental days.

The testis, eye and brain are part of immune-privileged sites. The antigens introduced in these sites tend to elicit weak or no immune responses. The antigens from these sites are hidden or sequestered from the immune system due to their lack of communication through blood or lymph. As a result, the self-antigens in these tissues fail to elicit an immune response.

When the antigens of these tissues are released during trauma or infection it may lead to prolonged tissue inflammation and injury. Hence it can be seen as the mechanism for post-taumatic orchitis and uveitis.

questions.text: A male patient with Ewing's sarcoma is scheduled for preoperative chemotherapy. Which of the chemotherapeutic drugs used in the management of this condition causes the most neurological side effects?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, vincristine is the chemotherapeutic drug used in Ewing's sarcoma that causes the most neurological side effects.

Therefore, when there is any sign of motor dysfunction, stopping the drug or reducing the dosage might be beneficial. It also causes moderate leucopenia. Other side effects include severe constipation which can worsen colicky abdominal pain and intestinal obstruction.

Other chemotherapeutic agents that can be used for Ewing's sarcoma are

  • Doxorubicin
  • Cyclophosphamide or ifosfamide
  • Etoposide
  • Dactinomycin 

Other options:

Option B: Vinblastine primarily causes leucopenia. Neurological side effects are mild, other side effects include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and anorexia.

Option C: Vinorelbine primarily causes granulocytopenia and moderate leucopenia. It has the least neurological side effects. It can also cause allergic reactions.

Option D: Methotrexate is an antifolate drug (acts by inhibiting the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase) commonly used as a chemotherapeutic agent in the treatment of childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia, choriocarcinoma, and intrathecally for meningeal leukemia and lymphomas. It mainly causes myelosuppression. It can also lead to spontaneous hemorrhage and life-threatening infection.
